Rice was well made. Naan basket was awesome. I love variety! Recommend. 

Tandoori game hen seemed promising because it was so popular that it became a regular item. I thought the spices were good but I got impatient with tearing the meat off of the bones. The salad ended up not really being eaten but it was pretty good too.

Chicken tikka masala was more flavorful than other chicken tikka masalas I've had. I like this best of all tikka masalas I've had but was not my favorite dish of the night.

Lamb curry was delicious. The cut of lamb that they had was soft and had good flavor. The curry itself was yummy and very spicy. Recommend. 

Dal gosht was almost the same as the lamb curry. Less heat but had texture from beans. I liked this one a lot.

This place had the tastiest Indian food I've ever had but also the most expensive. The prices really crept up on us. We had $50 to spend from our coupon but we still needed to cover $60!
author: Sofia R.

description:
Finally I can give more than 3 stars to an Indian place in SF.  Chicken Tikki was solid.  Big nice pieces of quality chicken in a great sauce.   The poori was nicely done.  Not heavy and gross, but crispy and delicious.  A plus that they offer 3 types of Indian Beer.  Also a huge plus that each dish maintained its unique taste instead of all tasting like one overpowering spice.  
If you go for lunch go between 11:30 and 12:45.  We went at 1 and even though they close at 2 it was clear the staff was itching to gtfo, and I felt slightly rushed out.   But I can dig it I would feel the same way.  A very generous lunch for 2  with drinks, tip and left overs was $50.  Not bad for a special stony lunch with your best girly :-)
author: Chelsey G.

description: I went here expecting good food, however, the food is adequate. The people who were pouring us water the cleaning off the table were really nice. But, the food was bad. The vegetable samosas wee okay, little burnt, but they tasted fine. We also ordered a lamb and chicken korma. First, they both came out without the almonds and the nuts. When I asked they waitress, she said she was sorry, but didn't do anything about it. The chicken wasn't well cooked, and it tasted like it was just added to the sauce. For the money I paid for, I could have gone to several place that actually live up to the taste of Indian food. I will not go back and definitely don't recommend it.
author: Zara C.

description: Amazing food and amazing service. It's a true pleasure to eat at this restaurant. One of the most welcoming restaurants in San Francisco and finest.
author: Paul B.

description: Excellent place for Indian foot. All dishes were fresh and had their own flavors-price point at 10/12 for each item.  Coffee was a bit high -5?? However it was fresh pressed.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I hated the food along with the Indian owner (maybe) here. 
*if u have had actual Indian food, u will understand what I'm writing about.
I have been living in sf since two years now, and have tasted almost all the Indian restaurants in the bay area, but din expect the food to be THAT bad at any place.
I ordered the paneer makhani with paratha, and the paneer was like rubber, actually I had to stretch it to eat it.. and the paratha was so dry, that the piece actually got stuck in my throat..
I have the two stars cuz I liked the ambiance and the interior, but except that.. everything sucked big time.. especially the Indian owner, to whom I tried to convey my message about the food, instead started to blame me for not ordering the correct food..
I don't think I'll ever be going or recommending anyone to go to this place.. thanks and good luck.
author: Karan M.

description: They lunch special is really well priced. Great decor for an Indian restaurant. Food was really good as well!
author: Tiff W.

description: Food was ok type.We asked to make chicken curry spicy but it was sweet in taste.Other that that everything else was fine.
author: Priyanka S.

description: Family run restaurant and they make great tasting food. They also take great care of their guests. I am glad I found one of the best Indian restaurants in SF
author: Arjunsimha C.

description:
Very overpriced. Terrible service. 
This place is incredibly loud, I came here for date night with my husband and we didn't even talk because it was so loud. The food was mediocre at best. I had the chicken tikka masala and it was ok, I'd give it a 6. We also ordered the goat curry and wow was it terrible. It felt like low quality fatty meat chunks. Now the service wasn't rude or anything, but we were never checked on. We both went without refills and never got to order extra naan or dessert because our waitress never came back. We asked some other person for the check so we can leave and get ice cream down the street. The whole process of trying to get someone's attention, paying, and getting our card back took 15 minutes. Meanwhile it seemed like our waitress was waiting on everyone but us and literally running around looking stressed out. Maybe they are understaffed? Still, not my problem, I'm trying to pay for good food and leave when I'm done. None of that happened.
author: Kaylah T.

description:
ROTI IS THE BEST INDIAN RESTAURANT IN SF!!! 
We just discovered this after living in the Parkside for over 3 years. Well, better late than never! This is a very elegant restaurant that seems to "dress up" every dish with extra touches, ie; lovely bits of onions and herbs. We ordered a wide variety of food from their menu and each selection, whether it was lamb curry or a humble cucumber salad were garnished with these little extras.
In fact, we started with that Kuchumber salad which was filled with chunks of cucumber, cherry tomatoes, red onions, and herbs in a light vinegar dressing. I find that this salad is usually a rudimentary starter at most Indian restaurants. But, Roti heightened their offering with what seemed to be a variety of fresh herbs.
The Bombay Calamari was very fresh and light, not greasy.
Our mains included:
Literally the best Tandoori Chicken that we have ever had! Succulent, moist, and very intense BBQ flavor. The incidentals are usually just onions and lemon at most places,but here included several kinds of bell peppers and veggies. We discussed the possibility in the future of stopping here to pick up a couple of whole chickens to take home and build a meal around...

Seafood Curry: This had the best creamy tomato sauce covering salmon, squid, and shrimp. Sublime

Lamb Boti Kebab with masala sauce. Quite a bit of meat slices in this!

Very good saag (creamed spinach)
 
Absolutely the best Keema Naan: the bread was blistered, yet buttery with very thick layers of ground lamb. Bliss

Onion kulcha and garlic and basil naan offered in their "bread basket" assortment.

Basically, Roti Indian Bistro offers gourmet Indian food for very reasonable prices in West Portal.
author: Antoinette S.

description:
70$(with tip) into the drain!
Today, I picked up some food for my dinner from this restaurant. Thought, it should be good(according to the ratings in Yelp).
Got myself a Chicken Pakora, Chicken Tikka Masala, Kabuli naan, and plain naan.
Pakora was the same as in all other Indian restaurants. Good!
Chicken tikka masala, was the WORST I ever had in my life. How do people eat that thing? Everybody here was posting pics of Tikka Masala, and that's why I ordered two of it. Extremely salty, and I think they used some kind of black pepper, which gave me the impression of house made, first time cooking chef's food. Was not able to taste any spice, except that pepper(????) and SALT! Not creamy at all.
Kabuli naan and plain naan were overcooked, bought 3 of them(2 KN, 1PN). All of them are burned behind.
In the past, I was thinking "Downtown SF has bad Indian food", but from now on, I would prefer going there than this.
author: Hajy A.

description: What can be said about Roti that hasn't been said before? This place is high-end Indian cuisine at its finest. We are regulars here and are never disappointed with the food. The wait staff is professional and attentive. The owner is hospitable and courteous. If you like Indian food, you cannot beat this place.
author: Osvaldo D.

description: My latest obsession.  I stopped by for take out on a whim, and since then I've had several tasty and generously-portioned meals delivered to my home.  My favorite is the Murgh Madras, but I haven't quite worked my way through the entire menu.  The Kachumber salad appetizer is a treat and goes well with the main dishes.  The garlic nan with the mint cilantro chutney should be outlawed for being addictive.
author: Ernest F.

description: A solid 5 on a 1 to 10 scale. The samosas were reheated. The basmati was very dry. I ordered halibut curry. The fish was fresh but I found the dish to rather bland and uninspiring for $24. And I'm pretty sure the fish was cod. Perhaps I just prefer something more flavorful and spicy than this regional style. I do like the beer and wine selection however.
author: Stanley J.

description: Incredible food and incredible service! They literally roast their own spices, and grind them in house. Personally, I'd say this is the best Indian food I've had in the city (be sure to try the mixed vegetables). Pankaj and his service staff are also top notch, giving great recommendations for new vegetarians (I know, I know), and explaining about traditional food preparations in India!
author: Carlos K.

description:
Quiet, clean, and friendly, Roti is on the slightly more upscale side of West Portal. It's a nice ambiance because it's crowded yet quiet enough to carry conversation, but the food wasn't very memorable, on the expensive side for what they were offering (~$14/plate), AND NOT SPICY AT ALL

--Must order: the garlic naan
--Skip: chicken tikka masala. It was garbage and essentially chicken in a canned creamy tomato soup base.
--Proceed with caution: the chicken korma and lamb biryani were standouts, but the meat was unfortunately cut (when you're eating family style, it's frusturating to get a plate with three huge chunks of meat in it). 

I did have a small peeve about having water here, which may be a bigger problem for people senstive to spices: our waitress would come around often and always ask us each individually if we wanted water, regardless of when our glasses were empty. We're trying to eat/talk--just fill the cups!
author: Cailin H.

description:
This is my favorite Indian restaurant in SF. The staff and owner are cordial and service is excellent.  

I recently ordered off the monthly special menu and had the Tandoori Game Hen.  It was perfectly prepared with the right amount of spices, and was a good value. 

We also ordered the Jheenga Marsala, which is my favorite shrimp dish. The sauce is amazing.
author: J M.

description: Kaylee is the best sever ever, and I love the owner too. Every week they make hand-made batches of these spices for their curries. BEST INDIAN IN THE BAY!!! Thank you for your hard work, Team Roti! Love it.
author: J J.

description: Everything here is carefully prepared and very delicious! The owner is super pleasant and always stops by to make sure you're happy.  The place is noisy, though -- I wish they'd hang some rugs or something... Conversation can be challenging on Friday and Saturday nights.
author: Jill T.

description: Excellent food!!! Just the right amount of spices in the sauces. Wonderful service as well. My water never went dry. Probably my favorite Indian food yet!
author: Sean C.

description: Roti never fails to put smiles on my family's faces. The navratan korma is an absolute must-have. Finish off a nice meal with kulfi and you'll leave very happy and satisfied. Roti has become a regular for my family and me.
author: Jacqui R.

description: My girlfriend was using the restroom and I was waiting to wash my hands. As I was waiting for her I noticed the art hanging on the wall had fly crap all over it. When She came out and announced that there was no toilet paper I let one of the employees know and he handed me a roll that had a cockroach on it. Disgusting! We did not stay and will never return. My perception is that it is filthy.
author: Marnie F.

description: This is one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  We LOVE the food, the staff... Panjak is just amazing!  We come here often because the food is superb and the service is attentive and accommodating! The monthly specials have seasonal specialties,  (awesome Crab cakes!!) and we often order 3-4 different dishes which we share.  We have had fabulous birthday parties here for 12 people, with again, awesome service and food.  Panjak and his family are professional, friendly, generous and sincerely great people.  We have eaten at many Indian restaurants in the bay area and this is by far, the Best!!
author: Carol B.

description:
This is undoubtedly our favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco. I was reminded of how authentic and excellent the food is recently when I had the opportunity to compare it with that of another highly rated Indian restaurant as I dined at both within less than a week and ordered exactly the same dishes. The Roti versions were more flavorsome, fresher tasting and less greasy. Our favorite dishes include: chicken pakoras, served with Roti's amazing mint chutney, the chicken tikka masala, the lamb korma and the jheenga palak (jumbo prawns with spinach). We always over-order so we can take food home with us. The service is friendly, personable and speedy. The staff make a special effort to welcome children, bringing delicious mango lassis soon after arrival. 
The stylish, smart interior, inviting lighting and attractive wall hangings make for a great ambiance too. Well worth the excursion to West Portal if you've never been out here.
author: Rachel B.

description:
I don't understand why this place isn't rated higher than it is. Their prices are decent, the ambience is good for a neighbourhood stop and the food is authentic. Undoubtedly it doesn't have the hipster vibe of Dosa, but but please remember that's not what they're trying to do here! The one thing we liked is that the menu is focused on North Indian, unlike some places that try to have everything Indian and nothing right! Try the Tandoori Game Hen and then ask yourself if you've had something juicier and more flavourful somewhere else. Their lamb Biryani is good value and is perfect for sharing. Finish it off with the yummy Khulfi!

Sometimes the service is lacking, especially during lunch when there's only one server on the floor. But I always believe we need to cut others some slack- unless we can do better ourselves!
author: Farah A.

description:
I love Roti! I order from there at least once or twice a week. 

What would make me give them 5 stars?? A couple of vegan options so there is an alternate to some of the vegetarian dishes with dairy would be wonderful. I would LOVE it if they could offer a vegan version of the mint chutney. I'm sure there is a good one out there, and it would make us who are trying not to eat dairy very happy! Here's one I found: http://vegetarian.about.com/od/rawfoodsrecipes/r/mint-chutney.htm

My other wish is that they might play around with some vegan alternatives to the paneer. 

Thank you, Roti!
author: Michelle S.

description: My favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco. In addition to having great dishes, the warm welcome from the owner and his son is second to none. I could eat here everyday and not get enough.
author: Cheick D.

description: Found this restaurant on Yelp because I was looking for something close by and Indian. The two of us ordered three dishes, rice, and roti. The roti never made it to the table. The spinach and potato dish, the chicken breast dish, and the shrimp dish were good. The pulao rice was very dry (or day-old) and tasteless. Because the rice was so disappointing, I didn't enjoy the meal. I was very hungry and the food was edible, so you could say it was "satisfying"? I won't be back, and the main reasons are because of the rice, feeling rushed by the woman server, and the quality of their food. I wonder what the roti was like. I'll never know. We didn't order drinks and the bill with tip was $60. The best part of this dining experience? Coming in from the cold and wet night to meet up with a loved one and being seated next to a space heater.
author: Mo O.

description:
I work in the South Bay and have frequented many of the notable Indian places south of the City, including many recommended by South Asian friends.  While I have my favorites in the Valley, none of them compares to Roti.  This might be my favorite Indian restaurant on earth.

The menu lists many dishes that you'll recognize from other places, but you will be astounded at the quality of the preparation here.  The spicing in particular is perfect:  the sauces taste like blends of various raw materials rather than something that came out of a bottle full blown like Athena from Zeus' bust.  

We tend to go with the same couple of friends, which means we can count on their ordering chicken makhani, saag aloo, bengan bharta, garlic naan, onion kulcha, and paratha with every meal.  Those dishes are sophisticated renditions of staples at most Indian places and they will make you appreciate just how upscale this cuisine is.  

For the remaining dishes at our repasts, we've sampled nearly everything else on the menu.  Particularly good here are the tandoori dishes, which always are redolent of smoke. If it's on the menu as a special, don't miss the incredible -- but maybe unauthentic -- tandoori duck; my only complaint is the portioning of that dish is uncharacteristically cheapskate, so you might need two orders to satisfy a party of four.  If there's no duck, try the tandoori cornish game hen -- again, who knows if this is authentic? -- and you won't go wrong.  Goanese vindaloos are good, too, with enough vinegar flavor to remind you that you aren't eating a garden variety curry dish. 

There's a wine list, I gather, but, seriously, this is not food that goes well with wine. The better choices are Indian and artisan beers, lemonades, mango lassis, and ginger beers.

Service can be variable but it's never less than good.  The manager or perhaps owner, an older gentleman, is certain to stop by your table to confirm your happiness and gloat in your compliments about the food.  He's also very quick to offer complimentary servings of cooling raita, never a bad addition to an Indian meal.

The bill adds up quickly, but you really do get what you pay for here.  Well worth the modest premium over other Indian sit-down places.

If I have one complaint, it's the same one that I have about every other San Francisco restaurant these days: It's too freaking loud.  You'll hear everyone else's conversations as you carry on your own, including those of people who need to shout louder to stay above the din.  That said, this is not an unusually loud place for San Francisco, given what passes for ambience at nearly every sit-down place in town.  At least there's no blaring music adding to the bombardment.  

As other reviewers have noted, you need to allocate some time to finding parking in West Portal.  We live there, so we walk, but we feel your pain.
author: Mike R.

description: Went here for a casual dinner; we ordered the Chicken Tikki Masala and the Chicken Korma, as well as the side naan and rice. The food was outright delicious. The Chicken Tikki Masala was just the right amount of spicy and extremely flavorful. Our bill was $55 without tax/tip for a 2 person dinner. I mean sure, that's a bit pricey for Indian food. So if you're solely craving Indian food for the heck of it, I would suggest a cheaper alternative such as those on Irving St (Naan and Curry/ Noori). However, if you want to have a nice dinner experience with attentive customer service, definitely check this place out.
author: Stefany Z.

description:
So I was coming home from SFO and was hungry. Thought I wanted some Indian food, but couldn't think of where, so I went to my Yelp and looked at things around me and found this place. Decided because of the review to try it out! 

WOW!!! What an amazing place! I lucked out and found parking right in the front, but I'm told that was only because there was a Niners game going on. I was met by a VERY nice staff including the Owner who, I had an extensive chat with and was very kind! The FOOD...outstanding! I had the Basil Lemonade. Good, but different and hard to explain. Then had the Goat Cheese stuffed Naan and a Murgh Makhani. Nice spice to the chicken and very flavorful. Portions were big, which is nice change in a Indian restaurant. I had a very nice lunch the next day! I don't live near by, but when I'm back in SF or coming home from work, I will definitely stop by again. Wish they were in my town, I would go there all the time!
author: Michella F.

description: They are back !!!  But come on peeps - get your health department score UP !!! Come on!
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
We used to come to this place years ago and it was always good. But we came back recently and it has improved!

It is now our favorite Indian food in SF
author: Tom N.

description:
5 star experience, however parking was a challenge.  We celebrated my daughters 18th birthday.  Food was very good but owner made the experience spectacular.  He and his staff brought a wonderful desert to share and served the 3 kids mango lassi and chai.  He also introduced my son and I to the different levels of spice...we definitely like it hot.  

The only reason for the four stars is the parking.  However, in all fairness the experience, food and service deserve 6 stars.  Thank you for making such an important night extra special.

Roti will continue to be a family favorite.
author: Ken M.

description:
Consistently excellent service and great food.  The standard Indian-American items are better than any other Indian restaurant in SF. 
We recently attend an upscale Indian dinner party at a friends. We were asked to bring something and ran out of time to cook AND we were a bit worried about how spicy things might be for the kids so we stopped at Roti to pick up our 5 year old's favorite in the world -slightly spicy chicken korma. The dinner was Indian and one guest had brought an incredible Pandi Curry from his home in Coorg. A number of other things including homemade dal that no US restaurant could hope to duplicate. And we talked about westernized Indian food but HERE'S THE THING: with no prodding, 2 of the Indian guests, (the 2 who had cooked things!) commented on how much they liked the chicken korma we brought from Roti.
author: K C.

description:
This place was very satisfying for a Friday night when I happened to look through restaurants in the hood and it landed on Roti.  Plus, I remembered we were holding a livingsocial deal for $50 for this place.  So reservations made on yelp through the phone and 20 minutes later, we were in the door. 

The only thing that beats a great meal is great service and this is the place for the best of both worlds.  The restaurant is very welcoming, and the fragrance of herbs and spices permeate through the restaurant.  The staff is very attentive, even if they are not assigned to your seating area, you're asked how you are, if the food is to your liking, etc.  Even the manager and owner came by several times to ensure the meal was satisfactory.  And it was.  They went above and beyond to everyone I noticed in the restaurant, a far and distant trade among the service industry lately.

We started out with the Goat cheese naan with regular naan on another plate.  Fantastic.  This is a must try for anyone.

Next was the saffron rice, which is long grain, simple and subtle but overall good.  The proteins were stewed with love and came out fall off the bone delicious.  The lamb was to die for, the classic chicken tikka masala was delightful, the spinach and prawns were a nice addition as recommended by our waiter, and best of all, the lentils and vegetables dish was absolutely the best dish in that place!

Again, good food becomes great with great service.  The manager took no time in jumping in when we were all deciding whether or not to have dessert.  He simply said, I'll take care of it and off he was with our menus.  In a couple minutes, our table was sharing mango lassi's which were creamy, smooth and a great compliment to the end of the meal.  He also brought out a plate of the galub jamun made of sweetened dumplings and milk and a sauce that was killer.  

So the livingsocial obviously helped but with two rounds of drinks, meal for 5, and two desserts, it was barely over $100.  I would've expected it to be double that.  No complaints here!  Great for meat lovers, great for vegetarians, and great atmosphere and service makes this a go to place for the crew when we need a good time out before or after the movies in W. Portal.  Thanks Roti!
author: Myke Y.

description:
I love West Portal. I love how cute and quaint Roti looks too. The service is awesome only because they told me that when you substitute chicken with paneer in "Chicken Tikka Masala" they just take out the chicken from the curry and add paneer. So then its basically not vegetarian.

The reason why I rated it a 2 star is because of the food. 

 It's white washed Indian food - no offense.

If your going for a cute date and don't care about the way your food tastes, go here.
If your looking to satisfy your Indian food craving- don't.
author: Muneera M.

description:
Kind and conscientious host, good service, family friendly, nice ambiance.  

Food is good, Especially the korma and biryani.
author: Mira F.

description: This is great Indian food! The Roti Basket really hit the spot, and the saag aloo was cooked to perfection. Ryan (our hot waiter) made this experience wonderful, and the overall atmosphere was really cozy and relaxing. Definitely my new favorite spot on West Portal. Will be returning for the food and just in case Ryan is working.
author: Katherine P.

description:
What is Indian food? Usually, for me it has always been a very heavy, rich and full of spice cuisine that leaves me wanting for a warm place to curl up and sink in to. Never would be a place for lunch because I do not want or need a food coma in the middle of the day!

Alas! 

I have found a restaurant that has all the flavor of proper Indian food, but in much lighter fair. Their prices are right, their Naan is awesome and their Game Hens are delicious.

-Adrian
author: Adrian E.

description:
This is our Go-to indian restaurant. Unique tastes and revolving monthly specials make it fun. Nargisi Kofta was delicious. Vindaloo curry is done right- it is supposed to be spicy so order it with caution!

The owners are hospitable and generous. It's my top 3 choices to eat indian food in the city.
author: Sharika S.

description:
Redemption time. 

Roti can fill up very quickly, hence a somewhat small lag in service. Once the order is taken things get rolling and the apps and entree are delivered at a good pace. The food is always delicious. 

They use flavors in such a way as not to over power the chicken or meat. The portions are very generous.

The owner came over several times to check on our food and suggested a nice complimentary yogurt sauce. A nice touch.

Roti is back :)
author: Kenneth S. L.

description: Today is my husband's bday and after a long debate he finally decided to come here. I happily abide as we came here once long time ago and had good memory of the last visit. Not only we were not disappointed tonight, we have even better experience than the last one. Food was beyond expectation though my husband thought it was too salty to his palate since he recently went on a low-sodium diet for health reasons. The manager, whom we really like and respect  (yes respect because he has this really calm and wise demeanor) took my husband comments so seriously and offered to give us extra onions to be added to his dish since he loves onions. He also reminded us tell them ahead of time in the future of any diet restrictions. We were also given a complimentary ice-cream with candle.  ;) All the servers were excellent and professional. My husband was proud of his choice and I'm too!  We will come back soon.
author: Chung T.

description: This is our new go to when our Indian food craving finds us. Thanks to them that craving has gone way up and we are becoming regulars. Great food and convenient by offering reservations.
author: james r.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco and one of my favorite Indian places in he Bay. Their goat cheese naan and the garlic basil naan are phenomenal and the rest of their food is terrific too. On top of that, they have amazing service - the food comes out pretty fast and the manager/owner will personally come by to check up on you.
author: Nirav S.

description:
This time Dave and I were attempting 5 at 5pm. When you get a craving for Indian food, it's 1) Contagious and 2) Irreplaceable so there we were piling into the car driving across town to West Portal, one of the few village like enclaves in San Francisco. Entering Roti with three kids in tow including twin two year old boys, I could barely lift my head to look the maître d in the eyes as we followed him to our table in the middle of the restaurant.  "Cool", shouted Cate jumping onto the banquet full of throw pillows followed by her brothers climbing on up as she rearranged pillows and scooted on down to the other side of the table facing me. I was still draping jackets and hanging purses off my chair which gave me a chance to scan the restaurant and judge whether or not any uncomfortable looks were coming our way. I got a warm nod from an elderly couple and saw that there was another little girl seated quietly with an iPad. I don't know how my nerves would make it through the day without the iPads at home but I'm not bringing them to restaurants or cafés. It's one of the few rules that haven't fallen to the wayside like eating on the couch and jumping off the coffee table.
Before I'm even settled in my seat, our charismatic server brought out three mango lassies in tiny fancy glasses with colorful straws. The kids eyes widened with enjoyment as they slurped down their treat. I took this opportunity to say hello to my husband while gathering all the knives from kids arm length. We were then offered papadam which ended up being a bit too spicy for Cate and Shane but Declan crunched away. Encouraged by his gusto I introduced him to the fresh plum sauce thinking dipping would entice him to try it, I was wrong so I distributed crayons and paper and picked up the menu. We ordered the tandoori mixed grill platter that sizzled and steamed onto the table capturing everyone's attention. I could not get any eye contact while I chanted over and over "no touching." Chicken, beef, lamb, prawns, and salmon sat piping hot in front of a captive audience. Dave and I had watched the skewers turning our meat in the open kitchen and the tenderness of each piece did not disappoint. I divvied up the pieces for the kids but their plates were still left untouched when the lentils, chicken masala, and prawn vindaloo arrived. I thought I'd spare the restaurant of having to sweep up afterwards so instead of ordering a rice dish we went with two orders of regular naan along with a keema naan. Needless to say we ordered way too much food but what's better than going out to Indian? Eating the leftovers the next day.
author: Danielle W.

description:
The thing I hate about Indian restaurants is that they cook the $#!* out of their meat until it's tough and dry. Not so with Roti. The chicken, in particular, comes out perfectly tender and juicy every time. The level of spice and flavor is just right for me.

It's a bit pricy, but the atmosphere is the best I've seen for an Indian restaurant. The service is OK, and they always bring my four-year-old a complimentary shot of mango lassi, which he loves.

I go to Roti more often than any other Indian restaurant around here.
author: Mike L.

description:
After passing on this place because it was too crowded before, we were able to have dinner at Roti tonight.  

The papadum we started with tasted great, and did the tamarind chutney that came with it.  Then came the Murgh Masala, Lamb Korma, Roti's Basmati Pulao, along with Roti's Bread Basket.  

The Murgh Masala was good, but the Lamb Korma was even better.  I loved drenching in the bread in the Korma sauce.  We ordered the basket of bread because I wanted to try all of them.  My favorite was definitely the Onion Kulcha, followed by the Garlic & Basil Naan.  

Our service was excellent.  Water glasses we refilled promptly as they were emptied.  The very nice owner even stopped by to check on us, and asked if the food was spicy enough for us.  

It is a little pricey for dinner.  All of the food was really good, but there wasn't a single OMG, off-the-scale-good dish that I was hoping for.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: The food was pretty bland for Indian standards but the service made up for it! The owner Pankaj was understanding.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Manager/Owner is really very humble and waitress good at service. He usually takes your feedback to improve further and provide you the best.
I just tried dinner twice and really like dal makhani (very different from others), lachcha parantha (awesome), vegetable biryani
author: Prateek G.

description:
I've tried many many Indian places in the city in hopes of keeping my wife happy and we have resolved to come only here now on a weekly basis. The reasons are:
-fresher ingredients than any other place we tried
-flavors are clean - I asked the owner and he says each dish is cooked in a new pan
-staff is very nice - there's been no turnover in years and that says a lot about a place


I suggest the biryani, mixed grill, and murgh makni.
author: J D.

description:
Nice place, food was...hmm... ok, but it wasn't Indian food. The channa was close, paratha was good. Aloo Gobi was cauliflower with tomato sauce and a couple potatoes, and the vegetable biryani was white rice, tomato sauce, and mixed veggies. First time eating at an Indian restaurant that I needed salt. But it was fresh food, so that was good.

Chef must have been in training. E for effort, but wouldn't eat his food again if he called it Indian food.
author: Jamal S.

description:
I might just enjoy the holes in the walls, but this place wasn't too impressive for me. It was too clean cut for an Indian place. I came here on a weeknight for dinner, via the living social deal with a friend. For $50 bucks, you can basically feed 3 people (barely). With two people we had a little left over, but wasn't much.

What we had:
Calamari Appetizers - Not too bad, but not really that great. It was cut into rings and large tentacles, and the tentacles were the better ones. The rings were cut a little too big, so it was a lot more chewy than crispy. It came with two sauces, which I assume makes it "bombay style" but it was very hard to understand what the sauces were. One was a dark sauce that was not quite balsamic, not quite wine reduction. It was slightly tangy. The other was a green sauce that was like a cucumber herb aioli. 

Spicy Garlic Asparagus (seasonal): This was on the monthly special thing. It said spicy asparagus, and we were excited to get some spicy garlicy asparagus. Was a little disappointed. The asparagus was cooked well, but it wasn't garlicy enough or spicy enough. It really tasted more like grilled asparagus.

Chicken Vindaloo: total disappointment. The menu said it was in a hot and spicy sauce, which my friend and I were both excited about. But...what came out was pretty bland and not spicy at all. The taste wasn't authentic. FYI, they use thigh meat with this. Just in case you care.

Chicken Tikka Masala: This was better than the Chicken Vindaloo, but still not quite authentic. It was good though, and made with chicken breast meat. I might come back for this.

Basil & Garlic Naan: this was pretty good! The basil made the scent amazing and we'd never had basil and garlic on naan before.

I think Roti has catered a little too much to the interests in the area. There's about 6 Italian restaurants in the neighborhood, and a lot of the food they offered had a bit of Italian touches to it. IE, Calamari, Basil in Naan, etc. It made the food less than authentic. They also seem to pull back on the flavors. I love Indian food because its full of flavor, but Roti's food was really bland in comparison to other Indian places I've been to. This deducted a star from them.

Service-wise, I was a little disappointed. We walked in and was seated immediately, but it took FOREVER for a waiter to come by to help us. I was craning my neck around like an OWL and they didn't notice! I finally waived someone down and we got our orders in. After the food was in, they were much better at getting our waters refilled and the owner (I assume) came by to ask if our meal was good. I take off half a star for the poor initial service.

Final review: 1 star off for inauthentic food, 1/2 star off for poor initial service, and another 1/2 star off for high prices without the good food to back it up. I don't mind paying more for good food, but don't price your food to something that's more than it is!
author: Lily W.

description: Local's favorite.  They do a great job taking care of my daughter's needs with special child's sauce, making great pakoris my wife digs and a craveable lamb kabab for me.  Ask for Tasha... great service.
author: Sam L.

description: This place is really good!  I was surprised!  Chicken tikka masala was nice and creamy, mango chutney was the perfect sweetness, lamb korma was ok, Naan was good, rice was good, aloo ghobi was the perfect tenderness and the curry was at the right spice level.  Portions are big but it's pricy. Worth trying!
author: Joanna P.

description:
Excellent service but overpriced.

This place is not for you if you don't like spicy food. I personally don't like spicy so I had to ask what is not spicy on the menu. I was told that there are only two items on the menu that is less spicy (nothing was not spicy at all). So we ordered the only two that was less spicy, chicken tikka tandoori ($15) and chicken tikka masala ($16).

The food took a while to come out so they gave us some papadum to hold us over. It was a nice gesture. 

The flavors of the tikka masala is one of the best I've had but it was also one of the spiciest I've had. If this was one of the least spiciest dishes on the menu, I cannot imagine how hot the other dishes are. It's also more expensive than what I'm used to paying for tikka masala (around $8). And no, they cannot make their dishes less spicy since the spice is already mixed into the meats/sauces.

The chicken tikka tandoori was better in terms of heat but the chicken was dry. Our server was great, he brought us some yogurt sauce for the chicken which made it less dry and added flavor.

The chai ($3) was good and bottomless and they are great about refills. Again, other places offer chai either for free or for only a buck and yes they are also bottomless.

Different servers checked on us through out our meal, we were never left feeling abandoned.

Although I don't think I will find this level of service at any other Indian restaurant, I don't think I will be coming back. There are many Indian restaurants that are just as good but more reasonably priced.
author: Andy W.

description:
The service in the restaurant on a busy Saturday afternoon was poor. Very difficult to get anyone's attention and the place seemed to be running in a chaos.

The food was really average. Indian food that I have eaten in other popular restaurants like Dosa, Naan n Curry and Amber is way superior. Even though I am not Indian, I could tell that the food didn't taste anywhere close to be authentic. However, I am not dinging them because of the food since that is subjective...just giving my opinion.

I am giving them two stars because of the slowness of service and lack of attention from the service staff. It may have been a bad day; I am willing to change my opinion. Will give them one more shot since they are the only Indian restaurant in my neighborhood.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Mediocre in my opinion. I don't think Clay Oven just down the street is any worse. We ordered the Chicken Makni and the Aloo Gobi. The Makni was okay; typical in your Indian restaurants. No differentiator. Potatoes in the Aloo Gobi were undercooked to my liking. Felt like it was a tomato based sauce - maybe a little too tomatoey; feel like I've had better at some buffets. The garlic naan was extremely buttery and was not crispy.  

Nothing I had here will bring me back.
author: Alton Y.

description:
Crappy delivery.  Spilt my drink before getting it to my house.

Also, delivery packaging sucks.  Looks like they just rushed everything out and the Biryani spilt all over the damn place as soon as we took it out of the bag.  VERY pisspoor service.  

The new management needs to Gordon Ramsey to fix their issues.

I used to love this place.
author: Phong L.

description: The Chicken Korma... so good! Always friendly service. A bit more pricey, but also more upscale setting, than the other WP Indian restaurant Clay Oven.
author: Darin E.

description:
Definitely a great place.
Food is quite good - but the best is the patron of the place .
He twice checked on me after I ate a bit of my husband's spicer dish and then brought me raita to ease the flames :)

Their paneer is homemade and exquisite - I rarely eat dairy these days but this was worth it !
author: Maya z.

description:
Good for lunch, pricey for dinner. Lunch items are about $10-12.

I highly recommend:
Chicken Tikka Masala
Tandoori "fish of the day" Salmon Salad

Tandoori Chicken is also pretty good and I like dipping it into the Tikka Masala sauce.
author: Derek M.

description: This was one of the very few Indian restaurants in the bay where you are really taken care of. The service, variety of food and the ambience is noteworthy. I really liked that the owner of this little restaurant, went  around each table to enquire if we had received our order and if the food was good.  I loved the chole, and the garlic naan, even the tandoori roti was very soft. This was my first time to this place and I am definitely going again.
author: Sangamitra N.

description:
As Guy Fieri would say, "We've arrived at Flavortown!" Roti Indian Bistro was better than I expected! I had a craving for Indian and I remembered seeing this place whilst eating across the street at El Toreador one day and made the decision to get my family to come here for an after-church lunch (:

My parents both ordered the Naanini and honestly, I don't like the metallic-like, earthy lamb flavor, but the lamb was delicious. Moist, soft, and of course spice enriched, it was super yummy. My brother got some kind of chicken curry and it was good but nothing I'd craze over. I ordered the vegetarian thali and I definitely recommend that! It doesn't seem like much since everything comes in small-looking bowls, but I assure you, I left with a food baby. I don't even know what I ate, but I know that I loved everything, especially two of the bowls. The cucumber salads that came with all our dishes were all really good too! I think anyone who likes honey mustard will like it. And of course, the naan. Oh naan. Soft, bready naan. The naan here was great. It was great alone, but duh you had to dip it in everything which accentuated all the flavors even more. We also got a garlic basil naan and that was like garlic bread on naan on crack!! 

I really recommend coming here for a good Indian fix. All the spices and flavors that I got from them were intoxicating. I was full but couldn't help myself from constantly dipping back into the food. I loved everything, and again, the vegetarian thali was amazing. It lets you try a variety of things and for sure, you'll be filled with eating all the naan along with it. It also comes with a milky chai that's super warming! Love the ambiance and the nice waitress we had. Definitely coming back (:
author: Holly P.

description:
If BFF had his way (& he usually gets his way, unless not one, but TWO girls are putting the kibosh on his plans), we would've had an Indian-themed day starting with yoga & ending with a Bollywood movie marathon. We skipped all that & just lunched at Roti in West Portal. 

My party of three started with assorted appetizers. Papadum (lentil wafer), vegetable pakoras (mixed veggies fried in a chick pea batter--crisp & flavorful), & veggie samosa (filled w/ potatoes, peas, curry spice--I enjoyed it considering I don't love curry.)

Other dishes included lamb chops (which I did not try) & a salmon dish (which was a tad fishy tasting. Also, sauce was not appetizing to a few of us at the table.)

The one thing I thoroughly enjoyed was running huge pieces of garlic & basil naan through the sauce in our murgh makhani dish (tandoori chicken cooked in tomatoes, butter, & cream--that *cant* be bad!) I opted for white meat chicken, which was firm & slightly dried out. 

Lunch is served with chai tea, which was mildly spiced & flavored... just like everything else on the menu. Believe me, I'm not saying I want to be hit with super strong Indian spices (I actually enjoy 'fusion' cooking), but it seems Roti is walking on eggshells in the kitchen, so as not to offend patrons with robust flavors. Your diners are here for Indian food, so don't be afraid to give it to 'em.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
At first I had some serious doubts.

I was not a fan of them not putting prices on their online menus.  I was afraid that it would be overpriced but when we arrived and got to see the menus it wasn't crazy.

It is about 1.5x the price of a divey Indian restaurant but the quality was a lot better.  And to our surprise the portions were HUUUUGE...

So at the end of the day, It is actually a really good deal.  

The service was attentive and thoughtful.

The Beghan Bharta was one of the best I've had and the Naan was delicious.  

Vegetable Biryani was too much for the two of us to finish...  It also had great spice and flavor.
author: William G.

description:
Food is good, but way overpriced when there is better Indian food available in the city and for cheaper. Chicken Tikka Masala had a tomato flavor, not a spicy flavor, but the Chicken was fresh and tender.

Overall, If they lower their prices, I think they would sell more food. Nice people, just overpriced.
author: Raymond A.

description:
I missed putting a review on this lovely place in foggy West Portal. The service is great and the food is about one step above the classic indian fare. The sauces are a little lighter, a little more lively. The naan is killer - the classic is just fine, just as good as the other flavored types. 

My folks are venturing more into different taste palates, and really enjoyed this dinner, which is very telling.
author: Art H.

description:
Y'know, when you go to the movies and you see those Fandango commercials before the previews? The ones with the paper bag puppets. Yeah, those ads. Well, my favorite is the Bollywood musical number (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pqCKoGhc-qA). That has nothing to do with this review except I just had some great Indian food. OK, maybe that's still a stretch...

Even though West Portal sounds like a gateway to heaven or at least the entrance to a really pricey Greek-style spa, it's actually one of those neighborhoods in which I rarely venture. I'm a downtown type of guy that refers to anything in this area as "somewhere over Twin Peaks". Shame on me for having such a limited vantage point since there are a lot of cool eateries around here of which this is one of the best.

Five of us commandeered a table in this low-key Indian restaurant (...not to be mistaken for Rotee, the also stellar and slightly more casual place in the Haight). It was abuzz with activity that night, but the decor was soothing to this savage beast. Mustard walls. Silk fabrics framed on the walls. Soft lighting. Just the right vibe for the type of dinner that five friends, who hadn't seen each other in a while, wanted to have. On our appetite meter, we were definitely more than peckish moving toward full-blown famished.

So to cut to the chase, we went for two orders of the $33-per-person Roti's Feast, which you may see as our lazy way to get around the menu. Yes, t'is true...but that's because everything looked so good. We received assorted samosas and pakoras which we promptly subdivided, a mixed tandoori plate, murgh masala, dal, pulao, kachumber, raita, naan, kheer and chai. If you recognize more than three names on that list, you have a more sophsticated palate than mine.

I actually don't recall the chai, but I was so wrapped up in the dinner conversation that I may have overlooked it in favor of the wine. We also went for the dessert-like $16 Lamb Korma, which was bathing in a spicy cream sauce and topped with almonds & cashew nuts. Very tasty. We also shared the $10 Aloo Gobi, which had cauliflower and potato chunks cooked with onions, turmeric, and fresh herbs. The $4 Onion Kulcha was excellent as it was naan stuffed with herbs, spices and onions The dishes were becoming a blur of furious flavors at this point in the evening.

No matter as I plan to return to the wilds of West Portal even if it means going outside my geographic comfort zone. Even with all the Indian options in my part of town, including Rotee and Indian Oven, the food is just that good here. So prepare the horses and the wagons and if you are not of such pioneer stock, you are still allowed to take a Muni train. It's worth the trek in any case.

FOOD - 5 stars...rich, tasty Indian food in the Wild, Wild West Portal area
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...warm, not ostentatious and seemingly quite popular
SERVICE - 4 stars...relatively prompt and serviceable
TOTAL - 5 stars...for the food mainly...scale Twin Peaks and bring a Fandango-inspired paper bag puppet to entertain yourself in case there is a wait
author: Ed U.

description:
Upscale Indian food does well in the West Portal area.  After hearing the buzz about Roti, I finally had a chance to see what all the noise was about.

Without reservations on a weekday, I was seated immediately for my party of two.  While waiting for my dining companion, I had a chance to peruse the menu and take notice of the details of this restaurant.  This is definitely a full-service restaurant that has a decent wine menu.  (Wine glasses are part of your table setting, so they are hoping you order wine.)

It took us awhile to look over the menu as we were catching up and the waitress seemed a little over anxious to take our orders.  At the time, it wasn't that busy and we felt rushed getting our dinner choices in.

* Roti's Bread Basket: "Assortment of Tandoori Roti (Fresh whole wheat bread baked in Tandoor), Onion Kulcha (Naan stuffed with minced lamb, spices and cilantro), and Garlic & Basil Naan (Unleavened bread with garlic and basil)." $9 - This is more than enough for two people!  I would suggest getting this for parties of four!  All very tasty and oh so good!

* Jheenga Masala: "Jumbo prawns (butterflied) sauted with onions, ginger, fresh tomatoes, herbs, spices and saffron." $18 - We requested this dish to be mild since my friend couldn't handle the heat.  Very good though and full of flavor.

* Navrattan Korma: "Seasonal mixed vegetables cooked with herbs in mild cream sauce with almonds and golden raisins." $11 - This dish was spicy, which didn't help my friend much.  (I wish the waiter noted that since we wanted mild for the other dish, maybe this one shouldn't be spicy either?  It never mentioned anything about being spicy!)  I really liked it though, and it had tofu as well!  So much going on in this dish and I loved slathering my naan bread with this stuff!

* Mango Lassi: "Refreshing mango yogurt drink." $5 - It was my friend's first time trying the mango lassi and she enjoyed it.

Overall, the food was really tasty and I enjoyed my experience there.  They were excellent with refilling my water glass without being asked, so big points right there!  It took a little too long for our food to come out though and the waiter even came by to apologize about the delay.  The restaurant really started to pile in and maybe the kitchen got inundated with orders and ours got lost in there somewhere?

I would definitely go back, maybe with a larger party so we can try other things too.

$60, including tax and tip.

(You can find pics of our dinner in the business profile section!)
author: Teri C.

description: Love how warm and gracious the service is here, felt like guests, not just customers. The food was delicious too, Thanksgiving arrived early with the November Turkey Leg :)
author: Cindy L.

description:
There are many choices for Indian food in San Francisco, lower end cheap, middle, and high end fancy. We like Roti because it is an all around middle range any night of the week Indian food restaurant. They serve great naan and a full scope of rice and meat dishes as well as vegetarian dishes that are flavorful. 

For thanksgiving one year they had a tandoori turkey leg and a sweet potato dish that was a fun twist in the Classic American thanksgiving dinner. With that the kabuli naan stuffed with cranberries was a treat! Since then I've been completely addicted to the kabuli naan. :) it's especially delish smothered in raita and mango chutney. YUM

The service is always decent and the owner always remembers us and says hello. This is a place we bring our family when in town. A nice all around neighborhood place. A real comfort!
author: Mary Q.

description:
Favorite Indian Restaurant by far.

everything is delicious. The biryani (all options they have) are delicious. I have been twice so far and I have yet to find a dish I don't like. This place is more family style service so be ready to share. The tandoori basket portion is massive so not recommended for groups smaller than 4. I loved the tandoori mixed grill and it truly  had something for everyone: lamb, chicken, fish. We went here for my mom's birthday dinner and when they heard they brought us a complimentary dessert with the bill. It was really nice and delicious :)
author: Larisa V.

description:
Great service on a busy Saturday night. We tried the appetizer sampler and the vegetarian platter. They were all great. Although I love the Indian yogurt dip, I was a little surprised that so much was provided as a dish in the vegetarian platter. Seems a more main dish could have been added or the tandoori eggplant as advertised.
Nonetheless --- we thought the food was delicious and will return again!
author: Zoe D.

description:
The ambiance of the restaurant is good and so is the service.  But I have been spoiled by the  abundant amount of cheap and good Indian food in the south bay, so in comparison, the food here is not as great and pricier.  

We got the chicken tekki masala and it was a bit too creamy; very filling.  We also got the appetizer sampler.  The samosa was solid 3 star, but nothing stood out.   We also got another dish but it was too creamy as well.  I think if they made the curries a little less creamy, it would be better and also we will be able to eat more :-)
author: Kat Z.

description: food and service are always good.  Like to try new things when go but always have to get the chicken tikki
author: Steve S.

description:
Delicious food
Great service
Lovely atmosphere
Owner is delightful
author: Lucy P.

description:
Roti is hands down the best Indian food Ive had. Every time I get out to SF I make sure to stop in and get lunch or dinner. I suggest you do the same. I recommend the Chicken Korma (which you can order to be spicy) with Jasmine Rice and the Goat Cheese Naan. That dish from this restaurant is my favorite Indian dish, hands down.

The service is always spot on - great presence and timing without hovering or being over eager - and the location and ambiance are perfect. 

Ask for Jake to be your server. He's got a great knowledge of the menu and he's very accommodating.

Roti earns all five stars with ease.
author: John G.

description:
My friend wanted to go here so I couldnt deny her decision, so this is basically her review:

She had palak paneer and plain nann

"There is no flavor in the palak paneer and the cheese is extra hard [firm]"

"It taste old like it was reheated"

"The nann is gross"

She was completely disappointed with the food so much that she barely ate half of her dish and did not want the rest to take home.

My previous review still stands as nothing was different with the food. 

One thing that was very different was the attack of waiters / servers / owner(?) who kept asking if we needed more to drink and if the food was ok. We were only there for 30 minutes and were asked 5-10 times. Too much customer service becomes annoying but from practically all the employees is way too much.

Nice try but Im not subjecting myself to a possible third time.
author: Andrew B.

description: I love this place. Their samosas are awesome. I'm a big fan of their channa masala. I love that the manager or owner (I'm not sure) comes by and greets tables. Service is wonderful and as someone from the service industry, that goes a long way with me! Highly recommend!
author: Seana H.

description: The Tandoori Game Hen is very tender and smokey. The Basmati Pulao is also smokey. Good place to get dinner with a party of 4. Order and share with the table style. I didn't care for the Chia it was more like watered down burned spice. The different onion, garlic, and wheat nan is very good.
author: Charlene K.

description: Delicious!! A little expensive but worth it! Favs are Chicken Tikka Masala (of course!) and Lamb Korma!
author: Ana D.

description:
Five of us came here on a Wednesday evening for dinner.  We arrived at 6:30 and the restaurant had a few people sitting down to dinner but got much more crowded within the hour.  The service was good - the waiters always seemed to appear just at the right time. We started off with some appetizers - samosas, chicken pakoras, and goat cheese naan - all pretty good

For my entree I ordered the curried mixed vegetables which was somewhat disappointing .  It's advertised as being "seasonal mixed vegetables" but it only consisted of carrots, peas, and cauliflower. The curry sauce was more tomato flavored than curry and wasn't very spicy.  Others had curried lamb, biryani,  curried seafoods which they enjoyed but was covered with the same bland sauce.

There is much better Indian food available in San Francisco so it's doubtful I'll be coming back to Roti
author: Bumble B.

description: Our go-to North Indian restaurant. Bindhi Masala is to die for, but there hasn't been a single item we've ordered that hasn't been delicious.
author: T S.

description:
So...we decided to try an "indian bistro"  (sorry but seeing the word Bistro in its name has made me hesitate often in the past...)  

What did we order? 

Chicken vindaloo (spicy but bland) and it was obvious that the chicken and potatoes had not been cooked together with the sauce...

Saag paneer (I'm not sure I have the right name from this place for it, but it's the curried spinach and cheese dish)...it looked beautiful but it was terribly bland.  I'm not talking about just the sauce but the actual cheese.  I know it's a special type of cheese but it was bland.  

Lamb korma--now, it was our first time trying this sauce, and it was a delicious--slightly sweet, a bit of salt, and a kick to it.  Oh and creamy.  It was good.  Now, the lamb was not as gamey as expected though...

My sister heard about the goat cheese naan, so we tried that... it was good!  

Bottomline: Food = okay.  Try the korma and goatcheese naan but have low expectations for everything else.

Service = friendly.

Decor/ambience = dimly lit, simple tables and chairs/booths.  

Like everyone else has said (over and over): Prices are moderate to high, especially when you compare it to the lack of savoriness of food.  It was food dressed like indian food and add in some heat, but nothing to rave about.   We paid $62.00 + tip for our meal (three entrees, rice and naan.)   

And I had a hard time deciding between 2 or 3 stars...but ultimately, I don't want to mislead people into coming here for 'great representation of indian food by giving it the full 3 stars!)
author: Fannie S.

description:
My wife bought a coupon at livingsocial for Roti and honestly I wasn't expecting much. Trying to get "modern" with a cuisine like Indian is just asking for trouble, imo. Also, I eat a lot of Indian food and unfortunately a lot of the Indian in the Bay Area is mediocre (although some is very good).

Let me just say straight up that I was totally wrong. This place was EXCELLENT.  We had two items from the July specials, a spiced raw mango and tomato dish (simple but excellent and I'd never this dish before) and a chicken dish that was just outstanding; the chicken was nicely spiced and on a bed of lightly grilled vegetables. We then had two of my standards, Bengan Bharta (eggplant) and Bhindi Masala (okra). They were both very good; I think the Bhindi was one of the best I have had.

When I ordered, I asked for it to be spicy, and I think this was key. I noticed that some of the other reviews stated the food was bland; ours was perfectly spiced. Bottom line; ask for spicy and it comes out very nicely spiced.

It's a little on the pricey side for SF Indian ($65 for two beers, an appetizer, and three dishes (OK, not really that expensive now that I think about it)) but the ambiance is very nice and the service was good.

All in all, a surprisingly nice meal!

GP
author: G. P.

description: This is one of my favorite spots on W. Portal.  I always get the chicken tikka masala or the lamb korma.  The food is fresh and the sauces are slightly lighter than other Indian places I've been to.  The staff and owner are always super friendly.  I highly recommend trying it out ; a little on the pricier side, but great for a night out with friends or family.
author: Mary M.

description: This is my favorite Indian restaurant. I love the food. My favorite dish is the tandoori game hen and the garlic and basil naan. The restaurant's owner is very attentive and amiable. You can tell that he values giving his customers the best dining experience possible. The restaurant can be a little noisy but the clamor just adds to the festive environment. They are a bit more expensive than their competitors but the higher price tag is warranted because the good is so yummy!
author: Angela W.

description: The food was excellent, the servers however were extremely rude, they seemed very unhappy. We never got water refills, and when we asked about putting different amounts on only two credit cards, we could overhear our server, C., complain to her coworker who then rolled her eyes and asked if there was another problem. Yikes, did not feel welcome here, not coming back.
author: Julia F.

description: My wife and I love coming here for dinner.  The owner and his son are so welcoming and so willing to adjust dishes to cater to my allergies.  Their food is very authentic to North India and it's worth the drive.  Definitely the best Indian food I've had in SF.
author: Karlito S.

description: Just a quick Friday "date night" dinner for two in search of good Indian food. Space is appealing if a bit crowded.  Service was quick, friendly, and efficient.  Our server knew a great deal about Indian food and helped us manage an otherwise overwhelming menu.  Beer choices are quite limited.  Appetizer sampler was disappointing but entrees and veggie sides delivered.  Flavors are classic and high quality with moderate to generous portions.  Roti is a solid place for Indian food if you are west of Twin Peaks.
author: Jason S.

description: Service is bad.  The food is so so.  I think you should try the other one down the street but they are not that nice.....
author: Joan H.

description:
Having just moved to West Portal, I've been slowly trying all the restaurants in this foggy neighborhood. I recently tried Indian food at Roti and am sorry to report that the food was rather underwhelming. To sum it up briefly, the portions were small, food mediocre, and prices high. 

I ordered the murgh makhani (butter chicken), garlic & basil naan, and a half portion of rice for $25 and felt a bit cheated at the end of the meal: I paid a lot of money for something I didn't particularly enjoy.

First let me review my order of butter chicken. For some reason, the curry here is light in consistency--almost watery. It translates into a lighter taste that unfortunately detracts from the flavor and spice of the curry. The dish was still pleasant enough to eat, but in all honesty, it was a little too bland, especially for curry. It just didn't pack the punch I was looking for. 

Second, the rice. I think this was the worst part of the meal. My rice was mushy and not very good. I'm guessing I got a bad batch because this stuff was horrible and made the whole meal hard to enjoy.

Third, the naan. Fortunately, the naan was good and I was able to finish the curry eating the naan and forgoing the rice. It was charred nicely and had a nice fluffy, buttery taste. A must-order if you eat here, and in general when you order indian food IMO.

I will note that the wait staff and owner were very nice and additionally the overall decor of the restaurant is excellent. I don't think these things are enough to warrant another visit however. I preferred the indian food down the street at clay oven. Although it's not quite as fancy as Roti, the curry and rice taste better there and the prices are more reasonable.
author: Daniel L.

description: Some of the best Indian food. Not overly greasy and you can actually taste the delicious herbs and spices which are home made. We ordered the seafood curry and the Kashmiri Biryani which were delicious. Will definitely return!
author: Yew-Hoe T.

description: I cannot give an accurate review as I don't eat much spicy food. However the flavor of the curry was very rich. I didn't like chicken masala, the flavor was a bit plain and the chicken was really dry.  I don't remember the other chicken but that one was much better. The lamb is very good.  What I really like is the naan, it comes in three flavors and very fresh.
author: Z G.

description:
Great location for dining in or doing lunch. Parking is easy, and the location is easy to find. This is a very upscale looking Indian restaurant; the set up, interior designs, silverware, center piece, etc... are all carefully placed, and organized. The atmosphere is perfect, and Interior designs are superbly done (very classy). The owner/s of this establishment really meant business. Kudos.
  Food is great tasting, I am no Indian food expert, authentic or not, I am not to judge. But every bite into the naan, and every spoonful of spicy lamb curry is just bursting with rich flavor. Spices, spices and more spices, layers and layers of taste will make you repeatedly stick spoonfuls of curry, rice and naan into your mouth until there are nothing left. What more is there to say?

  Side note: you will feel a bit under dressed if you show up in jeans and t-shirt =P
author: Wayne L.

description:
This is like upscale Indian food at its best. Very chic, trendy atmosphere with dim lighting and interesting photography on the walls. Very clean and the service is excellent. The prices are a little higher than your average Indian restaurant, but it's totally worth it. You'll leave the restaurant feeling clean and not in a frantic search for your Purell :)

For our table of five, we got the Mixed Vegetables, Palak Paneer, Achari Gosht, Tandoori Game Hen, the bread basket, and basmati rice. Every single dish was very well made with high quality ingredients. The Achari Gosht was so delicate and moist that I couldn't believe it was lamb! But the game hen, that dish stole the show. OH MY GOODNESS it was flavored so perfectly, a little on the salty side, but that didn't matter because the chicken was so juicy and tender and pretty much amazing. It comes on a plate of arugula with some pistachios sprinkled on top. The vegetarian dishes we had were also delicious. The naan was awesome!

Overall, great experience! Glad we had the livingsocial coupon or else it would have been a bit pricey!

Oh and there's a little bowl of fennel seeds in the front that is traditionally used to freshen your breath after the meal. I'd recommend it only if you're a fan of black licorice! And a little goes a long way.
author: Moraia W.

description:
I love Indian food for having so many (delicious) vegan options. Roti does not disappoint on this front! It's one of the few places I can go to eat with my boyfriend (a carnivore) that both of us leave from, feeling completely satisfied.

They have wonderful naan and their lamb and chicken (according to David) are delicious. As are, of course, all of their veggie dishes that I've tried. 

Also, their service is wonderful. The manager often stops by with complementary yogurt or sauces and just to check how everything is.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I was avoiding Roti because I thought it was too expensive for Indian food I could get somewhere else. Then I woke up to a daily deal from Living Social (which I should opt out of those emails cause they have been really good and my wallet is getting angry) to see a $50 worth of food for $25 deal.   I jumped to the chance because if I can get expensive food for cheaper, I'm there!  

I've always liked the West Portal area.  The restaurants are small and quiet. 9 times out of ten, they're probably really good (in other words; fancy). 

We were seated right away at one of the window tables.  The window bench seats have cushion seating and pillows for added comfort.   The lighting was dim but everything was still pretty visible.  The server was very knowledgable and have good recommendations. I ordered the chicken tikka and my date ordered the lamb vindaloo with garlic basil naan.  

Lemme tell you something.   Their menu is more expensive for a reason...the portions are huge.  I could only eat half of my chicken tikka and my date ate 3/4 of his dish. The meat was moist and flavorful. Those are two things that can be missing in Indian cuisine. The naan was the kicker. I think it was the basil that put it over the top or maybe it was because it was more moist than other naans.  Whatever it was, I'm hooked.   

Even though the prices are more expensive than other Indian restaurants, I think the food here is worth it to come back.  I wouldn't make weekly trips, but monthly sounds wallet-friendly.  Grab that window seat!
author: Lisa X.

description: Great food, great service, and family friendly.  We came with seven people including my eight month old.  Not only did they not mind having a baby in the restaurant but they gave us special attention and even provided extra daal for the baby.  Daal is now my baby's favorite food and we will be coming back often.
author: Ariel B.

description:
The food is great and the service is good with attentive staff.  Awesome food and I have had Indian food, and this is one of the best ones around the Bay Area.
Portion sizes were great for the party of eight that I was in.  We enjoyed all around the food, atmosphere.
author: A M.

description:
Can't comment on the food because it never came! 

We decided to celebrate our 14th year anniversary by trying a new restaurant near our neighborhood. So we checked out Roti.

When we arrived there were only 2 other parties there.  We were starving so we were hoping for fast service. 

After waiting for 10 minutes we placed our order...then we waited.  A few other couples came in and a large group was also seated after us.  

As our stomach was grumbling....we tried to patiently wait....40 minutes passed and still no food. We asked our service and he said it would be right out... Another 10 minutes passed and we decided to leave.

They not only ruined our appetite by serving us water and chips for 50 minutes...but also ruined our anniversary dinner.
author: Cin T.

description: Much disappointment here.  Place looks nice from outside, the inside didn't disappoint, and the staff was plenty friendly and efficient.  Food...hmmm...it was just okay.  Those prices, whoa, talk about pricey!  The veggie biryani was dry, the chicken murgh (other places call it madras) was too sweet, the aloo gobi watery, and the fish tandoori lacking flavor.  Only reason for the three stars is due to the staff.  I'll stick to Masala Dosa, or Guddo de Karahi instead.
author: Joel M.

description: The food was very very good and a little different than most of the places I've been to. Perfectly balanced flavors. Our server was great, very helpful and the staff was attentive. Slightly higher prices but worth it for the quality of the food and will not hesitate to go again.
author: Tod D.

description: Best Indian restaurant I've been to in SF, hands down. The salmon curry and cherry naan were spectacular.
author: David B.

description:
Tikka masala was pretty decent, but their vindaloo was bland and tasteless. Also, this place is not spicy at all for an Indian restaurant.

The basil and garlic naan was pretty good. Wasn't sure if it would work, but it did!

Didn't much enjoy the sauces that came with the calamari, but they did fry it pretty well, so I won't complain too much.

Overall, it was just way too overpriced for what we got.
author: Lady V.

description:
My friend and I were driving around the area, not quite sure where we were but craving indian food when we found this place on yelp.  Upon walking in when were able to order within a few minutes and our food came rather quick.  We had samosas, lamb vindaloo and saag paneer with a side of naan.  All three dishes were delicious.  I'm not from the area but if I found myself around here again I would definitely go back to Roti. 

Even beyond the food it was a good experience, nice decor, comfortable seating and good service.
author: Jessica C.

description: This is well-done Indian food. It has the classics and some unique dishes that aren't "fusion" but rather creative modern Indian cooking. As a Indian American, I have strong opinions about Indian food and Roti is one of only 2 places I'll go for Indian food in the city. The service is also lovely and I love that they give all kids a small mango lassi as soon as they come in. The friendly owner always checks up on us. This place is much better than other reviews would suggest. Maybe you just need familiarity with the cuisine to appreciate it!
author: SF Soccer Mom S.

description:
This review is way overdue! I have been going to Roti bistro twice a month for last year. This is great restaurant with great ambiance, amazing food and neighborhood community feel to it. The food is amazing and i have tried almost every dish on the menu and I would recommend Samosas for appetizer for dinner you can't go wrong with Saag paneer, Saag Chicken, Lamb or anything from tandoor is great. They do have specials every week

Save room for dessert! my favorite is Kulfi and kheer. week. The wine and beer selection is limited but good.
author: Subhash J.

description:
So... a doctor i work for purchased a coupon on livingsocial.  Since she was unable to use it before the expiration date, she gave it to me.  

I took my very non-adventurous boyfriend with me (he was dreading to try indian food).  It was my 2nd or 3rd time trying indian food... it was a first for him.  It helped that this was a little more "upscale" than the previous indian restaurants i've been to.  the decor was pretty and modern.  When you walk through the door you can immediately smell all the yummy goodness coming from the kitchen.

We sat down and looked at the menu.  Feeling a little intimidated i asked our waiter for some suggestions for "rookies".  Johnny was very sweet and patient and pointed us in the right direction.  We dove right into our food and was pleased with EVERYTHING.  Even my non-adventurous boyfriend was already thinking about having this place cater our next party.  

The owner, a sweet timid older gentleman, stopped by to ask us how our meal was.  He explained to us that everything they make is made from local ingredients. even their chicken! he said they get their chickens from petaluma, so their meat is butchered fresh and never frozen.  when we told us that we were practically virgins to indian cuisine, he would go to the kitchen and bring out "samples" of things to try.  OMG by the time we left we were so stuffed we couldn't breathe! 

This is by far one of the best restaurants i've been to in a long time.  I would HIGHLY recommend this place, even for those non-adventurous types......
author: Monette P.

description:
I like this place, but I have to say I think it's overpriced for what it is. The tandoori anything is good, that includes the chicken tandoori and the mixed tandoori plate. But again, overpriced. The plain naan at $4 a pop, and other filled breads at $6-8 each seems like a steep price considering many places in the city give you that for a buck or two. I would prefer smaller but cheaper portions of the bread, or a sampler of breads at a more affordable price. Or how about a naan freebie? It's basically your bread basket.

None of the entrees comes with rice, meaning you also have to order a plate of rice at $5-10 a plate, so all these sides and it starts to add up quite a bit.
The service was fine, in fact they seem to have one too many waiters and somebody is always hovering about you. But that is preferable to not enough or inattentive staff.
The decor is warm but not overdone, kind of indian-contemporary.
The wine pours are pretty skimpy.
In a word: Good food, you'll pay extra for the sides, overpriced for what it is. 
Also: Avoid the pickle, I found it nasty and rank. Maybe it's an acquired taste.
author: John S.

description: They have great food. So far one of best in SF. It's a bit pricey for the service you get. I'd come back more often if price is a bit more affordable. Also it would be nice to have three curry combo etc so that I can try many things.
author: Ryosuke K.

description: Excellent food. Lots of gluten free options including a calamari dish that is crazy good. Friendly service, great atmosphere.
author: Sharon B.

description: One of the best! Went to Roti with friends last night..an easy muni trip...fun to get out of the city and into a more chill neighborhood. The food was amazing..We all shared many dishes including lamb, game hen, duck etc...the goat cheese naan was amazing. Highly recommend. Service was terrific. The owner is a great guy too.
author: Doug V.

description:
Came here for dinner and although the service was excellent, the food was no where near as good as I remembered it being from several years ago.  It may be due to the fact that I've eaten Indian food in many of the places I've traveled to including London since the last time I ate at Roti Indian Bistro, but I think that it's mostly because the food just is not great Indian food.
