Very Americanized Indian food. Definitely not authentic but I would recommend it as a beginner's Indian food restaurant. Service is par. Chai tastes like it comes from Starbucks. Ambiance is awesome. And the music choice is terrible. No bistro or Indian restaurant would play
Techno. For more authentic, maybe try Masala on 9th and Lincoln. It's my fav still. San Francisco best is still likely Shalomar. Bon appetite.
author: Eugenel E.

description: A great place to catch some good North Indian cuisine. The Aloo Paratha was great. The place isn't too expensive either. The best part is that it is open late upto 10:30 PM, unlike most places in SF which close by 9 - 9:30 PM.
author: Varrun R.

description:
By far, my favorite India restaurant is Tikka Masala on Judah--no fuss, cheap, nearby--great takeout.

But when I'm looking for something a little fancier for a dinner out, I head to Roti. The interior is chic with an exotic flair and the service is better than, say, Naan 'n Curry (that's right!).

I'm not really an Indian curry aficionado, but if the naan is warm and soft upon serving and the curry has that tumeric/masala spiciness, I'm a fan. Can't really complain about Roti's food!
author: Kym M.

description: Service was very good, food was delicious, but it was a little bit on the pricey side. You have to try the goat cheese naan, it's absolutely scrumptious :)
author: Anna K.

description: The food at Roti is excellent.  If it weren't for the horrible service, I would give it 4 or 5 stars.  My wife loves this restaurant, but we can only go on the weekends and that is the worst time to go.  They have a little room in the back that most guests don't know about.  In that room, which seats 40 people, they host private parties and little Indian groups.  Unfortunately, they do not increase their wait staff to cover the load.  Last night we waited 15 minutes before I had to beg the host to send a waiter over to take our order.  It took 55 minutes to get our food.  Of course, they tried to sell us more wine.  It is really offensive and greedy on the part of the owner of the restaurant.  My wife may return for lunch, but I will not patronize this place.
author: Ralph B.

description: I was so impressed with tonight's dinner. My husband and I took our daughter, age 12, to her first Indian meal.  She really liked all the mild foods we ate, and the nice proprietor brought over some raita to go with the delicious biryani.  The service was excellent.  Terrific all around!
author: Sarah S.

description: This was my first time dining in an Indian restaurant and what an experience it was!  As soon as the waitress and manager heard that I had never before had Indian food, they brought over 3 additional items for us to try.  They are truly proud of their food and were so happy for us to try it.  Some of the highlights were the goat cheese naan, mango chutney, boti kabab and tandoori murgh.  Amazing service and delicious food.  I will definitely be back soon.
author: EVELYNE E.

description: Awesome Indian food. Good for dinnertime. The setting is cozy and comforting. Good for family.
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
Good Indian food is hard to find in the city. I am writing this review after going to Roti a few times...
Both times I have a had a great experience..reminded me of my mom's cooking.  It is pretty pricey but you can BYOB for only a $15 corkage fee.

My favorite dishes:

Seekh Kabob
Jackfruit biryani
Roti
Chicken Tikka Masala
Paneer Kofta

Ambiance is great, staff is friendly, location is clean. Great date spot.  Food is nice and flavorful.  I definitely like this place better than Clay Oven, Maharani, New Delhi, Chaat Cafe, Pakwan, and Chutneys.  

Mango lassi is pretty damn good too:)
author: N S.

description:
Roti is our "go to" fancy Indian, although with the steep prices, we don't go often.  The food is delicious and the ambiance is very nice for a  "date night."  We often do take out as well for large family meals.

As many have noted, this once "King of Indian food" has gotten emptier over time, and the service is largely to blame.  It's the classic restaurant mistake you see all over SF -- a place gets wildly popular and then starts cutting corners in service and food...I hope the owners read yelp and act accordingly.  It would be so sad to see it go out of business, but if changes aren't made, we fear that's what could happen.

It's still very good and a nice outing.  We recommend it if you have a full wallet and lots of time for a lengthy albeit flavorful meal.
author: Anne B.

description:
It's good, but I hate to admit that the Burlingame location is a tad bit better.  The chicken tikka masala was a little more watery than the B-game location and it had a more tandoor/smoked taste to the tikka masala sauce.  The spinach with lentils was also good, but somehow the B-game location has more "omphf" to it. 

I do like how they give generous pours of wine.

Service was good. 

But I might just drive another 15 min and go to the B-game location...
author: Natalie S.

description: I had much better indian food.... my first time having indian food was when i visited the uk, the best place for pakistani indian food, so maybe i kept comparing? I'm still yet to find an indian restaurant that hit the spot
author: Cliff T.

description:
This place is definitely a gem so I eat here whenever I get the chance.  The food is great, the service is lovely, and the atmosphere is nice.  I am a huge fan of anything tandoori, the seafood, and their goat cheese naan.  So yummy.  

This isn't an inexpensive Indian restaurant but the food quality and atmosphere is much better than those inexpensive places, and the food quality and portion sizes are much better than Amber India.  It's also a place where they really care about your dining experience.  The owner is often working in the restaurant and he comes by to check on you to make sure everything is going well.
author: Cantik E.

description:
Ok they really deserve 3.5 stars, but hey, what can I say?...I'm generous.

Food was good, but kind of cold.  I like hot food, well, Hot.  I think if they serve in hot plates, that may actually solve most of the problems.  I love the naan.  

Ambiance was very pleasing to the eyes.  I felt relaxed and comfortable.  

Service was decent.

Parking is hit or miss depending on the day and what the nearby theater is playing that day.
author: Vanna S.

description:
Probably the best Korma I've ever had:  lamb so tender, great sauce with a rich, nutty flavor.  Good naan.  There are several "samplers" across the menu if you're having a hard time choosing just one.  The food here has the subtly richness of good Indian food--you can taste each of the different spices and herbs.  They also serve nimbu pani (Indian limeade with salt and pepper--really refreshing) and an amazing gulab jamun.

The owner and his family were attentive and checked with each table personally.  Waitstaff was attentive, friendly and very helpful.  This is a nice restaurant, that serves an excellent Indian meal that comes from the heart.

Not obvious, but apparently there's a back room, where a 12-or-so party of birthday revellers were spilling out.
author: Steve K.

description:
My two biggest problems with Indian restaurants are:
1) My wife can usual make better food
2)Restaurant food is greasy

Neither is true at Roti (don't tell my wife).   Well, it's not so much that they are better cooks than my wife, it's just that Roti does things a little different.   Restaurant quality food should be better than standard home-cooked food.  It is supposedly cooked by real chefs who cook food for a living.   This is the case at Roti where the execution is nearly flawless, the visible oil is minimal and the food is fresh and unique.   Very Good!!!!
author: Ranjit M.

description:
A classy Indian joint on West Portal? That's cool, the ambiance beats the hell out of Shalimar in the Tender Nob. Roti has beautifully presented Indian food and a pretty extensive wine list. The servers are professional and efficient as well. 

I recently heard something on the radio about how the servers can increase their tips by doing several things like crouching next to the tables, repeating the order back to the customer and touching the customer. Our server did all those things. I don't like being touched. OK, let me amend that statement. I DO like being touched but only in a Michael Jackson kind of way, (can I have more Jesus juice, Michael?) when it's done by a complete stranger it kind of bugs me.

It can also get pretty loud in there. It was so loud the night I went the woman sitting at the next table had to practically yell the details of her sexual escapade with a man she thought was gay.

See...CLASSY!!
author: Josua P.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian Indian!
I dont know how the other food is, but all the vegetarian food we ordered was tasteless and oily. All we could taste was the raw chopped green chillies added last minute, since we asked for spicy food.
The only good thing was the goat cheese naan as an appetizer.

The paneer jalfrezi, part from being oily and the worst ever, actually had lettuce in it. Since when did people start "cooking" lettuce, and especially in Indian cuisine?! This is the first time Ive ever had lettuce in a vegetable gravy dish. I could make better paneer at home. The naans/rotis/parathas were huuuge and super oily. 

I think the chefs may have changed recently, Ive eaten here ebfore, and at their Burlingame restaurant as well, and it was much better. The food was so bad, that we didn't even want to box it up!

Apart from this, great service and staff.
author: Soniya R.

description:
When I was in kindergarten, my teacher Mrs. Turley would tell us to sit "Indian Style" on the big rug.  I had no idea what this had to do with Indians, but we all knew what to do.

I think of Roti as "Indian Style" food.   Although they do serve many authentic dishes, you're not going to think for a second that you are in Bombay.  If you prefer to sweat out mouth-burning spices while listening to high octave singing, this is not the place for you.  If you're ok with variations on a theme, you will probably be OK with Roti.

Example:  Roti Calamari.  It's pretty good, with an Indian spice aftertaste.

The Chicken Tikka Masala is good, as are the other familiar dishes - Chicken Korma, Palak Paneer.  I had a very tasty special chicken dish the other night which had a lovely green sauce and light flavor.  Look for it on the October specials menu.

Service is very friendly.  We were offered a complimentary glass of wine or port for no reason other than it was Halloween night.  

Not my first choice for Indian food, but a nice neighborhood restaurant.
author: Liz S.

description:
Ok, so I love Indian food and I love little hole in the wall places to find them because those always seem to be the hidden gems. But this place is far from being a hole in the wall or a hidden gem, but a well known diamond. Decor was contemporary and stylish, dim lighting but, comfortable atmosphere. It was pretty empty walking in but, about 20 minutes later the place was packed. Tandori and Goat Rice Dish was to die for and the Naan couldnt be any fresher. When you get your dishes you tend to think, what small portions but, it is very filling. The flavors from the dishes in front of you and the aroma from the dishes next to you makes you want to order one of everything thing on the menu. 

The only thing i wished was that they had given me a big basket of Naan!
author: Trisha C.

description: This place is pricey but soooo good! The service is amazing, and the ambiance is perfect for a date with your lover or with good friends. The food is really delicious. What a wonderful find.
author: Christine S.

description:
I knew nothing about this place. I knew nothing about indian food. I still know nothing about indian food. 

All I know is that Gulab Jamun will make your life worth living. 

I'll be back Roti, I'll be back.
author: Slasha S.

description:
I rolled out of Roti full, sassy and feeling like that extremely fat man from Monty Python who kept refusing the 'wafer thin mint'.  Just let me curl up in the corner and digest, dammit.

I came with friends and we tend to treat every meal, regardless of cuisine, as a 'family style' experience.  Why have one dish when you can have tastes of several?  So, armed with the menus and a decision to forgo any tandoori dishes (don't ask), we proceeded to create our own digestive doom.  Naan, this amazing masala, more curry than you can possibly imagine, raita, kulcha, vindaloo - we laid siege to the various menu options and emerged victorious.  We even had a lovely Riesling that complemented the meal.  But it was a Pyrrhic victory...I'm not sure how we managed to move once the evening was over.  

One jarring note, and the reason for the reduction in stars - it was WAY too loud.  Not just the obnoxious large group at the rear of the (not very big) restaurant, the noise level here rises to uncomfortable levels.  Even when the loud birthday group left we found it to be too loud for effortless conversation. 

On the plus side:
Great decor - classy and subtle with wonderful color combos.
Very nice service - our waiter was especially helpful with specials and recommendations
author: Suzanne B.

description:
most restaurants on West Portal seem to be excellent. This one is no different. 
I love how this restaurant is decorated. Unlike other indian restaurants. the style leans more towards sheik and sophisticated. The service is great and the food usually comes out in a timely fashion. 
I would recommend getting the vegetable Samosas as an appetizer. They are great and something i don't seem to find at every indian restaurant. I also love the chicken tikka masala... but i always love that. 
Go here for a good meal. Good ambiance. And enjoy a different part of the city than the norm.
author: Wes P.

description: Awesome service, very beautiful setting, the owner is very nice and visible in the dining area. First time here And will definitely be back!
author: Anthony H.

description:
I declare this place "Another 5 star Indian restaurant in San Francisco!"

Food: Incredibly delicious
Ambiance: A bit loud, but decorated with warm colors and interesting photographs
Service: Incredibly friendly. 

A friend at work mentioned she'd eaten at the Burlingame establishment and said it was very good.  So, we decided to give it a try on Saturday night.

I called at about 7:00 and was told to come in around 8:00 and they'd be able to seat us then.  We got their at 7:45, were greeted by a very friendly hostess, and seated immediately.

Our waiter was incredibly informative and helped us with our selection (samosas, rosemary naan, rice, navrataan koorma, and the daily special: tandoori grilled vegetables coated in a spicy Indian sauce). 

The samosas were spiced perfectly, a great size, and very tasty.  And the tamarind sauce is definitely the best tamarind sauce I've ever had. I usually just taste the tamarind sauce, and then dress up the samosas with the mint chutney the restaurants typically provide.  This time, I became instantly enamored of the sweet, sour, delectibilty of Roti Bistro's tamarind sauce and couldn't get enough of it. 

Whenever I try a new Indian restaurant, I always first take a bite of the rice to see how it stands alone.  If it's boring, then one must hope the curry will be outstanding and overshadow it.  The rice here was divine. Colorful and tasty, I could have eaten it plain and been happy. 

The daily special consisted of fruits and vegetables battered and placed in the tandoori oven.  It was divine.  I loved eating spicy mangoes and pineapples alongside more traditional veggies like broccoli, onions, red peppers, etc... 

And the Navrataan Koorma was out of this world, and a perfect pair for the more spicy daily special.  Subtle, creamy, complex and completely sublime, this dish also included sweet fruits (pineapple and raisins) alongside paneer, peas, and other traditional veggies. 

And if you judge a restaurant by the patrons, you can tell this is a winning establishment.  Everyone seemed really, really happy.  Customers, waitstaff, cooks, and patrons. 

Just a fantastic place... we will be back many times, no doubt.
author: Tahd F.

description:
Ok, what is the scoop? Have you all been keeping this place a secret or what? How is it that I have lived in this city for 7.5 years and have not ever heard or been to Roti until last night?

One word - LOVE. We absolutely loved everything we got. We ordered the Roti's lamb "popsicles", Chicken Tikka Masala, onion kulcha, mango chutney, basmati pulao and Taj Mahal beer. Everything was fantastic. 

Atmosphere and host were warm and inviting; service was friendly and fast. Prices great. AND it is located right off a MUNI stop. Getting there was a piece of cake. 

I have found one of my new favorite spots in the city!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Roti in West Portal is an attempt at upscale neighborhood Indian. The only thing upscale was the price. The food, although not terrible, did not meet the standards of Naan and Curry, Pakwan or Lahore Karahi, not to mention Dosa, a legit upscale Indian. When we asked for spicy, we ended up with an artifical tasting spice rather than a balanced approach. Understanding how to "build spice" into a dish is mandatory for Indian cuisine and all I found was caked on spice. Add a bit more spice paste and that'll show em'. 
On a positive note, our server was excellent and the service in general was above average. Overall, if you are looking for a "western" version of Indian, you might be happy with Roti. Otherwise, I'd recommend Dosa or Pakwan, Lahore Karahi, or India Oven.
author: Phil M.

description:
Uh.... I like Naan and Curry more than this place. 

Their Naan is not fluffy at all. They look like grilled tortillas. They're garlic naan tasted like regular naan with a little grittiness to it. 

Had the prawn vindaloo and chicken jalfresi? I think that's how you spell it. 

Tasted like... chinese food. Like lamp chinese food. Maybe we ordered the wrong things? I don't know. But if you can't get the basic naan right? I don't want to talk to you. 

Their Mango lassi was good though, but how can you really screw that up? It's just yogurt with mango juice. Really now, how can you charge 6 bucks for that?

I really wanted to like this place but alas, no. 

Our waiter was interesting as well, he kept saying "light sauce" and "cream sauce" while swirling his "o-k" formed hand in a circle.

WEIRD.. and not impressive.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
I haven't been here in about 9 months and I just confirmed I won't be back for another 9 months if ever.  Here lies the problem of ordering take out from this place.  About 9 months ago I order some take out, very simple an order of the fish and a veggie dish, when they tell you 1 hour, it's actually 1 1/2 hours.  As for today, I order food around 5:10 and got there about 5:45, they told me 30 minutes.  I left after 6:30 with my order.  

There were a few more people who waited unhappily for their take out.  

I was offered a free dish for the wait.  I thought about for all of half a second, I didn't want to be stuck there waiting for another 30 minutes for a free dish.  Hell No.  I opt to take my food and leave.

The naan I brought home wasn't fully cook and had a doughy taste. as was the aloo gobi (the cauliflower is completely crisp as if only just dumped into the curry and pulled out).  I will never order the assorted appetizers ever again, that was horrible.  The vegetable pakoras were a bit on the burnt side and wasn't even close to being authentic in any way .  I'm seriously disappointed today with the food tonight.  The tandoori murgh was very spicy (which I like but my daughter couldn't eat) was the only dish that was decent.  

I've never had problems with the food when I eat there, but take out is a nightmare.
author: Twist' D.

description:
Didn't actually try the food BECAUSE I was told " Oh, you don't need a reservation ", but when I got there (about 5 minutes later)......................
I was turned away because they were too busy. I spoke to a friend of mine who had similar service issues. 
I would like to give this place another chance but I would be getting it "to go".
author: Ivy C.

description:
Being a fan of Naan And Curry you're going to tell me that I don't know good Indian.  That may be true.  I won't deny it how do I know what is authentic or good?  I do however know what my tummy likes, and it loves this place.

It's like eating Naan and Curry in a very nice grown up atmosphere, without the # on the table, and waiting in line to order and pay.  It's the same type of dishes, but made with probably real authentic seasonings from India, versus Naan and Curry's bulk purchased ones.  (which I do love).  Also the food is modernized and Americanized enough so that if you are a scaredy cat of new things, one could bring you here to try and ease you into Indian dining.  The food is alot nicer and more elegant and authentic than say Naan and Curry, but that does not mean that either one of them doesn't make me happy just the same.  

Oh and for lunch, they have a $10 or $11 special that is a steal!  

YUMMMMMY.
author: Denise B.

description:
Enjoyed everything about Roti. 

Love its West Portal location - low-key and easy to park. The ambiance is warm, dishes deliciously flavorful, pricing reasonable for both food and wine. Service is good, unobtrusive.

Definitely an easy spot to return to ;)
author: Kimbalee W.

description:
-1 star for "organic" claims without the goods to back it up (ie: conventional factory farmed meats/cheese and overly fishy farm raised fish). 

-1 star for burnt dry tortilla like naan. 

-1 star for general inconsistency of food taste and quality. 

-1 star for horrible acoustics and overcrowded atmosphere.

-1 star for exorbitantly high prices not justified by portion size/quality standards of the food. 

-1 star for horribly rude owners with no concept of customer service. 

alas... 1 star is the lowest score i can post. oh well. 1 star.
author: Blythe H.

description:
:::THE GOOD:::
Flavors were good

:::THE LAME:::
No Indian people eating here... bad sign.
The price!  $20 for a curry!?!?!?  Uhh... hello???
Garlic Nan was flat as a pancake and not very tasty.

:::GENERAL:::
Why would I ever eat here again?  Can't think of a good reason.  How I miss London for the killer Indian food experiences!
author: Dan M.

description:
Fellow West of Twin Peakers get down on their knees and kiss Roti's doormat, if for nothing else other than simply helping to raise the bar for dining standards a touch on West Portal.  I mean you can only go to El Torreador so many times, and Cafe For All Seasons is still serving the same food in the same way it always has, which is fine if you like your routine and still feel your mullet to be a contemporary fashion statement, thank you very much.

But that said, Roti is nothing to get all that excited about.  The decor is nice enough, with a loud, jovial atmosphere.  I'm not sure about the staff turnover here, but we've had different waiters on each of our several visits.  On one visit, the entire waitstaff completely disappeared for about 5 minutes, right after my wife's Saag Paneer hit the table, but still waiting for my Jheenga Masala, which arrived 5 minutes later, and 5 minutes cooler.

Once the food does arrive, there are often fatal flaws that owe not to fundamental errors in the ingredients or recipes, but simply sloppy preparation.  How hard is it to cook fish to some point short of vulcanization?  And while smoking may be banned in the dining room, I'm pretty sure the guy making decisions on how much salt to put in the food must be doing so between puffs, because our Fish Korma tasted like it came straight from Mono Lake.

I do so want to like this place, and may even try it again at some point.  But my expectations are diminished, and I'm not kissing the doormat any longer.
author: Hugh B.

description:
Used to live in the inner sunset and would get India Clay Oven delivery. Then we moved to Bernal and ordered from their sister restaurant India Garden. Many times in a row, they'd deliver the wrong chicken - we always ordered Chicken Makhani (and Veggie Korma) and they'd bring Tikka Masala. They'd try to convince us it was ok, they were the same. They were hit or miss - and the last few times our faves were lumpy and oddly colored.

Tonight we discovered Roti and it was delicious. The phone at Aslam's Rasoi just rang and rang and I gave up after many tries - it would have been our first time there too. 

We got the Chicken Makhani and the Veggie Korma. Both were so tasty and creamy - smoothly spiced. The onion kulcha was loaded with soft onions and the bread was perfectly oily instead of too thick and dry like many other places. The goat cheese nan was pretty good. Samosas - great. And the chutneys - I have never had such a creamy (mint &?) cilantro chutney. What else can I use to scoop that up with?

The only negative is that its a little pricey. And we don't have as much left over as we usually do which is unfortunate for tomorrow...but it is worth it and we'll be back.
author: Kristi M.

description:
The most expensive Indian Food in San Francisco, perhaps on the entire West Coast. The curry entrees run about $16-$17, but that does not include rice, which was an extra $4 or so. The Naan bread was $4. I went there on my own and dropped nearly $40, including the tip. Ouch.
The food is not any better than the Indian food favorites, such as Bombay Indian or Pakwan. If price is a factor, skip it. Also, the service is sketchy. You will likely be ignored for long periods. I walked out the last time I was there, 15 minutes went by and my waiter never even looked at me
author: Stefan Y.

description:
Long waits!! At a restaurant on West Portal!! Grab me my skates because hell has frozen over!

A beautifully appointed interior puts the old Sabella's to shame. The service is five-star, and the food is perceptibly good quality. The lamb kabob and Murgh Masala are good, and I dig the wheat bread! (Get the Bread Basket for a tasty variety.) I don't love their tikka masala, but there are so many other things on the menu, you should probably take a break from that one anyway. Chai is a little expensive, but the price is part of this place's image, I think. 

Service is very professional; almost comically so for the neighborhood.
author: Megan W.

description:
I was starving tonight, but not in the mood for the same old-same old that we've let ourselves fall into.  So, based on Ranjit's review (above or below mine...it keeps moving, ha!)  we headed to Roti.

I may not have ever been to India, but I have eaten Indian food all over the world...this is by far one of the best places I've eaten.

I ordered way too much food (for two people, I ordered 2 sides, one bread, and the variety/sampler entree, plus a rice dish, and we ate until we couldn't breathe any more and then brought the other half home!

The service is outstanding! Courteous, knowledgable, attentive waitstaff.  I only wish this place were a tiny bit cheaper, as we blew 90 bucks with tip and one drink each (nothing fancy, a beer!)  

Still, very well worth it!
author: Lisa B.

description:
If you like flavorful, spicy indian food--you know, the authentic, good kind--then avoid Roti. Everything is watered down, including the personalities of the wait-staff. If you are a local yuppie who loves paying too much to feel 'cultured' then this is the place for you.
Check out Dosa.
author: Meg I.

description:
My review will sound like many that came before me....Roti has tasty cuisine, but I'm a little irritated about having to pay $3 extra for rice. Come on, it's practically the cheapest food on the planet - slap some on my plate to soak up that lovely curry sauce!!!

Beyond that, the food here was great. I had the Navrattan Korma (at the suggestion of another Yelper) and all I can say is WOW. So tasty, and just the right amount of spice. We  made the mistake of ordering the bread basket (an assortment of naan breads) for only two people; I wish the server would have told us that is WAY more naan than any two people can possibly eat. But hey, at least we have leftovers for tomorrow. And I WAS pleasantly surprised to receive a little (free) plate of papadum as an appetizer and a complimentary mango lassie at the end of our meal. I don't know if this is something they do regularly....but cheap bitch that I am, I gladly accepted these gifts!

Finally, I  echo the previous poster who suggests calling the restaurant for a table instead of reserving online. The online system said we couldn't get in until 8:30; however, a phone call revealed that a 6:15 table was available. I'll definitely be back to Roti...I live in the area and I think it's a pretty cool joint.

EDIT 8/18/07:
What's up with the pushy wait staff who try to get you to order things you don't really need??? The portions here are huge, so beware -- if your waiter/tress "suggests" adding another appetizer or order of rice for the table, just say no. It will be way, way too much food (and way, way too much money out of your pocket and into theirs).
author: Beth T.

description:
Roti was the most expensive southern indian restaurant I went to by far. For three people, we spend over $70 in food. However, I found some food and service was not up to par. 

I would give a two star because: 

1) The Chicken Tikki Masala is like the "basics" for indian cuisine but it was not as tasty as some other reviews were talking about! The meat was not cooked like other places and it taste like the dry salad chicken meat... For the price tag, I was expecting much more from the sauce and unfortunately it was not as tasty as I would like it to be. The food was served in white plate that cools down quite fast. 

2) Service was bad. Maybe they don't welcome "non-white" people going for their business? I requested to have my table wiped because there were a lot of crumbs from the samosas... The waitress who picked up the plate pointed that to another person, went back to the cashier area and talked to another person pointing at our table. This simple task was not done and it was very unpleasant for me to continue my meal at that point on. 

I did not receive enough attention and the staff felt lazy and unhappy. My concern from a business stand point was: There were many staff in this restaurant and some of them didn't look like they were busy compare to the number of tables. If the manager in this business was nice enough not to cut jobs at this low economy, shouldn't the staff play out their effort in rewarding the manager's kindness? 


However, I decided to give a third star because: 

1) The Roti mixed Tandoori was very good. The portion for salmon probably worth half of the price for this dish. It was cooked perfectly and not over cooked at all. There was also a small piece of chicken that tasted much better than the one in Tikki Masala. The beef was also small piece and it was cooked 80% which I liked it that way. The lamb was made into a sausage and had a very strong smell with it. If you don't like your lamb to be smelly, this dish might not be an option for you. 

2) The samosas was also excellent. The crust was so crispy and it was one of the better samosas I tried. I would rather it has three smaller piece than two big ones because I enjoyed the outside more than the fillings. I also wish that there can be other options for samosas but I only see one from the menu.
author: Angel K.

description:
I've been to Roti on multiple occasions and I've always had a great experience.  Sure, Naan and Curry is cheaper and the quality of food is about the same (although still not quite as good), but you go to a restaurant like Roti when you want the atmosphere of a nice restaurant and you're not in the mood to serve yourself.  

My boyfriend and I came in after a movie, and less than half the tables were filled, so we were able to sit down right away.  Yippie.  Our food came out no more than 5 minutes after we ordered, and it was just as good as always.  I love their menu.  Tons of choices, and I have yet to be disappointed.

What was with the service?  First off, when we walk in, the hostess barely looks at us and asks (in an I don't give a damn kind of way): "Alright so where do you wanna sit?"  No big deal.  Then later on when someone else came in and asked if they were still open, she goes, "Um...  Yeah."  I seriously had to hold back my laughter.  Not like it was an HOUR before closing time or anything.  I think our server hated his life.  No smile, didn't look up from his writing pad, didn't ask if we wanted anything to drink besides water, didn't ask if we wanted dessert before dropping off the check.  No wait.  I think he did smile.  It was when a friend of his opened the front door and yelled his name across the entire restaurant.  Now that's what I call professional.  Roti, you're letting yourself be represented that way?  I know you can do better...  I've seen it.

Honestly, it takes a lot to actually bother me when it comes to service.  I've done the whole serving thing, so I totally understand when mistakes are made or food takes forever blah blah blah.  I didn't leave Roti feeling bothered or offended or anything, but I did feel really surprised to see such a blatantly unprofessional staff in such a good restaurant.  It's little restaurants like Roti where you find servers who suggest you try new things, who can recommend a glass of wine that pairs perfectly with the lamb vindaloo, and who get excited when you ask what their favorite dish is.  But hell...  the guy didn't even want us to order a stupid dessert.

I'll go back.  I'm close, and good food = good food.  However, as far as providing the ultimate dining experience goes, Roti is slipping.
author: Jen P.

description:
This place is exceptional!!!!
I love hole in the wall indian places, but sometimes its wonderful to go to a fancy indian restaurant like this one. Lots of wine choices. And the food - top notch. Their ability to delicately use spices made my mouth simmer. I got their vegetarian platter for dinner and had their delicious rice pudding with cardamom for dessert  (included). I reccomend their eggplant.
author: Sari G.

description:
The food here was pretty good but definitely overpriced.  Its called "Bistro" so you can't expect it to taste too authentic.  And also adding bistro to the name adds a few bucks to the prices.

I went with a bunch of Indian dudes from work and they seemed to enjoy it so it can't be too bad.  But of course the boss was paying and we had lots of beers so that probably helped in the enjoyment department.
author: Bryan K.

description: LOVE this place! I go as often as I can and the food is delicious! The owner is so nice and always makes everyone feel so comfortable. All the people that gave a bad review for this place must just be unhappy people that want to complain about something because I have been here a hundred times and it's great!
author: L. S.

description:
I went to dinner here last night and it was great!  The hostess was so charming and friendly.  The second we stepped in the door, I felt so welcome and her greeting really got the evening off on a positive note.  The interior of the restaurant consisted of warm tones (browns, oranges, etc.) and dark wooden tables.  There are also several couch- like booths as well.  I liked the photography on the walls.  

We started off with the secunjawl ($3) which is Indian-style lemonade.  It was very, very sweet.  I had a glass of the Gewurztraminer Chateau St. Mary's ($3) which was very sweet as well, but I like sweet wines.  The pour was quite generous.

For the entrees, we ordered the Chicken Korma and Chicken Tikka Masala (both $13) and Navrattan Korma because I had heard such good things about it from other Yelp reviews.  We also got 2 orders each of rice and plain naan ($3 per order).  The Chicken Korma was delicious!  It was very creamy and buttery.  It had a mild flavor and was a very simple dish.  The Tikka Masala had more spice to it and was good as well.  I was excited to try the Navrattan Korma and I liked it a lot.  There were plenty of vegetables and fruits in it and the flavor was on the sweet side.  I felt all three curries were great.  The naan hot fresh and chewy, which I like.  I felt the rice and naan portions were more than enough for two people.  I think next time, I would just get one naan and one rice for two people.  

I know that at cheaper hole-in-the-wall places you could have gotten our entire meal for a fraction of the price, but you are paying for the ambiance and the fact that it's a nice sit down place.  The waitstaff is great and we received good service.  I think Roti is a nice place for a date as well as group dinners so you can try lots of different dishes.  I would recommend making reservations.  The neighborhood is really cute (lots of cafes, shops, and restaurants) and is easily accessible by Muni (West Portal station is just a block away).  Overall, I recommend this place and look forward to coming back!
author: Karen K.

description:
Had dinner the other night.
The Chicken Tikka was nice and moist. The Chicken Tikka Masala kind of lost it's punch and the Palak Paneer actually came out warm, with the middle of the cheese almost cold. That was sent back.
I'm not sure what the protocol is but we were told it was put back in a pot to warm back up. I'm hoping it was not a communal pot for hygeine sake. I've been here at least three times and it seems the spices have been toned down a bit. The prices are also a bit steep for the portion that you receive. I did not mind when the food was good, but now that it tastes slightly "bland" I am starting to notice the higher prices...
author: Kat T.

description:
Ok. I went back again. It was much much better. I'm pretty much back to my normal adoration of this restaurant.

The food: Fantastic as ever. (see my first review for extensive gushing)
The decor: Always lovely - as long as you don't sit behind the host stand.
The service: Pretty good! Not five star - but MUCH better than last time. 

It takes a while to win be back over after a bad experience. But I've been back twice since... And trips were either very good or exceptional. So they're back in my good graces, and a smile is creeping back onto my face. Let's keep it that way!
author: Mindy L.

description:
I have been to Roti nearly a hundred times and it is a solid 3-star place. I think the ambiance and decor of it are some of it's greatest assets since it's the perfect place to bring someone. 

That being said, I find the food only okay (an exception is the Goat Cheese Naan which is de-li-cious!) especially for how much you pay for it. The portions are rather small and the flavors a bit muted. I find for the same or less price, you can go down the street and enjoy a much finer meal at Clay Oven.  

Over the years I've seen the popularity of the place decline and can only hope that the recipes get a little tweaked so bring Roti back to it's former glory.
author: Maria C.

description:
Enjoy the traditional Indian food in a fancy setting. 
This is a perfect concept for the modern day and age. 
I took my best friend for her birthday and we enjoyed it. 
The restaurant is very romantic with nice lighting. Also with laid back ambiance. 
There are nice sofa seats by the window if you make the reservation. 

I thought the flavor would be adjusted for American taste bud, but they kept it nice and traditional. Lots of flavorful Indian spices. 
They keep the price decent also. 
Staffs are all very friendly and professional.
Nice family or couple dinner.
author: Mai K.

description:
I've eaten here about 5x and this place scores big points for fresh tasting dishes and nice decor.  I recommend Sag Paneer, Benghan Bharta and Mixed Tandori Plate.  Unfortunately the acoustics are poor and it is very noisy - we've had better luck dining after 9pm when the dinner rush quiets down and it is easier to hold a conversation without shouting.   Dishes  have lost some of their authenticity/taste which I think is due to the fact that they don't want to turn people away who are not accustomed to Indian food.

Edit:  1/6/06 - Have tried to go back many a time but there is always a  long wait now....and they do not take reservations.
author: Michelle M.

description:
So we decided to give Roti a shot since not one person out of the group had ever been there. My friend Karen's friend who happens to be Indian said that this place is La Bomba. If a restaurant is endorsed by a native countryman, it's got to have some merit right?

My friend and I walked in to meet aforementioned friend Karen in our sweats since we just finished up rockclimbing at Mission Cliffs. We immediately regretted the decision to not change out of our damp, frumpy sweats. I'm the Naan n Curry/Indian Clay Oven variety of Indian food enthusiast, so i was quite surprised by how chi-chi this place was. Not a trace of the ethnic Indian vibe you come to expect. And West Portal is a little neighborhood village, so i was definitely not expecting something so polished and swanky. 

It's 8pm. I'm starving. I look at the menu. Everything looks so good. But oh, the price. That doesn't look so good. It was definitely more expensive than i expected. I'm not a cheap person. Don't let my chinese exterior deceive you. I LOVE good food. Call me a glutton. You pay for what you get right? I'll pay for good food. But a $16 Prawn Vindaloo dish? It better be damn good! When we got our luxury dish, i was very disappointed to see that we had a total of 7 shrimp. And they called them PRAWNS. They are obese shrimp at best. Not Prawns. Definitely not prawns. The Chicken Tikka Masala does get 5 Stars for flavor and texture. It was definitely juicier than most other ones i've had. We also ordered a Lamb dish and the Aloo Ghobi both of which were rather tasty.

The service was decent. They were quick to take our order, bring our food, and made sure our glasses were never empty. 

The food for taste and quality deserves 4 stars (minus the SHRIMP) but as far as VALUE, it did not quite make it to par.

4 People:
Vegetable Samosa
Garlic Naan
Regular Naan
Rice
Lamb Dish
Chicken Tikka Masala
Aloo Ghobi
Prawn Curry
1 glass of Cote de Rhone
= $96 with tip

YIKES! It was pretty good, but can i justify paying TWICE as much as i normally would? HELL NO.

I would come here again but only on a date when he's paying. =p
author: Glory W.

description:
The food at this cozy Indian bistro in West Portal has gone downhill in the last year and one half.  It used to be much better.  Last night we had the Channa Masala and the Aloo Gobi.  Both had watery tasteless sauces and the service was just average.  It is a shame because this place used to be a good choice for tasty Indian food at a reasonable price!  They may have a different chef or be under different management than they were a year and one half ago when I had my last good meal there.

The Roti Indian Bistro in Burlingame has much better food than this one.
author: Daniel S.

description:
My partner and I have been eating at Roti since it opened, sometime in early 2005 I believe.  The food is wonderful, and the staff is generally very good.

Unfortunately, last night (2/2/2006) we had quite possibly the worst waiter on earth - rude, short, unwelcoming, and he ignored us the entire evening - and it's unfortunate, because Roti's cuisine is really to die for.  

Hopefully the owners will hire better staff so that their food can be enjoyed along with good service.
author: Michael D.

description:
I've given up on this place. They have great food, but atrocious service. In restaurant, everything is just slow and sometimes the staff is pleasant, sometimes not.

Trying to call in an order for pickup is pointless. They don't answer the phone, or, if they do just leave you on hold. This has happened to me so many times that I finally had to write a review about it.

They are one of the priciest Indian places around, and while the food justifies it, you'd think they could hire a few more people on staff.

It's also almost impossible to find parking, which is not really their fault, but something to be aware of.
author: Jim T.

description:
Roti Indian bistro (and Masala in Danville see my other review) are reminders to the population at large that Indian food is an amazingly flavorful and classy dining experience.

The food is amazing. I particularly love the chutney's, the naan and the pilafs. The lamb is phenomenal. Roti is an excellent location to dine out with friends as the place is tastefully decorated.

If you think of Indian food and your thoughts stray to "Naan-N-Curry" you need to be beaten senseless. And then dragged to Roti.
author: Mona I.

description:
I am not sure it really even deserves one star.  I won't be going back.  My wife and I ate there last night...The wait staff was slow to our table with some excuse about business.  They took our order, the waiter asked how hot I would like my Chicken Vindaloo...(really hot is my thing)...he replied oh they like a challenge so I will tell them to make it extra hot.

20 minutes later...still no food.  Other people who sat down after us had received their food.  They brought out my wife's soup special.  It was ok.  They brought two bowls, I guess they thought we were sharing.  Anyway...several water filler dudes reached all the way across my plate to refill my water.  My food took another 15 minutes.  The server said oh the kitchen is really backed up tonight.  There are two tables ahead of you.  

In the end they brought out the Vindaloo...It was barely hot enough to work up a sweat,  And it was 14 dollars.  If you are a rich snob living in West Portal then I guess this place seems cultured.  But with rip off food and bad excuses for service I really don't think it's worth it.  Plus the decore is really sad.  Too loud...no Indian music.  And many staff walking around like they nothing to do....GO GET MY DAMN FOOD!!!

I will not be back.  Instead I will patronize a million other good Indian Food places in the city.  Like, Dosa, Indian Oven, Pakwan, Alhamra...etc.  This place sucked.
author: joshua c.

description:
Really nice experience here tonight!  First time customer and will definitely put Roti Bistro on my A list.  Had the Tandoori Lamb cubes which were huge, plentiful and perfectly prepared.  The goat cheese naan is unusual and really outstanding. Companions had chicken jalfrazi and chicken korma; both were excellent.  BTW you have to ask for dishes to be made spicy, otherwise you get a mild version of the dish.
Nice selection of wines by the glass at reasonable prices.  Service was great, even with a number of large parties in the restaurant.
author: Sean M.

description:
Roti really is as good as it gets.  The owner is one of the nicest people I know and he continues to do whatever is necessary to make his guests feel above and beyond at home.

i have been hooked on their fresh Hen and Kulfi.  I just cant say enough good things.  I respect good customer service and have a great sense of Indian food given that I am brought up in parts of India where bad food does not have much tolerance so this place gets five stars from me and a special bow to the wonderful owner for his polite and sweet gestures to make sure everyone has a five star experience there!
author: C K.

description:
For authentic Indian food, this is the place with lots of great selections for meat and vegetarian folks. Excellent dishes, I highly recommend their mixed tandoori, chicken tikka, and boti kabob, all very flavorful. 

The West Portal location is small so seating is limited. Generally, they will be a long wait for dinner if you don't have a reservation.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
I like Roti a lot - their food is incredible.  Their food is so good that i actually agreed to get their monthly email blasts (ya'lls know that's a big deal).  

Here are my complaints:
1. everything is a la carte.  I hate it when you think you're getting a $12 plate but really you're paying $20 because you want the yogurt and the naan and the rice.  Granted - they are ALL DELICIOUS but...it's one of those places where you might get some sticker shock. 

2. they NEVER EVER EVER pick up their phone.  EVER!  that really aggrevates me.  I've asked the hostess about it once and she says - yeah...we don't pick up the phone when we're busy.  WTF?

3.  I went on a Tuesday night and the place was half empty.  I wanted a table but they were booked.  WHAT?  I walked by an hour later...still lots of empty tables.

I think that the hostess just gets...i don't know? Nervous?  They really need to work on their front service.  

Again - 4 stars because the waiters and the food = great.
author: Rose Z.

description: When I'm in the mood for Indian Food and I'm at work, this is the place I go to for lunch. Cute restaurant, decent service and yummy food. Everything I've ordered has been fresh and so delicious. Parking is a challenge but hey, it's West Portal. Get an SFMTA card and hopefully you'll get a meter that isn't broken. ;)
author: Heather L.

description:
My boyfriend and myself had dinner at Roti tonite and we were extremely disappointed. To start the hostess seemed confused about where to seat us and eventually she sat us at a table not finished to be cleaned up and put the menus on the dirty table! We had to call someone to clean it up. After that, I ordered a chicken tandoori (murgh)and my BF a Machchi Masala (sea bass curry dish). I almost fainted because my chicken was too spicy. I was in pain, my mouth, my throat and my stomach were burning like hell. I called the waiter and told him that I could not eat it  because it was too spicy. The waiter was confrontational and simply said that " this is the way the food is here" ! 
I was horrified and told him to take it away. He offered me to change it and make another one not spicy. My BF's curry was too salty/msg, inedible and the seabass was overcooked and soaked in the rich and salty sauce. The waiter came back 15mns later and my BF told him about his dish. The waiter answered him agressively" you too you want to change that"?? 
He said no, but give me more rice in order to be able to mix my fish with .
I felt bad because it was our Friday date night and it was screwed up. 
2 hours have passed since the end of the meal and I am still in pain, having stomach cramps. 
And on top of that it is very expensive for the quality of food and service.
author: Mary A.

description:
I came here for the first time on Valentine's Day this year.  No, not with a date sadly.  HA!  I came with two of my friends and with my brother.  We were all dateless so we figured "why not?" 

The place was packed, as you can imagine.  The food was delicious.  I was with good company.  What more could you want?!  Oh wait, a date right?  It WAS Valentine's day *barf*
author: Jillian J.

description:
Roti was such a pleasant surprise, since I'd just about given up on a delicious, atmospheric Indian meal in the city.  The paneer dish (paneer bhurjie, I think) was incredibly good--the cheese-like paneer is fresh and soft, unlike in most other Indian restaurants.  The off-menu marinated paneer is so mouth-watering, I asked them to consider adding it to the menu.  Even if they don't, I was told I could call in advance and they'd marinate it for me in time for dinner.  Now that's customer service.  Our waitress was friendly and efficient (Thanks, Sara!) and the wine selection-especially the Rieslings--complement the Indian food well.  The paratha bread has been very highly recommend (I went with the buttery naan and roti), and I can't wait to return and try the rest of their offerings and chat with 2 of the friendly and lovely new owners.  

Also, every few months they offer a "tasting and pairings" event, which teaches you about 3 selected dishes and offers wine selections that pair with the Indian dishes.  Each of the dishes offered this weekend drew acclaim, and the sparking red wine (Lambrusco from Italy) was a great match for the tamarind chutney.  Ask about the next tasting!
author: Suhani K.

description: Gave it another shot at this place last week.  It's always very warm in there.  The service was okay.  Food was okay, but very rich with lots of grease in the sauce.  The naan bread is not nearly as good as the Clay Oven in West Portal, a little on the saggy side.  Kind of pricy for what you get.  Will not return.
author: TopCat W.

description:
This is actually 3.5, we'll round up.  Food, was great.  Especially good was the fish pakora -- fresh, tender, juicy, flaky fish with a very hot, flavorful and terrific batter.  It wasn't so thick it obscured the fish.  A perfect balance all the way.  The chicken and prawn vindaloo were also both very solid.  Not screaming hot, but cooked with attention and liberal hand on spices.  Absolutely amazing Kabuli Naan with golden raisins, cherries and nuts ground into a smooth paste and slathered in between the layers of the chewy, moist and piping hot bread.  It was incredible.  Try that naan and it'll blow your mind. 

The service, was great until they delivered our food.  Then, we didn't see them again until we tackled our waiter for the check.  Yes, definitely busy and I think they could work on efficiency and timing.  But, I'll drive a long way to get my hands on that naan when I've got a craving.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Go if you're in the neighborhood.... It's in West Portal = far farrrr from where I live...  

Great loungey-ish lighting/atmo.
Interesting modern and classic dishes.
Organic / sustainable ingredients.
Young, hipster servers.
Good wine list. (The Chateau St. Jean gewurztraminer pairs great!!)

Some dishes work a lot better than others though.
And the prices aren't cheap!
author: Melanie C.

description:
Whenever you walk into a place for the first time and the owner takes a look at your posse and thanks you for coming back, you know it's going to be a good dinner.

I am often mistaken for someone else.  It doesn't bug me, especially in this case.  We were treated quite well.  The food came out quickly and the service was very nice.  Food was pretty good though somewhat over-priced, but not by much.  You are really paying for the atmosphere, which has a great ambiance about it that relaxed me as I ate my curry and chicken masala.

I would like to try this place again to see if I still am mistaken for someone else.
author: Chris M.

description:
Really great food and cute decor, but service was not the best. We started out with one waiter, who either went on break or was frightened off by me telling him we were NOT ready to order yet.  Whatever the reason, we got some other waiter, who I think also served Josua P. He tried to make some joke which made my bf uncomfortable, then kneeled and touched us. It was not okay. 
Despite the strange waiter situation, I would definitely return to try some more of their dishes.
author: Kate P.

description:
Roti (not to be confused with Rotee, which is in the lower haight!), is a bit pricey for my means, and frankly, I couldn't really detect where those extra dollars were going in terms of the food, with the exception of the seafood masala, however, which included big, yummy chunks of salmon! They certainly don't skimp on the fish! 

But $5 for a mango lassi??? I mean, who does that???!!! At least they had free refills on Chai tea ($3), however, as plenty of people probably know, the chai is FREE at a handful of other notable, and less upscale for that matter, indian restaurants in SF and the East Bay. 

I will say, though, that the food was remarkably non-greasy, which counts for a lot in my book...or maybe it's just that I didn't order a cream-based dish, but either way, I didn't feel like I was going to die at the end of the meal, which is a good thing!
author: Shannon R.

description:
3 Friends and I decided to actually leave the mission for dinner and decided on Roti in West Portal.  It was delicious.  Our waitress, Shipra, was really  helpful, and told us in detail about the dishes - flavors and spice-level.  

When my fellow diner spilled his glass of water we were immediately descended up on with napkins from the staff - so nice!

Bhindi Masala (okra) was out of this world, as was my lamb and spinach dish.  I love spicy food, but want to be able to taste something other than "hot".  Roti delivered.

One minor thing, the appetizer sampler was a bit disappointing, with only two items.  Both were tasty, but a sampler implies more than two - right?
author: Annie C.

description:
When I went here I ordered:
2 Samosas, which were really good and I've never had bad samosas in an Indian restaurant.
Vegetarian dumpling-type things that were pretty good.
And the basmati rice.

The restaurant was busy so the service was understandably slow. I recall that their roti bread wasn't vegan which was extremely disappointing because I've never ran into that problem anywhere else and I was looking forward to having it.

I remember the food was pricey and although it was good, it wasn't worth the amount I paid. I'd much rather go over to New Ganges.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Roti has excellent food, a raucous fun atmosphere and all things considered - pretty good service.

I've lived in India and I can say that the food here matches very closely the food I ate in India in texture, taste and quantity. Roti makes some of the best naan in San Francisco and their tandoori is not too bad either. The night I was at Roti there were several Indian couples sitting near us and you know what they say - if THOSE people are eating it then it must be good.

When I went here I made a reservation 30 minutes before on Open Table which was a smart move, because when we arrived there were at least 8 people standing outside waiting for a table. Tip - before coming pop open Open Table and make a res - you'll be glad you did.
author: Shane H.

description:
What a disappointment.  I chose this based in part on the recommendation of a friend who I usually trust, but...

Two of us had two entrees (chicken tikka masala, mixed tandoori) the basic rice, garlic (and basil??) naan, and kingfishers beers.  $80 with tax and tip

pleasant atmosphere, but very loud for an "expensive" restaurant.  adequate service.

food -- meh.  flavorless tikka masala ($16), usually one of my favorites, definition of bland here. at least i built up my empty calorie count..sigh. mixed tandoori ($22!) was 1 prawn, 1 small piece steak, 1 small piece chicken breast, 2 ground lamb, and 3 chunks of salmon.  the lamb was yummy, very very flavorful.  everything else...see, above, description of chicken tikka masala. the salmon was pretty well cooked, but if i didn't know i was in an indian restaurant, i would have had no idea based upon the flavor...nothing but a (too fishy) salmon  flavor.

would have been 3 stars, but -1 for the price.  esp in West Portal, for  $40/per person, expect outstanding food and/or service, and nothing here was more than....meh

Fortunately, my company made up for the restaurant's shortcomings! :-)
author: John R.

description:
My wife and I got takeout from here and it was very delicious. I used to live in London where there are Indian restaurants everywhere and I think this place would be among the best even there. 

The lamb in my Rogan Josh was incredibly tender and the sauce was perfect. The rice was great as well. I will definitely be going back to this place at some point.

The prices are a little bit high for Indian food (e.g. I'd expect to pay $10 for a curry, not $15), but it is above average quality and the portions are reasonable. 

I only took away one star because of some minor issues: the Nan bread was too flat and the food took about 10 minutes longer than they said it would. This caused me to have to wait standing up in front of the restaurant and I felt like I was ruining people's nice night out with my sandals and shorts. Like I said, minor issue.
author: Jamie D.

description:
ck out the rack of lamb ribs. I ate 4 last night and my buddy Jeff ate eight.
Outstanding food and service
author: Harris L.

description:
Let me preface this review with the fact I'm a wuss when it comes to spicy food. The slightest hint of jalapeno triggers five-alarm signals to my poor taste buds. Don't judge. Having said that, Roti disappoints in fusing flavor and spiciness that Indian food is known for. Me and my guest ordered the Chicken Jalfrezi and Aloo Gobi (cauliflower plate). Both were curries carnivorous and vegetarian friendly, respectively. While both plates were decently spiced, they seriously lacked palatably, and I wasn't eager to dive in for a second taste. It was like eating a PB&J sandwich without the jelly, but then again I don't like jelly, bad analogy. The only reason i kept eating was to have something to dip my naan in, which you really can't go wrong with, even if it's just plain naan.  

All in all, the experience was pleasant: servers were attentive and polite, dim ambiance. May I add, it was a little noisy but maybe it was just that particular night due to 3 separate big parties taking place, one being a group of drunk 40-something cougars.  However, the food fell a little short of prompting future visits.
author: Annie L.

description: Excellent. The murgh malai and rogan josh were the most tender meats I've had, with very good flavor. Calamari was outstanding, and very good naan. Kheer was good if not great. Cozy atmosphere with great service.
author: George F.

description: I'm not a big fan of Indian food but the food here sure does taste good!  I went here for the first time with my husband and we ordered a bunch of stuff, none of which I can remember but they were all good.  Oh also, order their Indian homemade ice cream with pistachio.  It's really good!  Since I enjoyed it so much, I took one of my best friends here and the food was just as good.  We ordered the Chicken Korman, the assorted Naan  basket, lentils, some cucumber dip.  It was all delish.  You have to try this place at least once.  Parking can be hectic but it's not as bad as downtown San Francisco.
author: Christine P.

description:
Credit for my little brother on this one. He saved an almost ruined nnight of walking in the rain to find an old favorite on West Portal closed. Darn Monday nights, almost everywhere good is closed.

Roti was open. We hadn't been there before. We really weren't planning on eating Indian food. But, it was the perfect comfort to counter all the dreary rain. The spicy and flavourful lamb, oh, just warmed everything up. The rice and spinach dishes were mm mmm good, too. We ate so much there. 

The food was great, and the staff was hilarious! What a fun place to eat at.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
The service was really great, perfect in fact and we, me and two friends, ever got into an actual conversation with our waitress that wasn't about the restaurant or the food - so, if that paints a clear picture, it was a very comfortable place with really nice people.

I am a jaded consumer of Indian food since there is the Bay Area's best Indian restaurant, Suraj, just miles away from my childhood home.

The food is really bland, especially when you're expecting to be eating Indian food.  You want some spices, some flava, some "Oh, shit, my lips are burning from Vindaloo."

I fell like the classier the Indian joint, the more plain the food is.

This place is run by really nice people and has a great staff but the food is boring, definitely not what Indian should be.

If you have a sever case of the gringo tongue, this place might be fine for you.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I love Indian food. I especially love it when it's delivered to me (mostly by Al Hamra, sometimes by Zante, on top of a pizza). But sometimes you have to go to the restaurant to get the best stuff.

We visited Roti on a rainy night, long after we'd first heard about the place. We were in the neighborhood dropping by the opening party for Citipets, a new pet store in the area that's an extension of a wonderful dog walking/pet sitting service. (Go and support them!) We felt welcomed by Roti's subtle lighting and surprisingly sophisticated ambiance.

The best dishes we ordered were the okra (bhindi masala), the eggplan (bengan bharta), and the garlic naan. Less stellar, but still fine, was the basic chicken curry (murgh masala). Rice was, well, rice. We enjoyed the water that came in the super-tall beaker.

Sitting right next to the kitchen wasn't ideal, but we hadn't made a reservation, so that placement was acceptable for a walk-in meal. Service was friendly, if slightly frantic and goofy.
author: Tara M.

description:
Decor and ambiance was on the upscale side and a bit unexpected. Staff were friendly and efficient. The layout of the restaurant made me feel a bit crammed in. Yet another SF restaurant which insists on placing the tables so close together that a private conversation is all but impossible.

The food was generously portioned, but I felt a bit bland. Nevertheless, it was tasty and I will probably return at some point to give them another shot at an additional star from me.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
I really want to give it one more star, but I really think the food at tasty curry is better. I rate the food, not the restaurant. Roti has great decor and ambiance, which make it a very nice place to good with friends or dates. But the food really isn't that great.

The lamb curry with yogurt is nice, but the lamb is too stringy.
The naan was alright.

Everything was alright. 
Atmosphere was great.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Hmmmm this place is sooo good.  -1 star because prices aren't fantastic.  
Ok, you must try the goat cheese naan.  Try it because it's super tasty and also because I have yet to find another indian place that has it.
The service is very friendly and attentive.  I ordered a mango lassi the last time I was here and it was very refreshing.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Expensive, modern Indian cuisine.

Good for impressing a date.  

Not good for eating out daily.

Their chicken saag is delightful.  Naan is pricey but that's more or less expected of any Indian establishment.

Will eat from again, but I prefer to take-out.
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
Roti was delicious.  I'm used to the grease and crap service at Naan n Curry (don't get me wrong, I LOVE it there).  My  friends raved  about this so I thought I'd give it a try. 

The portions were pretty large to fit a family of four.  I expected it to be smaller because it seemed more like a date place, but nope.. took my family here for a pre-Father's Day dinner.  We ordered the Rosemary Naan (June Special), some kind of Fruity Naan, Lamb special, grilled veggie & fruit sizzling platter, and some chicken dish (and surprise, it wasn't Chicken Tikka Masala!).  Everything was perfect.  Thought the veggie & fruit platter was a bit pricey it was tasty though, but NOT worth it.  

Bill was very fair for four people, but they do charge a Health Insurance Surcharge which was $4 on top of tax and tip.  But  it wasn't a big deal.  Food, service, and atmosphere was all worth it.
author: anita h.

description: Food is always great, atmosphere relaxed and yet a little upscale, and personal attention by the owner
author: Terry W.

description:
My wife and I were looking forward to eating here but our experience was mixed. The food was pleasant but no where near as good as restaurants like Ajanta in Berkeley or Junoon in Palto Alto.  Moreover, the service was not that great.

Usually, I am so into the food that I don't care about the service. But at Roti Bistro it completely failed to meet even minimal expectations:

1. The hostess seemed dazed and confused. Had problems deciding where to seat us
2. The food took quite a while to arrive even though the restaurant was not that busy.
3. We ended up ordering twice as much rice and bread as we needed. The waitress didn't  bother to give us advice on quantities.
4. My wife had to ask three times for another beer.
5. One of the entrees was left out of our to go bag
6. The restaurant didn't bother replying to my email about #5

Oh well, there are many more restaurants to try...
author: Chris R.

description:
I probably shouldn't have come here one week after returning from India...

The roti is Singapore-style, not Indian-style.  It's not that tasty.  In India, you get better roti on the street for twenty cents.

The food was lacking in spice and aromatics.  The fish was pretty good, but the vegetarian thali lacked any resemblance to good Indian food.  The whole place seems blanded out for Americans.

There are much better places downtown and near the Tenderloin.  This place has a nice dining atmosphere, but that's the beginning and end of it.  

This was my second visit, I attributed the low quality of the  first to a visit on a slow lunch day for the place.
author: Spike S.

description:
The place was a bit of a disappointment after reading such good reviews on yelp. 
We had paneer tikka masala and chicken jalfarezi along with Naan and roti. The food was good, but on the bland side; but given that I like my Indian food spicier than most, it may not apply to everyone. 
The naan was also quite a disappointment; though the roti was pretty good. 
The place was also on a little expensive side - i've eaten better India food around the city for less.
author: Namita G.

description:
Wow, what an amazing food and dining experience.  As a Indian aficionado I thought that I had tasted the best food until I visited this amazing West Portal restaurant.

Despite being packed (we waited because we did not make reservations, you should) it was worth waiting for the Tandoori lamb (Seekh Kabab) as well as the tasty Murgh Masala!  However, what stole the show was the piping hot Roti and a dish called Palak Paneer (Cheese and Spinach).  I would go back for those dishes alone!

Additionally, the staff was friendly, the table was great and to top it off, Chef Paul came to our table to see how we were doing, a nice touch to a great evening!

Thought the prices were very good for the type of food that we ate and the wine selection was solid.  Definitely worth going to, as it is in my opinion, the best Indian food in the Bay Area.  I read that they have another restaurant in Burlingame and the next time I need to have a Peninsula meeting, I will have it there!
author: Michael C.

description:
PRO'S: Great service, good food, and the garlic and basil naan was off the hook!

CON'S: You have to wait FOREVER for a seat, it's really pricey for food that is better at naan and chutney, and the goat cheese naan may "sound" like a good idea...but really, it's not. They go over kill on the goat cheese, and I love goat cheese, but even I know when too much takes away from the meal.

I really like this place, I would go again...but I have had better and bigger portioned indian food at other places in the city that didn't cost over $40 for two people.
author: Nancy M.

description: Just got back from eating there to celebrate our anniversary, on a super-busy holiday Monday eve:  wow!!!!  excellent & attentive service, absolutely delicious food (salad with cucumbers, fried eggplant, spinach aloo, dal, veggie biriyani, naan), warm inviting atmosphere.  We won't wait till our next anniversary to return.
author: Kate M.

description:
excellent high quality dishes.
excellent service.
excellent management.
This place has the great indian tastes with high quality ingredients. Rostam the manager makes you feel welcome every time.
author: Kasra V.

description:
(1) Yummmmmmmm.

(2) Yeah, they're not great about crowd management. We wanted to place a phone order recently, and only at the end of a long, long message were told "if you hear this, we're very busy right now and might not be able to take phone orders." (Really? Too busy even to answer the phone and say that?)

(3) Yummmmmmmm.

(4) Yes, it's more expensive than most. It's a different kind of place than a hole-in-the-wall Indian restaurant. Or a restaurant in India, of course (he said, glancing at Ben N and his 2-star review). Atmosphere counts -- and, to me anyway, the food is superb.

(5) Yummmmmmmm.
author: Andy N.

description:
Like Nathan R., my husband & I dined at Roti on NYE. 
I tried calling in the afternoon to make reservations, but no one answered until close to 5:30 PM - I thought that was a bit odd, but I understand that restaurants often close in the afternoon, etc. When I did reach someone, he couldn't tell me if they  had space for us right away, so he took my info and called us back.

When we arrived for dinner, our reservation was "lost", but the Bookkeeper/Host sat us right away anyway (since he was the one I spoke to on the phone, I think?)

On to the food: we ordered 3 dishes: Lamb Biryani, Baigan Bhartha and a Chicken Curry and regular roti and paratha. Oh, and we also had Samosas for appetizers; the Samosas were tasty. The portion size for the main dishes were generous and since we had asked for spicy (or was it extra spicy?), the kitchen did indeed oblige, which my husband loved. 

I would say that the food here is solid, and our server was pleasant, but the whole reservation process is a bit spotty.
author: Jo-lynn F.

description:
If you wanna have authentic north indian cuisine , this is the place to go!
I can say that coz i am an indian !
the ambience is very urban. the food is yummilicious. the service is good although it is very noisy.....coz its always packed....
A great place for indian food!
author: Vaishali R.

description:
Roti on West Portal has a bad attitude. 

One night my wife and I walked in at 10:00 and they wouldn't serve us stating the kitchen was closed even though the hours on the door said they were open until 10:30.

The very next time we tried to go was 6:00 on a Saturday and They would not serve us without a reservation even though there were many open tables.
author: steve g.

description: Consistently the tastiest Indian food around. LOVE that they create monthly special dishes. Top of the list is their tandoori game hen, once a monthly special, now permanently on the menu. The staff are welcoming, friendly and really great overall.
author: m g.

description:
This place is pretty yummy. I feel like this was the restaurant that taught me what Indian Food is supposed to taste like. The food was very flavorful and spicy. Loved their Mango Lassi!

It's a little on the pricey side, but if you'd like some really good indian food, this is the spot.
author: Diane N.

description:
I'll admit, I walked into this place with a bad attitude. Anyplace that labels itself as an "Indian Bistro" is highly suspect in my opinion. I mean, calamari at an Indian restaurant? Please. 

So when the waiter couldn't pronounce the word "lassi" correctly, it got my panties in a bunch. When I saw the prices, my fists started to clench. And when he informed me that they were out of mango juice, I think smoke may have started coming out of my ears.

But to my surprise, the food was really good. We ordered the Paneer Bhujia, the Cholay, the Chicken Tikka Masala, and the special Badami Chicken. I'm veg, so I only tasted the sauces on the chicken dishes, but it was all really tasty, and sufficiently spicy for my mirchi-loving companions. The naan basket was really yummy as well. My "special Indian style lemonade" was waaaaaaay too sweet though, and at five bucks for a mango lassi (or laaaaahsi, as the waiter pronounced it), it had better have diamond chips floating in it (it didn't).

Once we were presented with our hefty bill (about $100 for five of us, which is a lot for Indian food, especially when Indians are eating it), it took the staff a good 15 minutes to pick up our credit cards, and then there was huge confusion about how to split the bill between three cards. It was a bit insane, especially since they seemed to have more waitstaff than customers at the time.

Anyway, I agree with those reviewers who've said they'd come here again, as long as someone else is paying. Otherwise I'll be in the Tandoorloin.
author: Vandana M.

description:
I'm pretty hard to please when it comes to Indian food.  My favorite places being Vik's Chaat Corner in Berkeley and Mehfil Indian Cuisine in downtown SF.  This place wasn't too bad!

I've been judging my favorite Indian food places by how good their Chicken Korma is (so far, Mehfil is the best!), and the korma I had at Roti was pretty decent.  The portions were decent to share with 2-3 people, but were very pricey ($13 for Chicken Korma?!)!  My only complaint was that the chicken they used seemed to be rather tough.  The pieces are larger than I'm used to,  and the dish just seemed very simple - chicken and sauce.  I'm used to korma with more substance - with nuts, shredded coconut, ginger, onion, garlic and tomatoes.  Don't get me wrong though, it was tasty none the less.

Another staple we ordered was the Palak Paneer (Saag Paneer).  It was really good.  I would have liked it to be a bit spicier.  The cheese was very good and it wasn't overly heavy like some other places make it.  We ordered the garlic basil naan, and it seemed to compliment both dishes very well.

Service was exceptional and so fast!!  A beautiful restaurant with a very nice atmosphere (it was really quiet when we went).  I'm just not sure about the prices - a tick over $40 for an appetizer, two dishes, rice and naan and two sodas is a lot to pay for Indian food when you consider what else is around (Mehfil is an easy $10 less for similar fare).  But, I suppose you're paying for the ambiance. 

Glad I tried this place, but I think I'll be heading back downtown for Mehfil.
author: Christy L.

description:
I've been intending to write this for a few days now, so here it is:

My date and I went to this restaurant last Saturday and would definitely go back again.

One suggestion -- don't use the online reservation system -- call the restaurant to make your reservations!

We started with a cote de rhone wine that was excellent (they have a great wine list) and was very highly recommended by our server.  Afterwards, we decided on a fried calamari appetizer.  This was not your typical fried calamari -- it was not chewy or greasy -- it was perfectly cooked.  It came with 2 sauces.  Our server also thought it good to include one more sauce, so she brought us some raita (a yogurt/cucumber sauce) that was excellent.

I decided on the Saag Gosht (lamb with spinach) and my date chose the Chicken Makhani.  Both dishes were excellently presented and were great.

After dinner, we were treated to a complimentary glass of port which completed the meal splendidly.

The atmosphere was good and my date and I were able to hold a conversation without too much yelling.

We would definitely go back again.

I would also like to give kudos to our server, Amanda.  She was very friendly and helpful.
author: Greg K.

description:
One of my favorite lunch spots.

11$ for Chicken Tikki Masala for Lunch (a lot more expensive for dinner). 

Compared to Naan 'N Curry: 
a. $3 more expensive
b. You get a pretty tasty salad
c. You probably get twice as many chunks of chicken in your curry.
d. The Chai Tea doesn't taste like crap.
