Also make sure you try the Papadum for $2. Definitely worth the money to taste the different dips.
author: Joe Z.

description: the coffee tasted so good better than starbucks..i had a fried calimarie was fresh and delicious. i was satisfied and the mint/tomato/cuscuber salad was wonderful. the pricing is not too bad. it must be true we will be come bak
author: Kaylie B.

description:
Pure enjoyment from start to finish. Each time I visited the place I was given a table momentarily and taken care of. Their food is extremely good (I am a big fan of Indian food)...and they got choices for someone like me who enjoys the cuisine as long as it's not spicy and doesn't give me a heart attack. 

A great list of curries and my favorites are their lamb and seafood ones. Their lamb was a bit overcooked, but it was still very flavorous and delicious. The restaurant is beautiful inside and out, the low lighting makes it even romantique...

Enjoy...
author: Katja S.

description:
Lovely first date restaurant.  The food's good and the naan sampler rocks!!!  But then I'm partial to naan. 
We ordered the chole which was decent and the eggplant bertha which, though I'm not a huge fan of eggplant by any means, was alright. 

Atmosphere was very classy and the place itself is on a cute stretch of street (from what I could tell in the dark in the pouring rain).  But, damn, it was loud inside!  It almost made you feel like you were having a nice Indian dinner in a club.  Perhaps it was just that particular night and the slightly rollicking birthday party happening in the back... good distraction though, while thinking of conversation topics!  :-))
author: Rashmi N.

description:
I make the call. I put the babe to bed. Make the coffee for tomorrow. Check email, empty the trash, grab a poop bag for the dog. Walk up the hill, watch dog do her thang, then a few blocks to Roti. 

Then it's a block home, almost running now. Quick, leash down, wash hands. "HONEY, let's go. It's here."

Chicken Tikki, Chicken Korma, Samosas, Naan, Freeman Wine.

"...And I'm feeeling...." 

It's fresh, dammit.
author: kelly b.

description:
Ever since my traumatic experience at Shalimar, Indian food has been dead to me. That included any and all Indian food. Alas, I finally satisfied my bf's craving for Indian by suggesting this new, hip Indian bistro in West Portal. Where is West Portal anyways?

When we walked around the corner and saw the sign, first thing out of my bf's mouth, "Oh, it's a bistro..."  What does bistro mean anyways one may ask and can you really classify an Indian joint as a "bistro"? From wikipedia: Bistro is a familiar name for a type of small restaurant serving moderately priced simple meals in an unpretentious setting. Well, that hit the nail on the head! Now although, most of you are well familiar with the ubiquitous Naan n Curries that raid the tenderloin, this was clean, modern, and had excellent food. The tandoori chicken was tender and full of spiced flavor. The chicken tikka masala and chicken korma were also fantastic winners in my book. We definitely would have tried more had there been more than two of us.

Wine list was surprisingly good for this type of restaurant and certainly for an Indian restaurant. And based on the general ambiance, I knew not to be afraid of the wine being open for days on end.

Tip - park on Portola and feel free to call ahead for reservations. Everyone is super nice and friendly.

This place has made me like Indian food again!  I might even go back to Shalimar...wait, that's a strong statement. Maybe I'll reconsider for 2008!
author: Josephine H.

description:
Update: 
My husband and I have eaten here a couple of times now and we really like it.  Other than the fact it can be difficult to get a table, the food is very tasty (especially the chicken tikka masala and naan - strike that - all their breads) and the service is super friendly.  Upped the stars to 4. 

Original review posted 11/07: 
I haven't eaten here yet, but we arrived there at 5:30pm! on a Saturday night, and we couldn't even sit down.  They said they were fully booked for the night, but there were still a bunch of empty tables at the time, and only two of us.  Just surprising that they don't set aside anything for walk-ins/foot traffic.  
Hopefully, I will get the chance to try it, and update my review, though I guess we will have to plan ahead and make reservations in order to do so.  I still prefer Aslam's Rasoi at this point.  At least I can usually get seated there.
author: Cami B.

description:
I am somewhat new to Indian food, and this introduction was definitely enough to convince me that I need to eat more Indian food!

Everything we ordered was really tasty and the flavors seemed to just keep coming -- good spice without being over the top. A group of 4 girls, we split 3 appetizers and 3 main dishes. 

Apps: *Samosas - not as heavy as I have had in the past which was good *Goat cheese naan - as a self-professed goat cheese fanatic, this didn't disappoint me, but it's not something I would order again *Eggplant - too heavily fried, not great

Mains: *Chicken Vindaloo - delicious *Kashmiri Biryani - a little on the sweet side, but a good mild, saffron taste *Channa Masala - good, not great, a little on the spicy side

Overall, Roti offers good food, good service, and while it's a little on the pricey side, I thought it was worth it. I wanted to wait 4 hours and go back to order another round of different items -- I don't think there's much on the menu that would disappoint.
author: Jen W.

description: Love love love their Mango Lassi, it is the best in town. I have had it at every other Indian restaurant and no one makes it like Roti. Their food is pricey but good.
author: Roxanne W.

description: Oh Jesus....I never wanted the food to stop coming. Everything was so delicious here. Where to begin? The garlic naan bread was great, the samosas thick and hot. they were incredibly generous with their mango chutney. My friend and I had curry dishes and they were sensational. The waitstaff was attentive and everyone from the host to the young man pouring water was polite and .....it was so good. When I die I want my ashes sprinkled there. What's the Indian word for YUMMMMM?
author: George K.

description:
The bread basket is like Indian crack.  I could be happy going there, ordering a basket of bread and a glass of wine, and calling that dinner.

Of course, then I'd be missing out on some very nicely cooked entrees.  Try the lamb kebobs, but don't make my mistake and order them medium.  Shoot for closer to rare, and I bet they'd be well near perfect.  My friends are partial to the chicken tandoori, which is also good.

It's also got an appealing laid-back feeling.  The worst thing about Roti is trying to find street parking in West Portal.  Carpool, and you'll be satisfied.
author: Foodbag B.

description:
Just came back with some friends and I must say that everyone was satisfied!  Our waiter was very attentive, extremely friendly and knew everything on the menu by heart.  The owner himself (i think that was him), even walked by every table to check if everything was ok.  Obviously, customer service here is over the board!  

Food was definitely up to par!  They have different flavored naan even though my favorite is the plain one!  It goes well with chicken tika masala, lamb and spinach curry, beef curry, etc.

I would recommend making reservations because this place gets pretty pack!
author: susie b.

description:
This Indian restaurant has very 'Clean' tasting Indian food. Not just ingredients thrown on a plate. Very distinctive.
The chai is esp. wonderful as is their current special of carrot/ginger soup.
They take a lot of care in the preparation of their food and the service is great. The restaurant is not too loud and the Indian music actually varies from traditional to contemporary.
Thanks
author: Paolo A.

description: If you like Americanized Indian food this is the place to go. Lacks real spices hence is unauthentic. Good service but if you want real Indian food, go elsewhere.
author: Jay K.

description: The best Indian dining experience I have had in SF!!  Excellent service, great food, good ambiance.
author: AJ B.

description: Modern clean atmosphere, friendly service, and very delicious Indian cuisine in a burgeoning restaurant area, West Portal.  I had lunch here with an Indian co-worker and she raved about it. So I have a hunch that the food here is fairly authentic. I have been back several times and wholeheartedly recommend Roti Indian Bistro. There is usually a crowd so plan ahead.
author: Jeff W.

description: What's pretty awesome is that everything is fresh. They make it when you order it. The downside of that is that you wait a little longer... but who cares, if your food is better! The dishes are unique - try the goat cheese naan and lamb curry with buttersquash. Tasty, fresh, and unique food. Lovely!
author: Natalise K.

description:
First time I went to Roti, there was one other group sitting at a table.  We sat there for 20 minutes without a menu, water or any attention whats so ever.  So we walked out and went to Bulls Head around the corner.

I thougtht they had a bad day, so I tried it again tonight with a group of friends.  We had a reservation that we were slightly early for.  She said we would have to wait 20 minutes to be seated.  We did.  Another group walked in without reservations and got seated right away.  I asked why they got seated ahead of us when we had been waiting with reservations and they didn't.  The hostess said the owner did it and she had no control.  Never again!!!!!   
Clay Oven is at the other end of West Portal and they will fall over each other to give you amazing service, not to mention the food is much better and much more reasonable.
author: Nessa C.

description:
....I wish I could just have endless naan from Roti. Please, I will not ask for anything else. 

Tandori was so spicy I couldn't stop blowing my nose. Chicken curry had a little yummy heat to it & was super tender. My friend & I were wearing shorts--very underdressed, but service was great! Roti definitely beats Naan&Curry, and now Indian food is one of my favorites. Thanks.
author: Alexa M.

description: We often dine at West Portal so we were in the mood to break out of the mold and try something new. What do you know Roti, my favorite type of bread...sounds good! So we stop on in and instantly enjoyed a cumin seed cracker with some sauce. Alright nice start, then the waiting began and didn't stop for another half hour as others were also in the same predicament as us. Feeling exasperated, irritated and overly famished our food finally came. The dishes were pretty good, ordered a Tandoori fish and once again salmon was used. Boy am I tired of that damn fish, it doesn't even taste good in Indian Dishes let alone Tandoor style. The chicken Tikka Masala was good and all the Roti you could eat. Right up my alley. If it weren't for the long wait I'd give this restaurant a better rating but oh well, I may give them another shot at taking my money but I expect better results next time.
author: graham c.

description:
My wife and I took out her mother there for her birthday.  Roti decor is a bit more fancy and modern than most of the Indian restaurants I frequent. For example, empty wine glasses accompany the standard place setting. I guess they are just living up to the bistro in their name.  Anyway, it was a Wednesday evening and the place was a little more than half full. The servers were rushing around trying their best, but were not very attentive. On a positive note, every server we managed to flag down was friendly and helpful.

We started with a tasty appetizer sampler including a samosa, veggie pakoras and a papad. The palak paneer (spinach/cheese, $10) and baingan bartha (tandoori roasted eggplant, $9) curries were both excellent. My mother-in-law had the $17 mixed seafood curry, which was ultra-fishy (not my thing). The breads were tasty, but the naan was a bit flatter and glistening with ghee more than I like, and virtually indistinguishable from the tandoori roti. 

I don't know whether I'd choose to dine here again, but I might be tempted to take out a couple of their delicious vegetarian curries.
author: Ron L.

description:
Awesome!

Visited Roti last nite and was very impressed:

- friendly service (the hostess is a doll and patiently answered all my questions)

-chefs were very understanding when I told them my pregnant girlfriend was starving and couldn't wait the 45 min wait so they put it in high gear and got the food out in 25 min (this with a full house!)

-delicious food made from local ingredients! we LOVED the tandoori chicken, chicken biryani, naan, and chicken vindaloo.... all were seasoned wonderfully and the vindaloo had a mild heat so we could appreciate the spices without constantly wiping our nose...

-warm modern ambiance... how rare is it to enjoy Indian food in a nice space? (OK Dosa is another standout... if you're in the Mission you've got to check out Dosa, too...) Roti is a medium sized restaurant with stone floors and several tables throughout... seating can get somewhat cramped and you can easily hear your neighbor's conversation, but I believe it adds to the charm. It does get quite loud in there, and this was 9PM on a Wed! If you have a big group call for reservations in advance and ask to sit next to the window.... 

I don't live in the area but I'd consider driving there again... highly recommended.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
I have been to this place a lot, its very close by.

The staff is friendly, the service is fast, the decor is great.

I took my dad here once (he was visiting from out of state) and the manager or owner gave us free wine and desert because we complimented the staff.

It can be a bit expensive, but it has been worth it every time!
author: Alex F.

description:
I've tried this place maybe 4 times now and I've always had issues with the service. The management does do its best to react to this, which is always appreciated. I've noticed the complimentary wine or desserts quite often now. What is the motive? Tips? Friendly gesture? 

Either way, the food is sometimes good and sometimes not. I agree with the other Yelpers that it is not as flavorful and aromatic as the more authentic places, but it can satisfy that craving if you're in the area.
author: S. P.

description:
Okay I have to be honest. I have had a major bias against this restaurant, I don't know if it's the "bistro" suffix or the highly suspect location, or the fact that I'd much rather eat at one of the dive restaurants in the Tenderloin. Or all of the above. Anyway, with much trepidation I took my parents to this restaurant to celebrate my dad's birthday. Our food showed up exactly 9 minutes after we had ordered, which can be a good thing. We ordered basic Indian fare - fish curry, okra, vegetarian thali for dad etc. 

Our meal was very satisfying and the service was above average. I feel the prices are a tad more than I would normally pay, but then the portions are sizable so I guess that cancels out. All in all, we had a good time and the owner was a very friendly gentleman that went out of his way to make sure we were having a good time. A decent option for someone that's new to Indian food, or wants to dine at a restaurant with a good ambience.
author: Matin N.

description: Had a perfect dinner experience! My husband and I needed to get to a movie in 20 mins, and the server said no problem! The food was out quickly- it was delicious ( Saag Paneer and Curry) - and we were on our way. Flawless. Heading out the door the hostess offered to keep the leftovers in their refrigerator while we were at the movie! Above and beyond. So nice!!!
author: Emily B.

description:
I ventured into West Portal last night because my hood (Glen Park) has started to resemble a restaurant wasteland (Where did the Indian pizza place go? Wait, I digress...).  Anyway, I stumbled upon Roti and ended up leaving a very happy girl.

The place is lovely inside, great colors on the walls, really amazing photography of India, and a very nice use of fabrics.  This would be a great place to impress a first date.  The food is pretty good, not knock your socks off, but good.  The samosas were decent, but I will try another app when I go back.  The Bhindi Masala was excellent, even my date Willie P. Dixon liked it and he normally thinks okra is slimy and gross.  The Rogan Josh was tender and yummy.  We had the goat cheese naan, which was good, but make sure you like goat cheese if you order it because they are not stiffing you on the filling, that's for sure.  To top it off, the service was really, really friendly.

Pros: great ambiance
Cons: a little expensive, but they have to pay for that fab decor somehow :)
author: Melissa G.

description:
The review that mentioned Naan N Curry as having better Indian fare is absolutely preposterous! You will not find any red grease-laden or turmeric tossed dishes here. The food uses traditional Indian spices, full of flavor and intrigue, without blowing you out of your chair or denying a close conversation days after. Their bread basket is a a great assortment of naan and kulcha and I highly recommend it for a meal of 3+ people. The makhani sauce is great and the traditional tandoori options are also good. The service is thoughtful and very focused on the diner's overall experience. Once, when I was with a large party waiting and waiting for our main dishes, the wait staff brought additional apps free of charge. Certainly, the crowd is not a diverse one, but the food, service and atmosphere should appeal to all types.

Update 6/2/07: the last couple times I've been, none of the usual wait staff were there, and there seems to be a new owner, but I'm not sure. The service has noticeably declined and the dining room is always crazy crowded. After being seated late for a few reservations, I get the sense that their window for dining time is too small on Open table or something. It is appreciated that they dole out the free port and appetizers to make up for their lack of service, but I'd rather they bring their A-game to the table the first time around. The food is unchanged and still great.
author: J A.

description:
I work very close to Roti Indian Bistro, but it is unfortunate that they are not open for lunch.  It is one of my favorite Indian restaurants in San Francisco.  Last night was the third time I've eaten there.  The place was packed...surprisingly for a Tuesday night, but we were seated fairly quickly.

We always order the Machchi Makhani...served with their fresh fish of the day.  The always have a choice of a white fish or salmon.  We always order it with the white fish.   The last two times, that dish was super good...last night, it wasn't so fresh. The dish smelled quite fishy...one would think that it shouldn't smell fishy since it is covered in a light curry sauce full of spices.  

Last night, we decided to try a new dish:  Matter Paneer.  Wow, was that really tasty!  Their Mango Lassi is very tasty too, but be careful...if you are like me, you can get too full from drinking it and not be able finish the meal.  The drink is quite thick and rich.

Overall, this restaurant is great.  Although, the fish quality was inconsistent from the previous two times, I will still continue to eat at Roti Indian Bistro.  The staff is very friendly and attentive.  And, on their walls you will find some cool photography of the people of India.
author: Michelle N.

description:
I am a regular at Roti. The food is freshly made and extremely tasty. The wait staff are all extremely nice too - particularly the South African maitre d' (cannot remember his name). Coming from London I was almost brought up eating Indian food, and can say that this restaurant serves my favorite Chicken Tikka Masala. I was there last night and had a great lamb dish with an artery clogging paratha - yummy.  I also love the monthly specials - it helps make up for what is a comparatively limited menu. However, let's not forget that the limited menu is what enables them to make such fresh food.

Great photography on the walls - particulalry the portrait and the Ardh Kumbh festival.

My one gripe - it is impossible to get through on their phone to order a take-away. Oh - and why on earth do they not do delivery!!!
author: Tony H.

description:
This is probably one of my all-time favorite restaurants in SF.

It has gotten really popular since it opened up about 3 year ago I think.  I remember eating there on there 1 year anniversary and they were giving patrons free flutes of champagne to celebrate.  It's popularity has definitely skyrocketed and I would highly suggest making a reservation ahead of time if you have a fairly large party.  Couldn't say for sure which nights are the most popular aside from your typical Fri/Sat. chaos you see everywhere.  

I always get the Navratan Korma, which is fantatic.  Along with raita, somosas, veggie biryani and naan.  You pretty much can't go wrong.  I'm not a meat eater (generally) but even the tandoori chicken gets my nose tickling and my mouth watering.  My boy always gets the chicken tikka masala or the Chicken Boti Tikka, both of which always have excellent quality chicken.  

We've brought both sets of parents here and even hooked friend's parents on this place.  It is on the fairly pricey side if you're looking for affordable Indian so we do save it for more "special" occasions.  But boy do I wish I could eat here more often.
author: Kirsten B.

description:
As far as the food goes - this is the best Indian food I've ever had.  I really like the curries, the nan and everything else I've had there.

The lacking stars are for a couple of reasons.
1.  Quite expensive: $12 - $14/ curry and a minimum/person order
2.  Atmosphere - Horrible!  So loud that you have to shout - when I go out, I want to feel like I'm at a restaurant, not a bar.
3.  Service - I think once a manager told me that they train their waiters at this location - before, they all shared tables so no one knew who had ordered, who needed to be served etc.

Other than the above mentioned issues, the food is great, I'm looking forward to eating here again but I think Take Out is the best option.

- Aaron
author: Aaron B.

description:
This time my bf and I came here with our best friends to set them up on a date together.  We are sneaky little boogers. The ambiance is dim and nice. Not much has changed since my last review but I forgot how loud this place actually gets. It can become a little too loud because we were almost yelling across the table to hear one another, but the food is still delicious. 

We tried the garlic naan (instead of the plain naan), roti, and a few other dishes this time. We enjoyed them all. The mango lassi was perfect . Again, without reservations we were seated right away and the service was friendly and promt on a busy Saturday night. Minus .5 stars from last review. I can't put my finger on why though. Let me sit on that one.
author: Jen Y.

description: Great food, but pricey.  White table cloth.
author: Amanda P.

description: The service was excellent. I wish I could say the same about the food. The entrees were bland; this is supposed to be an "Indian" restaurant. The portion sizes were small unless you include the water, which I guess was supposed to be the gravy. Not giving it one star because of good service/staff.
author: Honest O.

description:
I'm really surprised to see so many high ratings on this place.  I have had a lot of good Indian food and I am lucky enough to have authentic home cooked Indian food often...
So I needed to bring a large amount of food to a Christmas party.  I looked around the South San Francisco area, and there isn't much Indian food available.  I drove to West Portal to pick up the chicken tikka masala, naan, and rice.  Luckily a lot of coworkers and family at the party haven't had a lot of Indian food because they thought it was okay.  Meanwhile my boyfriend and I were extremely let down.  I spent a fortune on that food and it was just mediocre and greasy.  It actually didn't taste at all like chicken tikka masala.  The restaurant is expensive, probably because of the decor but definitely not because of the food.  I would much rather get food at a more authentic restaurant with less fancy decor.
author: Christine L.

description:
After a quick intimate wedding at Grace Cathedral 9/12 evening we decided to celebrate the nuptials at Roti. What a treat, because Roti is soooo good! We got to Roti around 9pm and it was a packed house, luckily we didn't have to wait long. You wouldn't think you were eating in an Indian restaurant from the decor since it's modern. The atmosphere is very casual and a bit loud. 

The good stuff: the meal! We went with the Garlic and Basil Naan, Murgh Masala curry, one of the Veggie curries with farmer's cheese (this dish was my favorite, the cheese tasted like tofu - YUM), Kashmiri Biryani rice - this was EXCELLENT and the Halibut special. We were VERY happy with our choices. I also ordered the mango lassi... mmm mmm.

I'm only giving 4-stars because the service was lacking. After our food was taken away to be packaged, we must have waited 20 mins for the bill, our server apologized and offered us tea, coffee and dessert on the house - but being so late, we decided to pass. 

Overall, I would come back to this cute West Portal dining establishment.
author: S N.

description:
Definitely NOT coming here again. We went for the first time yesterday. We could not believe they were charging $16.00 for Chicken Tikka Masala but decided to place 2 orders anyway since it's one of our favorites dishes. BAD MISTAKE. It tasted like americanized indian food, not tasty & not worth the price. Go to Chutney Restaurant where you'll get the same dish for $6.49 & it tastes SO MUCH BETTER. They serve AUTHENTIC indian food that's reasonably priced& their food is VERY delicious unlike wannabe Roti Indian Bistro. 

Ordered Mango Lassi, which was delicious but again OVERPRICED. They charge $5.00 whereas Chutney charges $2.00 for a larger portion & is just as delicious.

Ordered Gulad Jalum, which was delicious but again OVERPRICED, not to mention the serving size is more suitable for a child. They charge $5.00 whereas Chutney charges $2.00, is just as delicious & serving size is for an adult.

We did not eat the majority of our meal so we asked the busser if he could box it up. Asked him to please include the dips for the appetizers & bread we ordered. Got home & there was no sauce. What did he put instead? The used lemon wedge that we squeezed over our appetizer. Really? Yes, really.  In addition, I hardly ate any of my Chicken Tikka Masala yet all he put in the to-go container was the chicken and left out almost all of the sauce that comes with it. WOW. Ummm... I paid for that entire dish as a whole and should get it as a whole if I want it to-go, not to mention the sauce is the best part of any Chicken Tikka Masala dish. HELLO???  

End price was $66.00 and really worth $10.00 & that's being generous considering the entire experience. I still gave the server an $11.00 tip because it's not her fault she works for a crappy, overpriced restaurant.

P.S. I do not work for Chutney Restaurant.
author: Randie M.

description: Awesome Indian food!  Got the Roti's Rogan Josh, it had just the right amount of spice and was cooked perfectly.  Also, best Naan I've ever had.
author: Nelson R.

description:
FABULOUS! be sure to explore the fine selection of indian breads. Poori is great, kabuli naan also excellent.
I warn you though, the indian lemonade is salty. I didn't expect that. I'm pretty sure it's supposed to be that way, but well. It does cut down the spice but just not my thing. Peach juice is great. 
There's a wait most nights though so reservations are good, or take away.

I think you get more food with the take away. Expect a wait even with take away.
author: vickie j.

description:
It's really good food but can be really hectic. Staff doesn't deal with the rush very well - gets surly or confused. If they can solve that issue, Roti is some of the best higher-end Indian food in SF.
=========
7/19/09 - wow, what a difference a few years makes. 
1. their food has gone way downhill
2. their service is regularly slow and indifferent

fortunately there's an Indian Over opening in West Portal soon. Farewell, Roti.
author: hunter w.

description:
I did not stay for the ambiance as I was too tired and wanted to get back to  my hotel room ASAP so I got take out. 

I got the following items and will describe them accordingly:

Vegetable Samosas: Yeah, they are samosa's alright. Not exactly what I was expecting in terms of spice though. Bear in mind that I can eat very spicy food. Just that the samoas did seem very mediocre. 

Seekh Kebab: Not bad actually! The flavor of the Lamb was definitely significant. Squeezed some lemon on them and enjoyed with my..

Parantha: Layed whole wheat bread, pretty much a roti on steroids. Very good indeed.

Now this was the first night and I ordered enough for two nights, so for dinner on the next night I had:

Paneer Makhani: Not what I expected but it was good regardless. I was expecting a dish known as Shahi Paneer which is sweet and has dry fruits in it with a similar sauce to Paneer Makhani.

Vegetable Biriyani: It was kind of bland. Could have used some more spices in it actually. 

Onion Naan/Kulchas: The onions used for these seemed like they were cooked beforehand with some Haldi and various spices. It didn't go very well with the flavor of the naan. I would like my Onion naans to be made with chopped raw onions, some cumin, cilantro, and some salt sprinkled on top. Delicious.

So overall, not a bad experience, but not a place I would take some Indian friends too. (Not that we would insist on going out for Indian considering we supposedly eat it every night.)
author: S M.

description:
i have been here several times and I have to say that I liked almost all the food that I have tried.  It is slighly on the pricier side, but I think it is worth it since the place is clean and the service is good.  

The only dish I didn't like was the Tandoori chicken which was a bit dry and flavorless.  I have had much better elsewhere.  Also, their naan was only ok.  

Other than that, I was satisfied with my meal!
author: Foodie B.

description:
First the positives: Good atmosphere, friendly waitstaff, nice crowd, and good naan.
Now the reason I gave it 3 stars: the food had good heat (spice) but not much flavor.  I want to go back and try again in hopes of giving it 5 stars.
author: Kool B.

description:
My friend Linda instroduced me to Roti Indian Bistro last month.  To date, it is the nicest "upscale" restaurant of its type that I've encountered in San Francisco.

The atmosphere was welcoming, the food delicious and the service was prompt and attentive.

We're meeting for dinner there again next week!
author: Stephen S.

description:
One of those upscale-ish Indian restaurants.  The food is good -- about the same quality, greasiness level (i.e., not very), and price as someplace like Aslam's Rasoi.  The paneer was standout; it seemed to be fried or browned or something -- quite good.

It was pretty noisy and crowded, though they had the tables arranged all Lincoln Log-ish, so you at least had your back to the people around you, instead of feeling like you were sitting on their laps.  (Cough, Dosa, cough.)  It'd be nice when it's not too crowded, I bet.

I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here (Old Krakow and Bullshead would be my top choices in West Portal, though in very different genres, I realize), but if you're in the neighborhood anyway and want Indian food, this place is just fine.
author: Megan D.

description:
Best Daal I've ever eaten. Really nice, light fried stuff, like pakoras and samosas. No heavy oily taste, the fried stuff is all light and tasty. Also they don't over do it on the cream sauces. 
Many people seem to think the food is bland, frankly I've felt the food at most Indian places was overspiced to make up for poor quality ingredients. The ingredients at Roti were top-notch and I felt like the dishes showcased them nicely. 
Seriously incredible Daal. Great pakoras. Pretty good tandoori, though the shrimp was overcooked. Great chai, great mango lhassi. 
Service was fine, I don't understand all the terrible reviews of the food at this place, and it was one of the cleanest restaurants I've been to. Also, they don't try to push you out the door like many other Indian places I've been.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Unsanitary!  We watched the server use his fingers to hold the fork tines, spoon head, and knives.  I complained to the manager who said he would tell the server, never offering an apology or compensation.  Verrry inappropriate.
author: Beverly C.

description: Great food, great service and nice ambiance.  Their monthly specials are awesome and all ingredients are fresh!  One of the best restaurants in San Francisco, you will be delighted if you dine here :)
author: K K.

description:
I'd give this place a 4.5 if I could. It was great to find an Indian restaurant with food that was tasty without being heavy or oily, the right amount of spice (requiring a sip of water, not bland or requiring a box of tissues), and a gorgeous interior. I'm so glad someone finally figured out that Indian restaurants can come in more decors than hole in the wall /shack on the side of the road motif or the overdone, aging, this is what Westerners think Indian palaces look like. Also, like one of the reviewers said, it's so wonderful not to smell like Indian food once you leave the restaurant.
Simply delicious...I can't wait to go back.
author: Madhavi K.

description:
This is one of my new favorite haunts.  Everything is good-- staff is nice, location is nice, food selection is nice, wine selection is nice, presentation is nice... it feels good to eat here.  And, it's not expensive. It's not going to blow your mind, but you'll probably want to come back.  

About the food: doesn't have the authenticity that some others spots have (my face being on Clement Ave, review posted ;D) but it's still good.  A great introduction to Indian food for the wary or shy.

One complaint: the very nice staff offered to finish the bottle of wine they had open by pouring it into our glasses, no charge.  (sweet!) however... the other two girls had Chardonnay and I had Viognier... he poured it without asking and I felt really bad bitching since he was trying to be nice... but then I had a sort of ICK hybrid of wines.  Only happened once though, and with the best of intentions :)  I go here one every week or so, as it's near my house.
author: crystala t.

description:
It was only on my fourth try that I managed to penetrate Roti.  

"Do you have reservations?"  
"Um...no"  We were about to leave, as usual.
"Right this way please."  I stand stupified.

But now that I have penetrated into Roti, I know what all the fuss is about!  Their food is DAMN TASTY!  Now, I've had Navratan Korma many many times in my life, but I've never had one like this before!  What IS that stuff in there?  Magic?  Pineapples?  There are so many flavors assaulting my tongue at the same time I don't know what to do with myself!  Maybe I'll eat the Raita.  Oh my god, the raita is delicious!!!  I'm gonna eat it all!!!!  What?  You're gonna refill that for me??  I love you!

Next time, I might contemplate actually getting reservations!
author: Athos K.

description:
+ Tasty, tasty food!
+ Nice ambiance
+ Great service
-  Drafty if you are sitting near the door
-  A little pricey
author: christine c.

description:
If you're looking for a quick Indian fix, Roti is the place.  

The food was very tasty, but not as aromatic as authentic Indian food is.  They have an extensive menu with quite a few house specialties.  

Also, they had a very decent selection of wines, for an Indian restaraunt, that the wait staff was very knowledgable about.
author: Josh S.

description:
A must go to if you happen to get lost in West Portal :).

The inside of the restaurant is clean and has a gentle serene feel to it.  Definitely a great place for a date, however, be forewarned that when you are finished with the delicious meal the smell of curry will linger on your clothes for the rest of the night.

I ordered the Chicken Jalfrezi, which is braised chicken with tomatoes, onions, peppers, basil and other spices.  Sounds good?  You bet! Since the chicken stews in the sauce, it makes it moist and tender to the bite.  The infusion of herbs and spices is perfect.  The presentation looks simple, but the taste is complex with many different layers and textures.  The dish had the perfect about of heat from the chili -- not too spicy or too mild!

Nann comes with the meal which is an excellent dipping companion with the sauce.  You do have a choice between either nann or rice.

A must visit!  Delicious! And the price was right!
author: myiken n.

description: Food 5 Service 3.  If you go bring a book because it will take a while to get your food.  Not worth a special trip but if you are in the area and want indian worth a visit.
author: Kevin C.

description: Simply the best North Indian food in SF, hands down.  I've been going here since it opened and the popularity of it has made reservations a must.  Everyone I take here continues to rave and demands that I take them back again.
author: Kristin E.

description:
pretty much as advertised: busy, good vibe, nice decor (especially for Indian) and good food (and nice takeout containers).

I'd recommend this for that nice, but not super fancy dinner out.
author: surya y.

description: Very good food and service, would recomend to anyone looking for a great place to get some authentic indian food.  The naan and paneer are fantastic
author: Justin H.

description: My favorite place for Indian food in San Francisco. This place is so delicious. It's almost like upscale Indian food. I'd recommend a reservation. They can get crowded, especially if you don't go right when they open. Their goat cheese naan is mind blowing good. I hate to be whitey-mc whiterson boring, but their chicken tikka masala is amazing. I love how spicy the Roti mixed vegetables can get too. You truly can't go wrong with anything on their menu. I recommend venturing out and taking their recommendations. Great place to go for a date or if you just love Indian food. Great intimate setting and in cute West Portal, so you can go see a movie at the Empire afterward.
author: Kristy H.

description: Had dinner last week. There were four of us and we all wanted the same things! Chicken Tikka Masala and the Tandoori Game Hen!  We've all been there before and love their food. I have to say, I can't think of a better place for Indian food. The atmosphere is really nice too - a warm contemporary feel and the manager (owner maybe?) is so sweet and gracious -he always makes you feel welcome. The flavors of the food really shine, their tandoori is spot on and very flavorful. The creaminess of the Tikka Masala is the best. Next time: Vindaloo!  I would add that the only reason I kept it to 4 instead of 5 stars is because the person clearing the table and pouring water was extremely sloppy. His attempt to be swift was cumbersome. It's not necessary to pile up every single plate in one swoop. It's noisy, distracting, sloppy with bits of food flying across the table. I really didn't care for that. He could quietly pick up a few plates, bring back to the kitchen which is only 10 feet away, and come back to get the rest. Other than that, you'll enjoy your meal!
author: Dorothy W.

description:
Oh my God, I feel re-inspired! I love Indian food but I had been in a rut with Indian until I tried Roti. I have eaten here four times now and each dish I try is excellent. Good menu, great food and good service in a nice location.

I would reccomend the Tandori Murgh and the Narvattan Korma.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Showed up Saturday night with no reservations.  The place was packed; but within 30 minutes, we got a table for two situated in a traffic bottleneck between 2 large parties. We got nudged and brushed several times by customers on their way to the restroom and wait staff dodging around us with sloshing water pitchers and plates of sizzling meats. Yikes! 

We relaxed after the arrival of our first course: a green salad with fennel and mustard vinaigrette that was way better than expected. Our mixed tandoori platter included lamb, chicken, salmon, prawn (only 1) and a tender portion of beef--all well-prepared and, with rice and naan, was plenty for two people. The frozen dessert with cardamom, pistachio and rose water was very good--rich, but not too sweet.  

Service was brisk but attentive; prices very affordable. We'll be back--but next time we'll ask for a table in the corner.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Went there for the first time last Friday. Here's why we would not go back: 1. The service is poor! 2. We waited a long time before we got our food. We almost walked out. 3. The food was not super delicious, considered we waited so long. We will not be going back. I LOVE Indian food. Travel to India often, so this was a major disappointment.
author: Cheddarj E.

description:
The place looks very nice, and the food is well presented.

But the service was unprofessional - the staff spent most of the time talking amongst themselves and virtually dropped the food at our table.

The food was OK, but slightly bland compared to other curry houses. We had no trouble turning up without a booking.
author: David S.

description: food was really good and the manager was really nice we waited a little longer to be seated so he gave us 20% off the bill no one does that
author: Nate K.

description: Chicken tikki masala and the bread basket. That's all you need to know. Feeds two generously!
author: Brenda B.

description: Just got a livingsocial deal $25 for $50 worth of food and drink at Roti! Best deal ever!!!
author: Linnea B.

description: Positively delectable Indian food prepared with artistry and subtlety. Another thing I love about this place is that many of their ingredients are organic. Love it!
author: Shalom O.

description:
Ouch, my wallet hurts!!  One app, two entrees and rice for $60???  Mediocre food, sketchy service, and ridiculous prices.  We even had to leave our table and wait by the front door to get our waitress to notice we needed our check.  

If you want good Indian food, look elsewhere!
author: Bonita H.

description:
They get five stars for letting us in at 10 at night when everything else on West Portal is closed, hahaha.
The food was pretty good. I was craving veggie curry and the palak paneer hit the spot. I tried my roomie's chicken tika masala, and that was tastey too.The staff was very nice and attentive. Even when they had a lil drama concerning an angry custmer that charged out of the restaurant, they kept their cool and continued to happily attend to their tables.
author: Chelena G.

description:
Being new to the area we've been on a mission to find good local places to eat.  We saw this place as we were exploring West Portal and it was always packed so one night we decided to give it a try.

We didn't have a reservation but we were seated after a short wait - despite the place being packed.  I liked to decor - modern, clean, not too crowded.  One thing we did notice was that it was really loud.  There were several large groups dining that evening so that might have been the cause but it was very loud and hard to have a normal conversation.

Service was merely ok - slow and not that attentive.  There were 2 waiters running around and the others and the hostess just seemed to be standing around.  After we were seated they kind of forgot about us so I had to snag one of the waiters to get our order in.  Once we got our order in our food came in about 15 min - not great but not too long.  We had to ask for refills in our water and again for the check.  

My reference for indian is Amber India in Mtn. View - Roti is not in that class but the food was good.  We ordered vegetable pakoras (very good - light and not greasy), chicken tikka masala (excellent - good sauce and plenty of well cooked chicken), aloo gobi (good flavor - veggies still had good texture), and naan (fresh and hot - just chewy enough).  Overall I was very pleased with the food.  It was pretty pricey for indian but the food was good and the portions were decent.

Overall I would have given it 4 stars on the strength of the food but the mediocre service and it being so loud I had to knock off a star.
author: Joon R.

description:
Its a nice place with good ambiance. However its short on space and looks cramped.

The food quality was good but not that great. I am big fan of Garlic Naan but I think I have eaten much better garlic naans at other places that this. Their garlic-basil naans were coated with losts of dry basil which was making it less tasty and they were not at all fluffy. But their raita was real good. If they improve little with naans and basic indian paneer dishes I think they will attract more good opinions.
author: Metal I.

description:
Yummy Indian food!   We had the garlic and basil nan, which was absolutely fantastic.  I probably ate half the order myself, and I'm not normally one to fill up on the nan - especially when there's so much other good stuff to enjoy.  But it was good!  And all you people talking about fluffy nan - what is that?  Nan is an Indian flatbread, cooked in the tandoori oven.  Are you thinking about focaccia or something?  Anyway, we also had the lamb special and it was amazing.  The lentils and spinach were really good too.  Everything was good and spicy with gorgeous flavors.   My husband and I both ate too much and got a tummy ache.  I'll be back!

By the way, I only gave four stars because the place is a bit loud and the tables by the door get really cold whenever the door is open.  Maybe a curtain around the entryway would help with that - and with the sound, too.
author: Catherine H.

description: I attempted to eat here on a Saturday night 20 minutes before the 11pm closing time. The turned me away because "last seating is at 10pm". So I guess the hours listed on Yelp and on the door are incorrect. I drove up from Pacifica because of the 11pm closing which is really 10pm closing.
author: Rick B.

description: I love Indian food and this place has some of the best Indian food I have ever eaten.  The staff is friendly and very accommodating.  I can't tell you the last time I walked out of a restaurant saying how great it was and raving about it to friends. Soooooo good!!!!!
author: mary c.

description:
CONS: Inattentive Service, Bland Food, Expensive Prices...Not worth going back.  PROS: One star for Nice atmosphere, but that's the only thing working for this place

So, I wanted to try this place for the longest time since it always looked packed and I remember even seeing this place advertised in the United Airlines magazine on the way back from a flight.  So I went there on a Sunday night for dinner, place wasn't too packed but we were waiting for at least twenty minutes for our food to arrive.  The waiter only came by one time to say "Sorry guys, your food is coming soon" before we waited another 10 minutes and the food finally came...It was sooo disappointing.  Indian food is supposed to make your mouth water with different spices and flavors...this food was bland and boring.  The palek paneer just tasted like spinach, no spices...the Chicken Vindaloo tasted just like spaghetti sauce with Raman Noodle seasoning...the WORST of all the Garlic Naan was cold and soggy in the middle but just crispy on the edges and overdone with basil and little garlic.  Service was really slow and even the check took forever to come.

It's one thing paying a little more for a nice atmosphere, but it another thing when the food is so unauthentic that I'm better off going to Tasty Curry for half the price.  It just pisses me off when people open a fancy restaurant in a nice neighborhood, dumb the food down to mediocre standards and get away with it.
author: Kris M.

description: Excellent Indian food!!!  Yummm!  Goat cheese naan!
author: Liss J.

description: This is hands-down the best indian food I've ever had!!!  Granted, I've only eaten here twice and both times had the Navratan Korma, but the way it taste I have a hard time trying something different.  It's to die for!!!   I've recently become a vegetarian and this place has a great menu for us (and even for you meat-eaters :-(  )  Next time I will try a different dish and review on it.  I think other people feel the same since there are not many empty seats.
author: Daniel W.

description:
nice location and decor. very pricey for what you get, i guess what youre really paying for is again, the location and decor. the food is okay, seemed a bit bland.. nothing crazy crazy good, but i prefer an authentic indian restaurant if you you want amazing indian food. 

i would go back for the sliced cashew rosewater(i think)  ice cream
author: Dae M.

description: do  you know what. I m not a big fan of indian food, sometimes they are little too spice for me, but this Mom and Papa Indian Bistro did it for me. I love the ambiance, the service and the best of all the food. The basil and garlic bread was marvelous, and the rice with chicken and spices made me a fan of this little local restaurant. Before I used to walk by and always was wondering why, why this place it is always packed, Thankfully my friend took me there and now I have my fever indian restaurant in the neighborhood. I ll be back and I strongly reccomend this place to anyone.
author: Alex M.

description: Hmm I have to update. I ate here again a few times and after eating at Clay Oven down the street (1/2 the price, bigger portions btw), I have to say they are JUST as good. Yes, Roti is more upscale and the food is great, but for the price i'd rather go to Clay Oven. Service is better there too, with Roti its a mixed bag. Sometimes good, sometimes really bad. Anyway, I hate to be spiteful, the food is still good. Its just not top choice for Indian food for me anymore.
author: Nicole L.

description: I've tried all the famed indian places in sf and have been less than thrilled with all of them. if you're a vegetarian, this is the place to go for delicious paneer makhani and veggie korma- amazingly complex and deliciously spiced food. a food ride- the way indian food should be.
author: Liz S.

description:
Now that I'm back to work in the medical field I'm enjoying all the perks that come with it. In addition to free/low cost dermatological services I am stoked to be the recipient of pharmaceutical company sponsored lunches!  Yay for free food from decent restaurants!
So today we had Roti. My boss did a few months of a Doctor's Without Borders kind of program in India so he KNOWS Indian food. He thinks Roti is the best. I think otherwise at this point. See, I was best friends with a girl whose father lived with a Punjabi woman and, as my boss agreed, the Punjabis make THE BEST Indian food.  Roti couldn't hold a candle to Karinjeet's cooking and I was really disappointed with my aloo gobhi. It wasn't the harmonious blend of potatoes, cauliflower and curry sauce that I'm accustomed to at many other lesser priced Indian establishments in SF. It was chunky and had a thin sauce, that could be described as spicy but not much else. The chicken biryani was good and so was the cucumber raita and naan bread but I make all judgements based on my favorite dish: aloo gobhi.  For the price of Roti, it should have been GREAT and it was just MEH.  I'm glad I didn't pay for it.  I may give Roti a second chance but not unless it's another free meal.
author: Jill D.

description: This is my very first review on Yelp. I will proceed to give positive reviews for the restaurants and businesses that I do like, however after our experience this evening at Roti I feel compelled to post this. We've been to Roti many times and have had good experiences, but this evening they were just a mess. The restaurant was busy (though not full) when we arrived and were told that they were having trouble with their reservation system. We had a reservation and were seated immediately. We ordered relatively quickly and our mango lassis and water were brought, however I could tell that our waiter was not in a great mood. We waited a long time before our waiter came over to say that our appetizers would be out soon. Well, soon was at least 10 minutes before our almost unidentifiable Assorted Appetizers arrived. The Vegetable Pakoras were a big stuck together, slightly burnt mess. All the while I continued to observe our waiter speaking to the cooks when at the open kitchen (at the rear of the restaurant) and he did not look pleased. The entire staff was running around like the Keystone Kops, although as my oft quoted significant other said, that would be an insult to the Keystone Kops. The only exception was the buffoonish manager who most of the time was standing at the cash register located at the rear bar. At one point another patron who was sitting quite close to him stood up and extended his arms outward to inquire as to what the hell was going on!! I could see that they too had been waiting an inordinate amount of time for their food. I applauded him! We still had another very long wait for dinner to arrive. Our waiter did come over to say that dinner would be out soon. I asked him what the problem was, and he said that the kitchen has been slow despite his requests. When dinner finally did arrive, ironically the Chicken Tandoori (which should be served sizzling) was barely warm after the long wait. When I told our waiter he offered to reheat it, but I was afraid that they would just dry it out. The Saag Gosht, Basmati rice and naan were all OK, but nothing memorable. I'm sure partly because we had such a long wait. By this time the restaurant was not crowded at all. The table of younger, overly loud and inappropriately dressed group (flip flops on a 40 something degree evening) behind us which arrived way after we did received all of their food quite quickly. Obviously, I DO NOT RECOMMEND Roti and WILL NOT BE GOING BACK! BTW, they didn't charge us for the appetizers.
author: Dan B.

description:
i had dinner here last night, and it was really good.  the neighborhood here is hidden and really cute.  who knew?  we arrived at 830 w/o a reservation and were told that the wait was half an hour.  the hostess took our cell phone # and said she would call us when they were ready, so we went to the irish pub across the street.  in less than 30 min, we received a call saying our table was ready.

we ordered the papadum, the tandoori roti, garlic & basil naan, cucumber raita, matter paneer and the channa masala.  everything was delicious and hit the spot, since it was already about 930 by the time we started eating.  the naan was sooo good.  for dessert, we had the gulab jamun, which came w/ 2 fried dumplings in syrup.  i would definitely come back to try some of the seafood dishes!
author: Helen T.

description: A friend and I recently went to Roti.  We arrived early.   Were seated right away.  We were not rushed.  Had a friendly and helpful waiter.  Enjoyed wonderful food.  And had to shout above the ever-increasing din just to be heard from across the table.  I loved all the food - the Naan was perfect, garlicy, crisp.  The rice was light and flavorful.  But if you have nothing to say to your dinner companions - this is the best place 'cause ya ain't gonna be heard anyway.  The decor was lovely though.
author: Jim S.

description: expensive for the kind of indian food that you can get at naan & curry, which is where i'd rather go than here. the naan here is really really oily too for some reason.
author: Anh P.

description: This is my second time here and it was even better than my first.  We made reservations and did not have to wait even a minute and the place was packed.  We ordered appetisers and got them very quickly and had just the right amount of time after we fished them before we got our main dishes.  The food was wonderful.  We had samosas, chicken tika masala, tandori platter and a spinach curry (I can't remember the name).  Everything was amazing!  OH, and the nan was delicious.  I highly recommend this place.
author: Sean O.

description: ok as a brown man I have to say that this is the worst place to get Biryani. I can only speak for their Biryani because thats what me and my girlfriend had last night. The meat was not cooked well, it was dry and the biryani tasted like the cook was someone who wasn't familiar with the brown culture. I think if this was a $5 meal I wouldn't care as much but 2 biryani's and some naan with Kulfi for $48 is not worth it. You can go to Pakwan and have it all for less than $25.
author: Zaid K.

description: As a connoisseur of the national English dish, chicken vindaloo, I've muttered darkly about the dearth of a decent upscale Indian in SF. No longer - the new Roti get's the naan. Great Bengen Bharta and Palak Paneer. Decor impressed the missus and you won't smell like you cooked the food. They can be a little careless processing orders - sometimes we've been surprised at what we've been served..but always delighted. PS. I went with a couple of Indian friends and the food wasn't spicy enough for their tastes, but there again, I don't rate the hole in the wall places they rave about.
author: Simon R.

description: Considering that I didn't pay for the food I would have given this place 5 stars. It is really nice inside, good service, and incredible indian food. I know i'll be back here again and when the price is factored into my review i'll give it 4 stars, so thats what i'm doing. We got goat cheese nann it was packed with cheese and had extra on the outside. We were with a big group of people so I had an assortment of different foods I can't remember them all. Not a good place to come to all the time because of the price, but it is a great place for a nice dinner.
author: Ali S.

description:
It's an impressively swank-looking place when you walk in, and then you notice that most of the entrees are in the $15 range, and you understand why.  Note that that's a-la-carte; rice and naan are extra.  But hey - I'm not against expensive food; my favorite restaurant in SF is Gary Danko.  The question is - is it worth it?

Well, I'd say no.  The chicken korma was really fantastic; rich hearty sauce with a wonderfully smoky aroma not unlike a good smoked gouda.  High quality breast-meat chicken from the tandoor.  This was good stuff.  
Rice was thoroughly seasoned, but not to the point of absurdity and was tasty.  
Naan was less impressive, but as we got ours takeout, I won't count this against them; naan just doesn't travel well.  
The murgh masala, on the other hand (chicken curry) looked like the Exxon Valdez crashed into it.  The top was nothing but pools of oil/ghee/something that was really quite revolting.  Don't get me wrong - I like me some gee-liciousness, but I don't want to see it pooling on my food.  I managed to spoon out a good tablespoon or so before eating.  Given that this isn't one of the menu items listed as involving butter, I'm a bit scared as to what they'd look like.  Flavor?  Eh, certainly not anywhere near as spicy or interesting as I'd been hoping (given the list of garlic & ginger & peppercorn in the description), and the chicken was of somewhat lower quality than that in the korma - decidedly more chunks of fat throughout it.  Maybe you like chicken fat; me - not so much.
At least the included chutney and mint sauces were good.

Overall, good enough I'll try them again, and see if I get a different experience, but not good enough for a glowing recommendation.
Oh - and if you're told that your takeout order will take 25 minutes, it'll probably take less.  We came back after 20, and it was already sitting out waiting for us.  And as the aforementioned naan doesn't travel well... the less time waiting, the better.

FYI, 2 entrees, 1 rice, 2 naan: $33
author: Don H.

description: This is my favorite Indian restaurant in the city so far.  My professor took me and her other assistants out to dinner.  I wasn't expecting something so great for West Portal... It was absolutely delicious, great service, and they have a really nice ambiance.  We had to work on students' grades and it was quiet enough to talk.  Luckily our prof was paying, so we had all kinds of naan, appetizers and sooo much food :)  I would go back ALL the time, if only it wasn't in West Portal!
author: Laura W.

description: What happened to this place? We were here last about four years ago and loved it, though we usually went to their branch in Burlingame. Took our son recently and it was awful! Kachumber salad messed up with mustard? Overcooked tandoori prawns. Never again. Makes me sad.
author: Judith H.

description: I was surprised to be able to get a table immediately on a thursday night without reservations.  There were some people however waiting for a table after we were seated.  The staff was friendly and attentive.  The food is delish!  Yes a very modern indian food place, however it hasn't lost its favors.  It's a must to return.
author: Kim N.

description: Great food, wonderful location and fantastic decor!  Besides parking being a little challenging and the acoustics not really allowing for easy conversation this place ROCKS!!!  I certainly recommend the navrattan korma, any kind of naan, mango lassi and the gulab jamun!  It is a vegetarian friendly place and has quick and friendly service.  I've been here many times and will go many more.  There are tons more things on the menu I would suggest that all should try but you should just check it out for yourself.  You can also ask for more or less spice.  Plus they have different specials each month!  Make your reservations ahead of time if you want to be sure to get a seat.
author: J. C.

description: I am not used to paying so much for Indian food.  It cost about $9 for the veggie curries, $10-14 for chicken and lamb, $17 for kebabs, over $9 for rice dishes, $3 for regular naan but up to $5 for the special flavored ones.  $5 for a mango lassi.  They do offer a veggie dinner priced at $18 per person, which sounded like the best deal on the menu.  The raita was the best that I have ever had in my life but I probably won't go back here because I can get the same quality of food (albeit not in as clean and trendy surroundings) at Naan n' Curry and Shalimar at half the price.  This is important because when I get Indian, I like to get a lot of different things and totally pig out.  At Roti, I just can't do that.
author: Tabatha Y.

description: The only reason I didn't give Roti 5 stars is because it's expensive for what you get, but the food is excellent and very clean. the other good thing is that you dont smell like curry when you get home! ok, this is what we had this time around and we really have tried everything on the menu and everything is good and the quality tops any indian: anyway, this time around we had murg makhani, which is yummy, the sauce on it is exceptional we licked it all up with some naan we ordered, and i do mean evrything! Then, we tried the dal-saag(lentils with spinach) which also was great and it had a bit of a spicy kick at the end and of course some of the best plain rice you could ever have and naan. I really like this place even though i hate that the crowd is not diverse... but I guess it is in West Portal...
author: Chris D.

description:
the bread basket with the cucumber raita is awesome.  the rest, it's all pretty generic.  nothing super special, but not boring either.  can't ever go wrong with lamb or some other mixed curry.  and the meals are always super filling.

i was upset one time though when i went to order the rice pudding and they were out
author: spiff e.

description: Coming back from a 3 week stay in India and reviewing Roti Indian Bistro may not fair, but here goes... what worked at Roti was the clean decor, color photographic prints of India (Varanasi), and the amiable staff. All these things bring about a pleasant eating environment. But what didn't work for Roti was the food. I've had better (and less expensive) at Naan-and-Curry, the buffet at Great India, and even this dingy spot in Jaipur for a few rupee notes. The Mutter Paneer was a meager portion and the worst that I've ever tasted in San Francisco, North America, or India. The garlic naan was the only thing that stood out as above average and that's worth 2 Yelp stars.
author: Be N.

description: This is one of the best Indian food restaurants that I have ever been to!  The balance of the spices has been perfect in every dish we've ordered.  They are flavorful without having to resort to spiciness to hide bad meat or lack of culinary skills.  I use the chana masala as a gauge to judge a restaurant, and this place served the best chana masala I have ever ordered.  Another good gauge is the naan - which this place prepares perfectly!  The ambiance is very modern, with huge photographs of India on the walls.  I am pretty sick of tacky old-school Indian decor, so this place is a breath of fresh air.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Bistro Roti is the victim of its own success. Spurred either by trying to accommodate too many people or by greed, they've jammed the tables together to the point that the servers can't reached nearby tables. On a Sunday evening, we were wedged into a table so close to others that I couldn't pick up my utensils without bumping into other diners' chairs. The noise level is deafening. When our server couldn't even begin to lean in to ask us about our beverage order, I had had it. We stood up to leave, and only then did the manager acknowledge that there was a problem. From my past experiences, the food is terrific here; but the less-than-stellar service and overcrowded layout mean that Bistro Roti is an unpleasant dining experience.
author: Rich W.

description: YUM!!!  Our favorite place for Indian food!  Nothing run-of-the-mill here...this is gourmet all the way.  Having sampled Indian food all over the world (including India), we can honestly say that this is the best of the best.  Returned for the nth time to try dishes we've never had here before.  This is consistently the best Indian food ever.  Tried the Murgh Malai...the chicken was succulent, fresh, and perfectly spicy. For lamb lovers, the Gosht Madras, cooked southern Indian-style with coconut sauce was delicious!  The lamb is lean and tender.  For cheese lovers, the goat cheese naan bread (served with a generous extra dollop of goat cheese, was creamy and so tasty.  All very good with a glass of the excellent Barbera.  The helpings are generous, the decor tasteful, and the music is soft so that diners can converse.  The greatest pleasure of all here is the warm and hospitable owner who is attentive to the comfort of every diner present, both at the time of seating and during the meal.   When chicken was served (instead of the lamb we ordered) in the Madras sauce, he gladly returned with the lamb, and treated us to 2 glasses of after-dinner dessert wine for the mistake.  We can't say enough about this gem of a restaurant, and we will be back again.
author: Donna A.

description: Over rated and over priced. The restaurant is pretty and the service was fine, but I go to restaurants for the food, duh. The food at Roti is, for lack of a better word, "Gringo-ethnic" - the food looks good, but is bland.
author: Chris R.

description:
okay so i technically didn't dine in the restaurant but i did order food for pick up...

upon calling i checked out their website. i was already craving for indian food and the gorgeous pictures on their site made me want it even more than ever. so i called up and ordered veggie samosas, roti tandoori (mix), chicken tikka masala (a must when ordering indian), saag aloo (spinach and potatoes) and roti bread basket. oh yeah, and rice.

they were quick with the order and it only took them 20 minutes to have everything ready. they even called to let me know when my food was ready to be picked up. and the person on the phone recommended the saag aloo dish to me and was super friendly on the phone.

anyway on to the food... i really liked everything except the tandoori. this tandoori mix consists of lamb, chicken, some kinda sausage, one prawn and salmon. eh... it was didn't taste right. i'm not sure how to explain it. the prawn was the only thing that was good. i wouldn't recommend this dish except for the prawn. the chicken tikka masala however was very very delicious. flavorful and not too spicy. the bread basket... well lets just say that there was a lot of roti go around. the onion one was best. and the veggie samosa... it's a big one. but once again it was very delicious and i ate it all up. on the rice... well it was just perfect. it was cooked just right. not sticky not overcooked or undercooked. it was well damn good rice.
author: Mei N.

description:
...

dude, wat the... did we just order upscale chinese?

the prawn vindaloo and chicken jezfreti-something, taste like freakin chinese food, at 1.5 times the cost...

regular naan was flimsy, unflaky after a while, like a limp quesadilla...

garlic naan, seriously lacked garlic punch...

indian lemonade, was just regular lemonade, slightly sweeter, with bits of mint...

basmati rice, was basmati rice, can't go wrong there...

-4 stars, overall lackluster, subpar indian/chinese food...
+1 star, refreshing ice water, and a staff member really loved my cologne...  8D

every time, i keep picking the wrong restaurants, dui bu qi!!
author: Ethan L.

description:
Best Indian food in the city. hands down. happy to make the food really spicey or mild, and is the only place i've found where i'm consistently happy with every dish i get. 

there tends to be a big crowd though (for good reason) so just keep that in mind. great staff as well. even with some large parties in house, they worked with us, even without a reservation, to get us a table in under 15 minutes.
author: Diane W.

description: I really like Indian food but I eat it rarely because it's extremely rich and filling.  The ambiance at this place is top notch.  I really like the chic decor especially in the bathroom and the cushions on the window seats are pretty.  The variety of Naan to choose from (different flavors and toppings on Indian flat bread aka Naan) is great.  This is a nice place if you have a hankering for Indian and want to impress your lunch or dinner companions.  It's much fancier and a bit pricier than the dime a dozen Indian restaurants dotted throughout the city but worth it.  The food tastes very fresh and the dipping sauces for the Samosas are wonderful.  Definitely ecommended!!
author: A H.

description:
I am surpirsed at all the positive reviews of Roti. I work in the South Bay and frequent the great selections of Indian eateries during lunch with coworkers (many of whom are Indian.) Perhaps my pallet has gotten to be too authentic. 

I was very excited that when I learned a upscale Indian restaurant is opening in my neighborhood. The "good" Indian restaurants in the City (i.e Pakwan and Shalimar; really Pakistani though) are all no-frills, hole-in-a-wall places. However, I was thoroughly disappointed when my wife and I visited Roti a couple of months ago. The food was incredibly blend. The vegetable korma seemed like was made with a bag frozen carrots and peas from Safeway (and it probably was). The check was on par with the nicer India restaurants in the South Bay (e.g. Amber), but the food has a long way to go. 

Maybe the restaurant is catering to the primarily non-Indian crowd with its blend seasoning. Note that its other location is in Burlingame.
author: S C.

description: Winning at Double Dare is more than just physical challenges.  You have to be smart, too.  So believe me when I tell you that the smart move is not eating at Roti Indian Bistro.  The food there is over-priced and doesn't provide the high quality nutrients that you need when you're training to win.  Take my advice and spend your money at one of the city's many cheaper and better Indian restaurants.  With the money you save, you can build an extra Double Dare obstacle for your home obstacle course.
author: David C.

description: I've lived really close to Roti for about a year now and finally ate there this past week. I thought the food was decent but we had really bad service in the beginning. We got seated right as a big rush was clearing out it seemed, but honestly it took at least 5 minutes to even get our waters. The papadum was tasty, though not as spicy as I like it. The vegetable pakoras & eggplant slices were good but were a little too fried for me. The mixed tandoori gives you a chance to try several different things of which I found the ground lamb kebabs to be the best. I'd probably return here, but would want to come at a time when they had their act a little more together.
author: Todd F.

description: One of the best Indian places in the city.  One of the few that uses organic ingredients.  Very few places know how to make Dahl and they do a great job.  The breads are amazing as well as most of their dishes.  If you've ever had home cooked Indian food, it's very similar.  Usually easy to park around there also.  It's a little far from everything else unless you live around West Portal.
author: Mitch A.

description:
roti is great. incredibly spicy, tasty food. delivers to the mission, and is quick.

i can't remember whether i thought the food was "traditional/authentic" but i DO remember beign greatful that i was delivered to my door and wasn't typical crappy greasy delivery style food.

yay roti.
author: Erika Y.

description: Maybe it was just what I ordered (chicken tikka masala), but I wasn't that impressed. Lacked flavor, and kind of felt like the Pasta Pomodoro of Indian cuisine. I've had better, cheaper, Indian food at dive places in the city.
author: Shirin M.

description: Just had dinner for the first time at Roti - it was delicious. I recommend the okra and the daal. We also had the naan with goat cheese, it was tasty. I liked that all the vegetables were fresh and cooked just enough. We had very good service. This place is busy so make a reservation or plan on waiting. We were a table for two and we waited 20 minutes. Definitely worth the wait.
author: T O.

description: The food is OK, but "Bistro" doesn't mean they should charge as if they were a French restaurant. Definitively too pricey. Mango Lassi will soon be charged as a cocktail.
author: Nestle L.

description:
Exceptional service and fantastic food!  
Went yesterday with my family and we were treated very well.  
I got there at around 6:15pm and waited for the rest of my family to arrive. (They were late half an hour)
I was sitting in the restaurant with my 2 year old daughter and the owner came by and told the waiter to get us
a thin piece of bread with two dipping sauces.  They were yummy and my daughter loved it.   Another 5 minutes pass and
the owner then bought over to us a small cup of mango drink.  That too was delicious.  Another 5 - 10 minutes pass and
again the owner comes around and asks if he could get my daughter some rice.  I said "no that's okay we can wait but thank you!"
The owner insisted and then he bought my daughter a small bowl of rice along with what looked like yogurt with cucumber.  
Finally a few more minutes pass and my family arrives.   We all sit down and the owner brings my son the same yogurt drink that 
my daughter and I drank.  We were not charged for any of this food.  What generosity!  

My family and I had a great time at the restaurant and even my wife commented on the exceptional service we received.  
Not only that but the food was some of the best Indian food I've tasted anywhere.  I've been to Indian restaurants in East Bay,
South Bay and one in SF but this one has the best tasting dishes I've ever had.
author: Alex H.

description:
This is kind of overdue, but I wanted to share the level of service received here.  I went with two friends on a pretty busy Friday night.  One of the staff  came to our table and gave us an appetizer to try on the house, and later some additional sauces, all delicious!  My friend ordered one of the daily specials and when we were finishing this same staff came to our table to see how our meal was.  My friend said, honestly that the special was good, but not great, as everything else was.  He listened to her feedback and then when the check came, her entree was taken off, courtesy of the owner, who our waiter told us, was the low key guy we had been talking to!  
And I need to emphasize, I tried her dish, and it was good, we're not talking dog food here by any means.  Just next to some of the other amazing dishes it paled a little.  I had a fabulous meal, would have returned here anyway, and especially would now!  What service and attention to your customers, along with great food!
author: stephanie m.

description: This place was okkk. a little more on the expensive side for the size of their portions. I had a birthday dinner here with some friends and nothing we ordered really stood out. I haven't tried much indian restaurants here in the city so i was curious to try this one. I heard Rotee on haight was much better, so i'm gonna try that one next time.
author: Rosalynn D.

description: Me and hubby's ultimate FAVORITE restaurant.  Never thought my favorite restaurant would be Indian!  See you soon Roti!
author: Anna B.

description: Meh is right. For the high prices, we expected much better. 2 entrees, one rice, one naan, and one beer totalled $50. It was worth half that. Roti is a pleasant enough place to have dinner, and the food is decent. But it's a bad value, and we won't be returning.
author: Presto G.

description: Some favorites:  chicken korma, goat cheese naan, and the chana masala kicked ass!!!  A good alternative to the greasier hole-in-the-walls which, while lovely and endearing, sometimes leave you wanting a nicer setting.  Great food and wonderful service.
author: P-Rock F.

description: The kitchen staff evidently don't like Indian food which is why they serve up watery and bland stodge. The best in the City? True. The others suck more than than Roti...
author: Jo M.

description:
nothing but love for this place. two of my roomates work here and i believe they have managed to bring just about everything on the menu home at one point ( an extensive menu, might i add)....so ive had the glorious opportunity to try many things on the menu.


everything is grand and the cozy little place is beautiful lit with bright torquoise fitxtures and orange textiles. lots to choose from (both for veggies and meatavores)...and the garlic naan is to die for.
author: sarah f.

description: I could come here just for the Roti Calamari.  Perfectly fried - best fried calamari I've ever had.  As for the main stuff...the bread basket and curry were just okay.  I've had better...in cheaper places.
author: Dylan's Aunt E.

description: This used to be one of our favorite places. We went there a couple nights before our wedding with our whole family. Back when Andrew was host, we went there for all of our big dinners and just had wonderful times. And did I mention the food was fantastic?
