But over the last couple years, the place has gone downhill a bit. Even though we still love going there, the service isn't the same, and the atmosphere has suffered. In addition, they've made some sort of changes to their Tikka Masala for the worse. Still, we can't stop going there. We just miss the good 'ol days.
author: Zack M.

description: Great food and larger portions than most indian places.  It does cost a little more than the average Indian restaurant however there is definitely more meat.  Since I am a carnivore, I love this.  The favor is fresh and tasty. Be sure to try more than just the tikka masala as there more to Indian food than that creamy sauce.  It's good but there were so many other good dishes there.
author: Ginny M.

description: If you are looking for upscale Indian food here is your spot.  The location is very good lots of parking and the neighborhood is great for walking.  We did not have reservations and took about 20 minutes to get a table, then it took another 10 minutes to get recognized by our server.  The menu is very big and not very cheap.  Warning do not go there hungry as it took almost a half an hour to get our order the excuse the server gave us was"everything is made to order"  what he meant to say was we have a really tiny kitchen and can only cook one order at a time.  Overall the food is very good, the serve so so and the decor is nice.  If I'm in the area I would stop back in but I would not make a special trip there again.
author: Prescott R.

description: This place is great if you're looking for an Indian restaurant with a refined atmosphere.  According to my wine connoisseur dinner companions, they had a pretty sophisticated wine list.  The food was also pretty tasty, and I'd recommend trying their feta cheese naan.  The only negative was that the portions were pretty small considering the cost ($10+ per entree).
author: Jon T.

description: By far the best Indian food I've had in the Bay Area. Being Indian, Indian restaurants have always disappointed me due to either lack of flavor (diluted to suit the taste of the masses) or greasy with the usual bad service. Roti Bistro is amazing! Service is excellent, and the food....oh god  I'm sitting here with my stomach fool but still salivating just thinking about it. You can't go wrong with Roti Bistro.
author: Amit V.

description: The food was yummy and I was impressed with the bubbly atmosphere at 8 pm on a Sunday night. There just aren't enough good Sunday night spots in the city. I had the Chicken Tikka which was good . . . and the garlic naan was to die for!!! Yum. Its not the hole in the wall where you come out smelling like curry . . . but if you want a pleasant dinner over some good Indian food, and a nice buzz in the background I'd recommend this and would go back for sure.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
yummy!
roti was delicious - wonderful chewy texture. we tried plain and goat's cheese - both great. we shared a vergetarian thali and that was enough for both of us (we weren't super hungry).  
the chai was lovely too. and the rice pudding dessert was divine.
service was excellent, price reasonable - very happy customers.
author: Christine N.

description: With Roti and its neighbors Bursa Kabob and the remodeled movie theater, this section of West Portal is my new favorite part of town. I was impressed by the service at Roti, but more importantly, by the food. Everything was amazing, including the lamb popsicles, chicken tikka masala, onion kulcha, basmati pulao and mango chutney. One of my best dining experiences in recent memory.
author: Jason B.

description: Nice ambiance, but that's about it, I mean they are not even the best Roti (see Rotee) in the city and at about double the cost.  The service left a lot to be desired, our waitress took our drink order, asked us if we wanted appetizers, then didn't come back for like 20min, and she touched me.  The food was good, but not as good as the better Indian places in the city.  They do have a tandori fish that is really good though.  I probably won't go back even though it's really close to my house.
author: David P.

description: I always thought that West Portal Village is this hidden gem in San Francisco. It has that one long street with all the great restaurants...all though I forget it's there because it's so far and when I get there, it feels like the 'burbs but better. Derek and I kept hearing wonderful things about Roti so it was on the top of our list of things to try. Food was, as I like to say "YUMO!". Unfortunately I don't know the names of these foods (my bad), but if you like spice - you got it here. The food was rich but not in a greasy way. The service was GREAT - except the waiter forgot my tea - but other than that, they were very attentive.
author: Jen R.

description:
I have actually avoided this restaurant for many years because it's so fancy - I have traditionally had the best experience at simpler Indian restaurants with "charm" and history. I tried it due to the reviews here and was delighted. It was definitely among the best Indian food I've ever had. I ordered take-out, apparently, enough for 4 people, but it was so good I ate almost all of it myself! The garlic/basil naan was the best naan I've ever had. The vegetable bryani rice, also, was the best ever. The lamb curry was fantastic though the curry was a little on the watery side (this is the primary reason for 4 and not 5 stars), and the benghan bharta (sp?) eggplant curry was fantastic. The service is slow, I had to wait a long time to pick up my take out order even though I had ordered it 30 minutes earlier. The prices are the highest I have ever seen for Indian food. That meal cost almost $50. However, on the menu, they indicate a preference for local and organic ingredients including organic meats. And, I could tell the ingredients were top quality.

12/13/07 downgrading from 4 stars to 2 stars. The first meal here was amazing. The second meal was OK. The third time, I ordered extra food to freeze some and have as dinners during the week. What a mistake. The quality was so poor that I had to throw away almost 2/3 of everything I purchased. The garbanzo beans were cheap quality from a can that had been sitting out too long and gone rancid, in a curry sauce that was flavorless. The chicken was hard and only white meat, not tender, in a curry that also lacked any flavor. The lamb curry was OK. The spinach and potato had to be thrown away because the quality was so bad. 

This place is unbelievably busy. My guess is that they are motivated by pure greed and in a desire to make as much money as possible, as fast as possible, they've cut quality to the minimum so they can push out more and more food. That's the impression I have. Also, my take out orders have always been late, past the 40 minute timeline they promise.
author: Eater S.

description: mmmmmm...tasty Indian food. Dishes with the right about of spice to have you grasping at your water cup. Then the second the hot spice subsides you're so ravenous for another bite of yummy lamb, chicken or beef dishes here that its impossible to control yourself. If I lived closer, I would come here time and time again.
author: Laura G.

description:
Came here with a friend on a Thursday night.  The place was packed but we were seated quickly.
Had their Assorted Appetizers: one samosa (tasty and filling), two veggie pakoras (lots of spices and greasy, like it should be), and one lentil wafer with sauces on the side.
Also had Half order of their Tandoori Murgh.  Even though it was a half order, it was plenty.  It came out on a sizzling plate full of onions and bell peppers.  It reminded me of the sizzling plates Korean restaurants serve their ribs on.  Anyhow, I was surprised by how tender and flavorful the chicken was.  I was expecting a yogurty taste b/c the menu says it was marinated in yogurt, but it had none.  It was really good.
We also had Saag Gosht--lamb and spinach.  This was the best plate, I think.  I usually don't like lamb but this one was really tender and the spinach/cilantro complemented it well.
We had all of this with one wheat and one regular naan.  Couldn't tell which one was which.
Warning: you will come out smelling like smoke and your clothes will reek of it for days.  
Overall great experience.
author: sarisha h.

description: The tandoori is just OK nothing to brag about nothing real authentic here. You can call it Americanized Indian food  for American only
author: jose m.

description: For the most part, I enjoyed my meal at Roti's. But if i'm going to pay 34 dollars per person for the Roti feast, their signature meal, I should at least get 1 prawn per person. We also only got one samosa, but that's okay since it was large enough to split among two people. Unfortunately, it's kind of difficult to split 1 prawn. Besides that, the servings were plentiful and delicious. C'mon guys, for 34 bucks a person, you can throw 1 more prawn on the serving plate.
author: Jim R.

description: Slipped into Roti 12/230/2011 and we were treated to excellent service, a charming staff including the Maitre'D and the chef/owner.  We had lovely pankora, and vegetable samosas which were crisp and not greasy, yummy spinach with a type of cheese and mixed Tandori to die for.  Everything was perfectly cooked, wonderfully spiced.  We had a complimentary raita with our rice and complimentary drinks after the meal.  They demonstrated to us back in the kitchen how they cooked Nan in the Tandoori oven by slapping it against the wall and watched it bubble and then ate it hot from the stove. An excellent meal in very pleasant atmosphere.
author: Liz S.

description:
I'm with Michael D. - we'd love to make Roti our neighborhood dinner destination of choice, since the food is fabulous, but two times out of three now we've had spotty service.  One time it was a (probably) new waiter, a little confused and slow, but with good intentions. Second time the waitress filled my BF's wine glass barely half full; later we spotted her taking a break outside as we waited into the 20th minute for our check. The maitre d' seems to pick up the slack sometimes, but it shouldn't be that way. 

Yeah, you can get pretty damn good Indian food in the city for less - Naan-n-Curry comes to mind - but Roti does take the quality up a notch. You can taste it in the texture of the naan, the spice balance in the sauces, the wine list. The decor also makes it a much better place for a date. If only they'd give their waitstaff a talking-to.
author: Cynthia S.

description: Friends took us here on a recent trip to SF. Food and service were great. Wish I could remember all we had, but we were a large party and sampled many, many dishes. All were very good. The atmosphere was very comfortable and stylish (compared to most Indian restaurants).
author: Brian M.

description:
Not really ever having Indian food before, we weren't too sure what to expect. But since a couple of us were on an Indian food kick, and with a recommendation from a friend, we decided to give this place a try.

If this is what Indian food is like, we're definitely fans! 
To start, we ordered the assorted appetizers which included a samosa, vegetable pakoras, and papadum. We didn't care too much for the papadum, the samosa was good, but we all like the vegetable pakoras -- especially with the mint chutney or plum sauce they served with it. 
For our entrees, we got the Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Vindaloo, and the Lamb Korma, along with an order of Roti's Basmati Pulao (rice) as well as an order of Garlic & Basil and an order of Onion Kulcha roti (breads).
At first we were hesitant, trying everything with caution and helping ourselves to modest servings, but all of it was so tasty that we quickly threw a munch! The Lamb Korma was a recommendation from the server, and a good one at that! It had this delicious, creamy sauce. The Chicken Vindaloo was really good too! It was pretty spicy, but it was so delicious you can't stop eating it, even if you start to sweat from the heat, as one of us did, haha.

The service could've been a bit better though. Eating such spice-full dishes, our water glasses were often empty and we had to wait awhile for drink refills. And, when the restaurant started to get busier, we saw less and less of our server.

Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our dinner. The food was super tasty, we left full and satisfied, and we're happy to say that we're definitely down with Indian food now!
author: Crys L.

description: Great Food.  Naan is excellent.  I was not much of an Indian food person until I ate here.  I've been back many times.  The only problem is that the parking is so tight!  Go around the corner into the residential neighborhood to the west and the walk is about a block.
author: Dan D.

description: We live in the neighborhood and do take out at least twice a month. The food is really good. I have had curry all over the city and in London and this is the best. The service is not the best. They have a really high turn over of staff. We had a bad experience trying to order. I emailed the restaurant and they sent an apology and a 50.00 gift certificate. That is good service. If you order take out be prepared for weird questions like " how many people are eating for this order?" Like that is any of their business???  One time the wanted me to pay ahead of time. Worth putting up for the yummy  curry. Pretty spicy but I am a petite flower.
author: J J.

description:
We've eaten Roti several times and the food has been consistently good.  Roti's Dal Makhani and Dal Saag both excellent.  The fish korma is also good - although make sure to get the white fish and not the salmon.  Tried Roti's lamb popsicles   - they sounded so great on the menu but ended up too dry for my taste.  The channa masala was nothing to write home about.  We've also tried several other curries and the palak panneer - all fine.  Wasn't impressed with their naan.

Though all in all I enjoyed this restaurant, I found Roti kind of pricey for Indian food -- maybe you're paying for the restaurant's decor/ambiance and polite service?  I much prefer some of the places in Berkeley - Vik's Chaat House, Ajanta (also pricey but sooo good) and even Khana Peena.  Also think Star India in SF serves up consistent and good food at lower prices.

Our takeout service was pretty disorganized.  Our order took over 45 minutes and adding rice and naan at the last second added another 20 minute wait.  

Having said that, it's good food and convenient when visiting family, so we'll be there again.
author: Junko G.

description: Big Dog and I eat our fair share of curry and have some authentic favorites (Vik's) but are happy to try modern Indian cuisine (Ajanta) as well.  We recently went to Roti on W. Portal on advice of friends.  We had seekh kabab, a yellow dal curry, and chicken tikka, naan, rice, raita, etc. - our basic - and it was good.  Not great, but I've had a lot worse.  So they get 4 stars for food.  They lose two stars for the incredibly loud (although pretty) dining room and the incredibly poor service.  Dishes were literally whisked off our table while Big Dog was still eating from the plate, fork poised in the air!  We had to tell the staff to NOT take plates that still had food on them.  We felt rushed and it was not pleasant.  We won't be back.
author: Liquid Kitty O.

description: I'm not a fan of Indian food.. but when my boyfriend brought me here!! Oh man did i love it.. we ordered Naan Bread, chicken tikki Marsala, saffron rice, lamb chops( spicy n very tender! cooked to perfection), and prawns!! yummmy.. Cant wait to go back!
author: Shirl C.

description: Roti is the type of place where you love the food, get friendly staff, and ogle the cute servers. And yet, I've never had a "this was a kickass place" reaction. And I've eaten here on more than one occasion. I will say, I love the wine selection! Big fan of the specials. Every time I go in, there's a special that peaks my interest and someone at our table chooses one. It's always delicious to the nth degree!
author: Elizabeth Z.

description: This is usually where I take friends to eat when I'm craving Indian food and want to bring them somewhere with a nice ambiance. West Portal area is great because parking usually isn't a hassle. Their hosts and waiters are very friendly. I love their okra,  garlic naan, mango lassi, and wonderful desserts.
author: vicki c.

description: The service is good and Roti has nice decor. If you're looking for a Naan and Curry type of place, this isn't it. The food was slightly uneven for me. The bread plate is worth the price, but tasted more like pizza than naan and roti. The navrathan korma had the best flavor as its ingredients were varied. The chicken saag was relatively bland.
author: Ellen S.

description: The positive reviews are all true!  Check this place out if you're in the neighborhood, or even if you aren't (fairly easy parking or easy Muni access). Great food, service, ambiance & wine list. Yes, it is pricey, but what Indian restaurant isn't (exception- Naan-n-curry). Yes, San Francisco has several great Indian restaurants, but I will go out of my way to come back here.
author: Cherie H.

description:
This was by far the most expensive onion salad we had. They charged $6 for a small onion salad - 2 plates. This is usually free in all the indian restaurants that I have visited. This is just plain overcharge. Also the order took almost an hour to arrive

The food did not had any taste (Except for the Naan and Biryani)
author: T P.

description: I ended up coming here for Valentine's day dinner. The atmosphere  was pretty nice. The service was excellent. The food was OK. We had the chicken pakoras, chicken tikka masala, chicken biryani, and a garlic basil naan. I really liked the texture of the naan but I think it wasn't garlicky enough. The chicken pakoras were basically spicy chicken strips. The chicken biryani was pretty good but I honestly think that although the chicken tikka masala is different from Naan n' Curry, it's not as good as theirs. I honestly don't know if the nice ambiance and stellar service is enough to make me come back.
author: Diane M.

description: my love for indian food started with Chutney.. of course I only know to order the "safe" dishes such as chicken tikka masala, biryani and naan. Roti did not fail to impress. Sadly, I had to tack off one star for the prices.
author: Nancie T.

description:
i never uttered the following words in an indian restaurant before: "what would you recommend off of the wine list".  the surprising-ness of that statement would lay the groundwork for what would be a stellar meal.  do not come in here expecting to pay pakwan/lahore karahi prices as you'll never get over that fact.  just go in expecting to have great food made with great ingredients!

for wine i had the escudo rojo from chile and i was very satisfied with it.  everyone tried out some wine too and was very happy.  the wife also got some mango lassi and, gosh darn it, it was good!

food food food.  we could not stop talking about how good everything was.  for appetizers we got samosas, the appetizer sampler and the calamari pakoras.  the samosas were awesome!  the tasted fresh and the potatoes inside were shredded rather than in chunks.  the sampler consisted of papadum, veggie pakoras and another samosa.  the papadum was standard fare but the pakoras were pretty good though it could've used a tad bit more salt.  and then there was the calamari pakoras.  WOW!  this was perfect and this plate was utterly demolished.  i would go back here just for this!

for entrees we got the CTM, bhuna ghost and the paneer makhni.  the CTM was different than most CTMs as it wasn't as creamy.  so while i'll say pakwan still ranks up top my CTM sauce list, roti's chicken itself was A LOT better.  the chicken was well seasoned and cooked.  the sauce itself was still very good.  the bhuna ghost was excellent too (this was a lamb dish).  the paneer makhni's sauce was reminiscent of a CTM-like sauce.  the paneer was cooked well and the dish was a hit.  we saw that there was a chicken makhni on the menu too so we wondered if that would turn out.  next time!

for naans, we got 2 orders of plain naan, 1 order of the garlic basil naan and 1 of the goat cheese naan.  the plain naan i heard was good.  the garlic naan was incredible from what i hear.  but i focused solely on the goat cheese naan.  this was incredible and worked very well with the dishes.  the naan was stuff with an extremely mild goat cheese so it fit perfectly with all of our entrees.

the decor of the place is nice and warm though one big pic that was in the back of the dining hall kept on freakin me out but that's ok.  the service was very good.  our waiter, joakim, did a great job in helping out w/ the wine selection and always made sure that we were doing just fine.

can't wait to go back to try out some of the other items.  also, i want to check out the west portal area.  this was my first time in that area and it looks to be an untapped resource for culinary excursions!
author: Swarup B.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect from Roti because it had many great reviews overall, but the complaints seemed to use "pretentious" and "overpriced." I can see where people got this idea, but I think it's ungenerous.
First of all, not every restaurant, ethnic or otherwise, needs to be cheap with large portions and a more hearty flavor. I think it's great to have these places around and since I am not independently wealthy, I usually eat at this variety of restaurant. But seriously, why the bad attitude about a nice Indian place? Yes, the dishes are more expensive (perhaps even twice as much as an inexpensive Indian restaurant at about $15), but the flavor was really excellent in my opinion. I couldn't judge "authenticity" since I have not been to India and I frankly feel that this is a little bit of a bogus category.  The dishes were familiar, but with something a little extra. 
The atmosphere was soothing and a little fancier, but I got to sit in the window seat so I was very comfortable. The service was also good and very prompt. 
Maybe not a once a week kind of place, since it was a little pricier, but I thought it was worth driving from the Panhandle to check it out. We will go back for a low-key evening.
author: Katy W.

description: Enjoyable, if slightly westernized, Indian food.  Good vegetarian options.  A little pricer than many Indian places, especially given that the menu is pretty standard assortment of Indian food.  Service was very fast on our night, and food came out quickly after it was ordered (though we did have to be aggressive in flagging down the waiter for any requests - he very rarely came by).  Our only complaint was that we ordered appetizers and main courses, and it all came out at the same time.
author: K. B.

description: The wait staff has turned over since I was last here, no push for add ons is refreshing. Still very crowded, but I can't fault the place for sucess. Ordered the papadam, naan, lanb kabob and matar paneer. All very good. There was not much peas in the matar paneer, the paneer was exellent. The wine list is superb (for me anyway)  I am looking forward to my leftover lunch today.
author: Amanda L.

description: I ordered take out last night and I'd forgotten that their food is SPICY! Even the tandori is spicy. Good thing they have the best cucumber raita in the world.
author: joanna c.

description:
Indian food. Yelp sticker on the window. Fails to disappoint. 

I went here with my friend one night and first, we weren't even going to enter the restaurant because we felt way too underdressed with our shorts. But thank god we decided to eat there. The food took awhile to arrive at first but that's just 'cause we were both super hungry. One time a waiter came by with a delicious assortment of food and I swear, we both thought it was ours. Not. But! Our food eventually came. NAAN NAAN NAAN. Always get that naan. Best naan I have ever had in my entire life. My friend's tandori was super spicy that I swear a waterfall was rushing out of her nose, but it was still really good. For me, the chicken could've been just a tad bit juicier. I ordered the chicken curry, and I have no complaints about it. Tender tender chicken and yes, spicy curry, but the waiters serving us endless water definitely was appreciated. Well, maybe one complaint. Not enough chicken. Still, I highly recommend this place.
author: Steph W.

description: Great Indian restaurant. The owner is always there to greet you and make sure you feel welcome. The food is very tasty as well, great flavors and not as greasy as traditional indian cuisine.
author: Lev F.

description: Our favorite Indian restaurant, at least on the west side of San Francisco.  Flavors are always really fresh.  Great for takeout.
author: Colin M.

description: Good food but pricey as fuck.  It isn't hard to find affordable, good Indian in the city, so I recommend you keep looking.  But if you're in the area (West Portal) and don't want to go hunting, you won't be disappointed here.  Their breads are excellent.
author: Igor N.

description: The ambiance isn't great, but the goat-cheese naan is to die for. Try to sit up front because it's FREEZING in the back of the restaurant. Also, you'll have to wait  a long time any day of the week, but the food is well worth it.
author: Michelle D.

description:
tasty food, lots of veg options.
the goat cheese naan is crazy good, but RICH, you gotta share it or you won't be able to eat anything else.

nice enough i can take my mom there.

tables are kinda close together.
if you're a fan of OpenTable, they often have 1000 point reservations.

a lttle on the spendy side, but like i said, momma likes to go there, and who can say no to momma? not me.
author: Melody O.

description: The indian food here was not "oh my god this is the best vindaloo I've ever had" but its very good. The meat is very tender and the sauces are not full of grease. The food didn't take too long to come to our table and it was hot when it came. The service was average with our waiter giving us the right amount of attention. Their mint lemonade (I was on the wagon at the time) was refreshing. The bathrooms were quite clean also. One thing (and worth an extra star) I liked about Roti was that when you walk to the bathroom, you can look directly into the kitchen. They aren't hiding anything here and the kitchen was quite clean also. Parking is tough around here but Roti is good for a nice Indian dinner.
author: D J.

description: this place was pretty good!  the papadom and naan are really good.... also the lamb chops are killer.  The masala/korma is OK.... the tandoori stuff seems to be their specialty.  They use a lot of hot spices, so be sure to order a mango lassi!
author: Jeannie P.

description: Yeah, I mean.... the food is pretty good but its wayyyy overpriced.  The servings aren't big enough, either.  Plus, the grilled veggies were WAYYYY too salty.  Like someone-spilled-half-the-salt-shaker-in-it salty.  Also, I wouldn't bring a date here--it's so noisy I could barely hear myself talk.  I don't know how many times I had to yell, "What??!??!  I can't hear you!!!  What!??!  HUH?!?!?"  Yeah.  So, overall...  Is the food good?  Yeah, its pretty decent.  Would I come back?  Nope, don't think so.
author: suzanne l.

description: This place is a unique fancy indian food restaurant. A bit on the pricey side but well worth the price.  It's best to make reservation before going. Roti Indian Bistro is a bit small.
author: Vespa Fox C.

description: Hands down, this is the best Indian food i've ever had so far. For someone to even mention Naan and Curry in the same sentence of Roti is absolutely crazy. Yeah, it's a little pricey, but this is quality, great-tasting food. And they frequently change their specials! I do wish they lowered the cost of a few menu items, because i would be here all the time (hence the reluctant 4-star rating.)  Service is generally good, and the decor is tasteful. Be sure to try their special Naans, and the Lamb Popsicles!
author: Sandra D.

description: This restaurant is so spectacular for us - it's the place to take people from out of town and special place for small group celebrations.  While there may be other Indian restaurants in the City, Roti on West Portal is the place we take those we want to impress with a great Indian meal. After we took our nieces there - one is vegetarian - we completely changed our ordering style.  We always get a veggie dish because they are as wonderful as the chicken and lamb dishes. Out of towners who haven't had a good Indian meal ever or in a while walk out sated and sorry to be leaving.  For groups of people, the Bread Basket is a must and all of the dishes are great for sharing. Sometimes - and I'm not going to ding them for this since it is rare! - the order of things out of the kitchen can be out of whack. Since we always think of this as a "meal to share" event, my husband always places the entire order for the table.  It means we've considered the combinations of dishes to avoid ordering two dishes with the same or similar sauces.
author: Jeff S.

description: I love Indian food and there are a bunch of them scattered everywhere but came here last night for some late dinner (~9pm.) The lights were dimmed but not so much that you can hardly make out the face of your friend or significant other (i.e. no steakhouse lighting) which is good in my opinion since very very dim lighting puts me to sleep. We weren't greeted by the host or hostess. In fact there was no one in the front except some lady (whom I thought was the hostess was busily chatting away with her friends.) It seemed a bit awkward at first since there wasn't anybody to seat us for a minute so it felt like they were done for the night but we were seated eventually. The waiter was polite but I think the service could definitely be better, i.e. more water please! I ordered the Roti Dal which had lentils and other veggies; I don't know if they add any cream of sort to it but it tasted creamy but not spicy at all if you know what real Indian food taste like!! (I like my food very very spicy.) My friend ordered a special they have for this month Shakooti Lamb and that tastes pretty good and it still wasn't spicy enough for my liking but had that kick! In fact it makes the Roti Dal taste muuuccchhh better if you mix them together, use the naan to scoop it up, and get that great meld of spices&flavor. We also ordered a mango lassi and a chai tea. The mango lassi was a great drink to have with the meal or dessert (tropical flavor from the mango and creamy consistency of the yogurt.) The chai tea (as I was told) tasted decent but it doesn't have any sugar added into it (just to let you know.) I'm not sure if I will be coming back anytime soon but if the food&service says otherwise then I will. The dishes seemed small at first but don't be fooled it will fill you up.
author: Donna C.

description:
From the decor to the service to the food, this place charmed me. 

What was fantastic:
Very friendly and speedy servers. 
Delicious Secunjawi (Indian lemonade),kulfi (ice cream with saffron, pistachio, cardamon and rose water), and entrees. 
Beautiful photographs on their walls. 

The downsides:
The rosemary naan had a bit too much of the herb piled on top. We ended up scraping most of it off. 
It's small, and can get a little noisy. I don't really feel like this detracted from my experience, though. 

Not sure if Roti is worth travelling across town for, but for us Inglesiders it's great.
author: Laura K.

description: This place is sooo great! My new favorite Indian restaurant! The interior is very attractive, with warm, sepia toned walls and interesting photographs of India on the wall. The service is very kind - they gave us some free naan since we went right after it opened. The chicken tikka masala and other entrees are very fresh, and not too hot nor mild. Just perfect. A little bit pricey, but definitely worth your money. YUM!!!!!!!!
author: O K.

description: Indian food is primarily composed of inexpensive ingredients, so it's hard to swallow paying more than $10 for a dish. But Roti is an exception -- we tried five different dishes, from a tandoori fish to a modest saag daal. Everything was spectacular. The atmosphere is much nicer than the Indian dives all over town, but it's also a little cramped and noisy. Still, the food... wow.
author: Eric M.

description:
excellent date restaurant.  and by that i mean:  very nice atmosphere, knowledgeable and friendly waitstaff, extensive and delicious wine list, food preparation takes time (it's not in-and-out), price is a little high but not extravagant.

we ordered some sort of combo platter -- i don't remember what it was called -- and it was EXCELLENT.  there was plenty of food for two people, and rice and naan were included.

if you're in west portal with a bit of time to spare before your movie, definitely try Roti.
author: hillary h.

description: I'd say this place wasn't too bad except for the service and the prices. The waitress there couldn't speak english very well and it took us forever to get the language out right. I had the Badami chicken with my friend. Not bad. Now when the bill came, my jaw dropped. I'm glad it wasn't my turn to pay. ^.^
author: Jason C. J.

description: The food here is exceptional. Go for the chicken tikka masala! My two homies are from India and they love this place...How can they be wrong, I know I am not. This place rocks...
author: Michael W.

description: OMG the chicken pakora's are fuckin bomb.... i'll eat 2 orders anytime! Try em they are soooooo delicious. Overall good food, a bit pricey though, good with the drinks if you know someone.
author: Noah T.

description: yay.....i love roti!  I'm not too much of a fan of indian food but if its roti's indian food, I'm all for it.   You go rustom & brenda..then again...you go also chefs!  love the tandoori chicken, samosas...and whatever is suggested to me.  sure according to some it may be a couple bucks more or so than other places, but i'll dish out anyday, a couple more bucks for some good food.
author: Syonora A.

description:
On the plus side:  Roti's food is really delicious.  I don't know much about Indian food, but everything we ordered tasted great.  Our waiter was very friendly and helpful about answering our very basic questions about what was what.  Also, it is a nice setting.  Service was quick and professional.

On the down side:  As others have mentioned, it's pricey, service is sometimes a little too quick (like they're trying to rush you through so they can make room for the next customer), and it is a little cramped (Our table for two was about 6 inches from another table for two--not very intimate.)

I would certainly go back, especially if someone else were paying.  And it did get me motivated to look around for some less expensive Indian restaurants, which I'm sure must exist here in SF.  I'll also look for a recipe for a Mango Lassi, because it was delicious, and I'm sure I can make it at home for a lot less than $5.
author: Andy L.

description: West Portal used to be pretty old-fashioned and boring, but lately it's gotten a makeover and a bunch of really good shops and restaurants have popped up in the area, including this one. I'd consider it among the best Indian places in the city. The restaurant is beautiful and immaculate, the employees are genuinely friendly (and there are a few hotties), and the food is amazing. It's a little pricier than some other Indian places, but well worth it. Nearly everything I've tried-- samosas, lamb curry, chicken tikka masala, seafood korma, Kashmiri and veggie biryani-- was perfect. The ice cream is awesome too, and they have a very good wine list. Once your bellies are stuffed, give your leftovers to your choice of homeless guy down the street and head across to the movie theater (they just remodeled and play indie films). Then go home happy.
author: Janine M.

description: One of my favorites!  The chicken tikka masala, naan, and poori were pretty darn amazing. The only downside would be the prices, but the food is just THAT good.  The atmosphere is great and the service is very friendly. I am definitely making Roti a regualar spot for dinner with friends.
author: Katrina C.

description: This is an interesting restaurant... I preface this by saying I am yet to find an Indian restaurant that lives up to the high standard I saw in Lincoln, Nebraska of all places.  Yes, that's right the one thing the Midwest does right is not hospitality (people in SF are much friendlier) it isn't corn or beef it is F'ing Indian food.  This place does pale in comparison but is the best I have found in the city.  The naan is nothing to write home about but the Pakoras are wonderful and seafood curry is great.  The atmosphere is great for a date and the service is very good.
author: matt g.

description: I love, love, love spicy food. Lamb Korma, chicken briyani, palak paneer and vegetables samosas was delicious.
author: Jennifer I.

description: The fish dishes are very tasty at dinner, but they leave you with a much lighter wallet. If you want to save your money and get a seat easily, then lunch is the time to go. They have about ten lunch specials with generous portions of various curries with naan or rice. They also come with a cucumber salad and chai, all for around $10-12. My favorites are the Navarattan Korma with Rosemary naan and the tandoori chicken or tandoori fish salad. The only downside about these specials is that you can't order them to-go.
author: J T.

description: stay away from this place.  one of the worst experiences i have ever had.  the food was below average, the meat dish had mostly bones.  the bread was even worst.  after 35 min. we were given the bill and asked to leave to vacate the table.  funny things, there had been two empby tables up front.  in my 48 years of eating out, this is a first.  shame on you rotton indian bistro.
author: A A.

description: I really like the food at Rotis - we order the Chicken Tikka Masala quite often - but, I'm giving it 3 stars because it is very expensive for what it is. A few of us ordered takeout for lunch the other day and I had sticker shock. With a couple small cucumber salads, 3 entrees & some naan, it came to $86. We did order one of the more expensive items on the menu - Tadoori mixed grill - but, the amount provided did not seem to justify the cost. Everything is pretty pricey - especially for lunch.
author: Karen G.

description: Mostly for take-out, but also for eat-in, this restaurant's service is terrible.  While the food is good, they continually provide wrong estimates for pick-up time.  It would be OK if it was always 5-10 minutes late, because you could plan for it, but sometimes it's on time and other times 20-30 minutes late.  Worse, they just don't seem to mind, saying "hey, we're busy."
author: Dr. O.

description: Now, people who call your restaurants fusion, get a pencil and take notes. This place is awesome and a great example of fusion of Indian cuisine with more global tastes.
author: Oz O.

description: Ummm... I really like this restaurant. It's good Indian food. It's not as great as India Oven, but if you're wanting your chicken tikka masala fix, this will do. Their na'an is really good. They'll also make stuff that's not on the menu which I love. I think there's one in Burlingame, too. The only complaint I have is that sometimes when you want to do takeout their phone rolls to voicemail and you have to keep calling until you get someone on the phone.
author: Michelle B.

description: Good Indian food, albeit a little pricey. Restaurant often seems overwhelmed, though, and take-out is an iffy proposition: prepare to be left on hold forever, or sent directly to voicemail, whenever you call around dinnertime.
author: Scott K.

description: Probably, the best Indian food I've had in SF. Could be a little less loud and crammed but the food is truly excellent!
author: Z P.

description:
Food: I ordered a chicken tikka masala lunch combo. It was probably the best ever. The sauce was fan-ta-stic. The salad dressings was fe-no-me-nal. The chicken was just a little dry though.

Price: Lunch combos are reasonably priced (about 10$ per item, including salad and rice). NB: you can't take lunch combos out.
A la carte is awfully expensive for an Indian restaurant.
author: Peppe R.

description: I have to say that last year I gave this place four stars - but I'm revising my review, taking it down to 3 stars based on the service.  It just takes too long to get the food - otherwise, my opinion on the quality of food still holds strong.  You just shouldn't go there if you are really hungry, because you are going to have to wait, and wait and wait...
author: J D.

description: Have eaten here with my wife about six times. Will continue to come back.
author: Armand M.

description:
Nothing here tastes like Indian food to me. Every time I go (because I'm in the neighborhood when I happen to get a craving), I'm disappointed.

Sure, it doesn't taste BAD, but it's just so bland. My murgh masala this last time tasted like spaghetti-Os (kind of like the chicken vindaloo that reminded me of lousy buffalo wings), and the naan just plain sucked. Indian food doesn't have to burn the roof off of your mouth to be good (though I think that's often a plus), but it should be at least a little aromatic and flavorful.

Service was good, especially for a busy night, and it really is a nice space... I just wish they'd get some new cooks.
author: Nicole A.

description: my brother and I went to roti on a lonely thursday night for take out... we got a nice collection of curries (meats and a cheese), including an order of naan and rice, the staff was really nice and friendly and honest when they told us that it would be 50 MIN to get our food... it was also a tad pricy, but darn was the food good... (the cheese was a bit bland tho...)
author: James P.

description: Great place. Never disappoints. Movie theatre nearby makes for a great date combination!
author: Fred C.

description:
As a 'mostly vegetarian', I love Indian food.  Although not the cheapest Indian place around (and not the most expensive either), Roti has fantastic food, probably the best in the Sunset/Parkside/West Portal area.  The place is very clean, perhaps even a bit froufrou for some people's tastes.

Outside of the food, my best experience here was a group of boys that clearly came out to West Portal from the Castro on a Friday night and were surprised that they should have had reservations if they didn't want to wait 30+ minutes.  Yes, believe it or not, there is good food and there are people with decent taste in SF west of Twin Peaks!  ;-)
author: Chris A.

description: Absolutely one of the best Indian spots in SF.  The lamb and chicken tiki masala are my faves. Wait staff seems spot on and service comes out fast.
author: Fashionista M.

description: DEFINITELY EAT HERE. By far the best Indian food I've had! We had a super friendly waiter, and one of the restaurant owners was personally visiting tables to see how they were enjoying things. How nice is that?! We had a reservation, and were sat right away. Seriously though, the dishes my boyfriend and I ordered; were FREAKIN AMAZING! And the Nan, mouth-watering deliciousness of course just like my Currie. I ordered the Vegetarian Currie, Navrattan Korma. My boyfriend ordered one of the specials for October. This cozy joint is clean, and so are the restrooms. There is only one tiny little downfall we noticed, which was it was a bit crowded (great for business :) granted it was a Saturday night. Also, the table for two we had was probably the worst seat in the house. Much of the wait staff zips by this particular table. My chair was bumped numerous times. Even though that was somewhat of a bother, the servie and food totally made up for our crappy table. BTW, this can be a romantic dinner for two if (you guessed it) have the right table. My BF and I do our best to *not* eat out often. However, in case you're wondering: WE WILL GO BACK AGAIN, and enjoy every bite at a different table :)
author: East Bay L.

description: We don't head into West Portal often, but when we're in the area, we like to eat at Roti. In fact, if we're just sort of near the area and hungry, we might well drop in.
author: Michael K.

description:
I'd love to give this place 3.5 stars but that just isn't in the cards. Almost every time I come here I end up ordering the Roti feast. I've probably had it more than 10 times, by virtue of Roti being the closest  indian food to our house. I love the  tandoori, daal, palak paneer and paneer kofta. 
I'm lukewarm about the samosas and chicken tikka masala. In general it's a great dining experience. It can be a bit tight on busy evenings and the service can be great or poor, depending which server you get, but I would (and do) recommend it. The 1.5 star deduction is for a slight lack of authenticity of flavor (not always a bad thing), the sometimes spotty service and the rather high price. Naan N Curry on Irving has a more authentic taste (not that I'd really know me = alabaster gringo) a much grimier atmosphere and a much lower price. Both are worth checking out. Roti would be a good place to take a date, Naan N Curry would be a good place to take hand sanitizer.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Yum. nice smoky spicy chicken & lamb chops were perfect.
Service was slow as they were clearly short on waitstaff but they were good otherwise. Tasty but i still want to find a place between naan n curry and roti in terms of price. 

Biggest minus? The other patrons. Went on a slightly busyish Sunday. We didn't have a reservation nor did the couple ahead of us. We were both clearly waiting but were kind of stomped on and over by groups who would grab the hostess anytime she buzzed by. I guess having a reservation means you get to cut in line and not apologize.  May try other location to see if it's better.
author: M H.

description: I really like this place.  It is a little on the pricey side but the food is great.  I wouldn't reccommend it as a date spot though because it's really loud inside but it's great to go to with friends.  If you're going on the weekends make sure to make a reservation.
author: Kaitlin V.

description:
I recently had to console the other restaurants on West Portal.  A lot of tears were shed, for they were feeling neglected.  It's all because of that horrible Roti!  In fact, the only tummys to fill those empty chairs in those empty restaurants were the ones turned away from the doors of the ever so Polished and posh Roti.  How do you get in?  Do those people that do get in ever come out?  Would you want to?  

  Roti is loud and bawdy; like the king of the block should be.  The interior is an expensive high gloss page from a magazine.  The service shines the shoes of your stomache after guiding your every step or chasing you all over a huge playground of a menu.  The Bauchus comes out and plays the wine flute for you too!  But, simply in the ugly dress of simple words, Roti has some really good food and that's why I go there.
author: John W.

description:
This place is pretty small and if you don't make a reservation you'll probably have to wait. It still gets five stars because it is consistently delicious, and the service is excellent for a place that gets so hectic.  It does get VERY loud when it's crowded, but everyone still seems to be having a good time. 
I know it's been said before, but the goat-cheese naan is seriously awesome.  Also, the navrattan korma is amazing and their kashmiri biryani always hits the spot.  Thank god their dessert menu is "eh", or they'd be rolling me out the door.  The service is helpful and super-friendly, but not over-bearing. 
Not a lot of complaints here, except that it's in West Portal..  Oh- and their Maitre'D is always kind of a stress case.  Um, and i think my server had a hickey (-but I'm not really sure that's a complaint).
author: Joobles P.

description: HELP!!...someone needs to roll me to the car!  Oh god, I'm stuffed to the gills with food and can not move!  The food is rich but satisfying and the dishes have a wonderful blend of spices.  I've gone to other Indian restaurants and sometimes the food is too oily and full of fat!  I especially like the Tandoori mix grill and spinach with lentils.  The restaurant has a casual atmosphere with lots of families as well as couples.  The service was prompt and the restaurant itself was very clean with warm colors decorating the walls.  However, be warned that finding a parking spot is a royal pain and make reservations ahead of time because this restaurant seems to be very popular with the locals.
author: Daria i.

description: I have only eaten Roti take out, and I must say it is amazing. My new favorite Indian in the City.  Don't miss the Korma and the Murg.  If it's good take out, imagine how good it could be if you eat in! Yummy yummy.
author: Christina C.

description: AMAZING FOOD!!!  From the appetizers to the last sips of tea at the end of your meal, the food is probably some of the best I have ever had. Last minute reservations or walk in seating can be a chore, but that's how it goes when great food secrets get out. In those situations I suggest take-out. Only in-house cons would be the tight space and sometimes high noise volume (difficult to have a conversation over those of everyone around you). But, by no means should this deter you from trying and inevitably enjoying your meal. It's one of those restaurants that you begin to crave. Wonderful!
author: c k.

description: Delicious food and perfect service!  I only wish it was a place where you felt you could linger for a while because it's not a cheap meal!
author: Linda L.

description: I've heard great reviews of Roti over the years.  So when a buddy & I were in the mood for Indian food, we decided to give it a try.  It was a Monday evening about a week ago and the place was half full.  We ordered vegetarian biryani  n chicken Mikhani (?).  I was really expecting food that would tantalize my tastebuds...instead I found the food to be so bland n so blah - no spices, no kick.  If I was blindfolded, I would not  have been able to tell that I was eating Indian food.  Yet I was talking with a friend today who dined there last Saturday and she raved about it.  Wassup???  Different chef on different days of the week?
author: chitty e.

description:
We order the "Lamb Popsicles" regularly. Though we never eat in due to the finicky nature of our kids, we bring it home and it's consistently delicious. 
The staff is always personable and accomodating - even for those of us who crave vats of mint chutney and tamarind to drown the already delictableness in.
author: RD J.

description: i love the mango lassi and bread basket.  some good dishes worth trying include: roti calamari, boti kabab, and mixed seafood biryani.  while the chicken tikka masala was a bit dry, the dessert kulfi was surprisingly good.  anytime i'm craving indian, this place would be one of my choices.
author: Paulina C.

description: Well you walk into this place and realize that its small and that they don't have a lot of places for seating or to wait... The host said it would be about 20 mins when it really was 15. Thats not that bad. The food seems to be pretty good. Not the best but not the worst. We ordered are food and about 25 mins later it came. Which seems a little long... the food was a little on the pricey side... I don't really need to pay 19 dollars for chicken tikia malisa.
author: Matt S.

description: good for those people who haven't had real indian food before or/and are too lazy to go to the real indian restaurants in the tenderloin.
author: Brian B.

description: I'm loving this place.  After several visits, I'm still impressed.  The food is overall very delicious and we're particularly impressed with the lamb.  Servers are knowledgeable and very friendly.  I've made several last-minute reservations through  opentable.com and then hop a K,L or M train from Castro Station.
author: Robert P.

description: Roti is my favorite Indian restaurant by far. So why then am I giving this place a 3-star rating and not higher one? To start off, I am very picky; in order for a place to get a 4 or 5-star rating, I feel like the place must earn it, and though Roti is my favorite Indian place, it has not yet earned a high rating. The noise level at Roti is almost unbearable. Talk about din while having din-din(dinner).  The food is ok, depending on what you get. My favorite is the Gosht Vindaloo. It's delicious. Other dishes are a bit strange for my pallet, but the overall food quality is good. The decor is very modern. The other major critique I have about Roti is its service. The waitpeople are horrible. They are rude, and slow, and so complacent when it comes to checking on the customers. I hate being ignored and having to wait 10-15 minutes to get their attention when trying to order more food, or get the check. In the end, Roti is a good place if you haven't had Indian food. The price range is average (from some $7-25). The average price for the dishes there is about $16-17. Bottom line: try Roti, just don't expect 5 star quality at this 3.5 star restaurant.
author: Kevin D.

description: Excellent, hi-end Indian restaurant in good old West Portal.  The tikka masala is the big hit with nice smoky flavors and a very spicy sauce.  A little pricey for Indian, but the ambience is nice and you get the feeling when you are done that it was a nice night out.  My two experiences there (one dine in, one take out) have both been very positive.  They have gone out of their way to make sure we had a great time, even when the place was packed.  Reservations are the way to go, particularly on the weekends.
author: Jon B.

description: This place takes Indian food to a different level!!!!  As everyone says the goat cheese nann is incomparable.  And the Lamb Popcicles!  Can I say yummy yummy in the tummy?  I never have had tandoori that I can say I like.  Even when I was in India I was never impressed, but now I want to try Tandoori wherever I go.  ...But then again maybe I don't want to eat it any place else but at Roti!
author: Lana L.

description: Love this place.  Good food and good ambience, unfortunately they are not children family so most of the time I order for takeout.
author: Diem O.

description: I'll be the first to admit it- I am a BEAR when I am in the hungry mode and the ticker is showing empty.  New Year's EVE: my lady and I got to go out sans kids- in typical fashion we walked in and out of 3 places before we came to Roti.  The menu looked good- the night was young and there were tables a plenty.  Unfortunately, there was something wrong with the staffing and the place had the bookkeeper ( an older Indian gentleman) who did NOT know how to host and seat.  He was CALLING PEOPLE TO SEE IF THEY WERE COMING TO FULFILL RESERVATIONS!!! WHILE I WAS FREAKIN' STARVING!!!!  Literally, he was so nervous and didn't know what the heck he was doing.  The place was HALF FULL!!!  I asked him if we could just sit down- and that we would eat fast.  He was leaving messages on peoples voicemails to see if they were coming- sheesh.  I don't know why the waiters didn't help him out- it was awful.  A lineup started behind us- he lost at least 8 people from not knowing what the heck was going on- and he could not communicate- GGGGGRRRRRRRRRRRRRRR!!!!  Bad, bad Roti.  Next time- get it right...especially on New Year's Eve- IF there is a next time.
author: Knathan R.

description: went here again last night. they put A LOT of butter on everything! the rice is heavy on butter, the naan is too, every dish has quite a lot of butter in it. although it makes the rice fluffy and more flavorful, im glad they dont tell how much butter is actually in it. its a scary thought.
author: Raye T.

description: The food was bland, they brought my son the wrong dish, and then after spending nearly $300, the owner asked us to leave because he needed the table for another large party. My husband wasn't even done eating! We were stunned. None of us will be back.
author: jan k.

description: Came here for dinner late on a rainy Thursday night and surprised to find that the restaurant was packed.  Luckily, the parties in front of us were 3 or more and so my sister and I got the last table for 2.  The service is very good and the food is even better.  We had the Chicken Tikki Marsala and the Spinach w/ potatoes dish (can't remember the name of it) and of course, the bread basket!  Everything was very tasty and delicious!!!  And the bread basket was heavenly.  It came w/ 3 different types of Naan - all very good.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Helen V.

description: we had high expectations due to all the recommendations from people we talked to in the neighborhood.  we were not really satisfied.  we ordered a cheese/veggie app which was just ok.  i had a veggie rice dish which was only good because i doctored it with their cucumber sauce.  the staff were very nice and the atmosphere was very comfortable.
author: Tammy N.

description: Best Indian food in town.  I go there once a week.  Only complaint is that is takes a really long time to get the food.
author: Jeannine M.

description: not really upscale, but more bistro/lounge? it's not gaylord's, it's not naan n curry. the food was really good. although i'm not a fan of the lamenated menu in general, they had a "news" update piece that was actually a really nice read. our waitress was a kick, adding pleasant commentary and good humor to the night. i think her name was sarah. nice girl. at the end of the meal, we ordered another glass of wine. the manager comped two more glasses on the house. nice touch. and a great end to a nice meal.
author: heather m.

description: Great food!  Accommodating waitstaff.  It was a little loud but that might have very well just been our table.  It's even better for lunch where you can order their combo plates that perfectly hit the spot! They've got another location in downtown Burlingame.
author: B B.

description:
worst service i ever had in an indian restaurant! where are the indians anyway! we had this chinese-looking server who seemed so pissed off just being there. food is okay but they don't have that rich, warmth you typically get at naan n curry. 
not worth the wait - will never come back... 

1 star for food; 2 stars for ambiance !
author: melissa w.

description: nice ambiance. The food was ok. I guess we were dissapointed since my  husband specially asked the waitress for something that didn't have cream in it.  The item she suggested came with cream in it. She was too busy to come around and ask how we were doing during the entire meal. So we had no choice to return it or get something else :) on the bright side the other entree was god. She did however, finally realize her error and apologized. so i guess the experience was not too bad, however my husband was definitely not satisfied with the meal.
author: Beena A.

description: Located in the beautiful West Portal neighborhood of San Francisco,this establishment lacks in substance and taste. First, its way over-priced as compared to other reputable indian restaurants.  Chicken tikka massala shouldnt have to cost 16$ and the naan shouldnt cost $7 dollars..........not to mention it wasnt too appetizing. Vegetable biryani at $12 was a rip off......tasted bland and uninspired.Second,the fish and the lamb kebabs in the combination tandoori were undercooked.......I almost barfed after just one bite of the fish tandoori.......WTF!  Perhaps,the other location is better or perhaps it was an off day in the kitchen.  I've had better indian fare at places like Chaat cafe or Tandoori Mahal. This is WEST PORTAL! step it up ROTI!
author: peter n.

description: Roti's warm lighting and subtle color scheme draw you in from the cold San Francisco evening, and the menu is varied and fun to peruse.  While I want to give Roti a solid 4 stars, the reasons to do so end there.  Don't get me wrong, the food is pretty good, however I think you can get food that is just as good (or nearly as good) at a MUCH cheaper hole in the wall joint.  On top of that, Roti is the happy owner of a robust take-out business, which helps to overwhelm the kitchen.  In other words, you have to wait a very long time for the dishes you order.  Again, once you do get the food, it is quite good (I had a mix of lamb, chicken, and veggie dishes), but costs substantially more than regular Indian fare (and the cost simply does not outweigh the benefit in this guy's analysis).  On the plus side, the naan was very good and the sauces were thick and delicious.  Finally, the service was lacking.  While this was not due to the wait staff itself (I still gave the standard 20% of course), it was due to the fact that Roti is understaffed, and it shows.  Oh yeah, don't order the egg plant fritter appetizer, it's not worth it.  All that being said, I would still say that Roti is a very good place for a date...you know, "show her that you mean it with some expensive Indian food in a nice atmosphere."  Even though this review is too long and too annoying: the door is often propped open by people waiting for tables, and it can be chilly in the tables as a result.
author: Mr. G.

description: host was a bit up in the face, but a good Indian experience if you are in the area and in the mood.
author: T O.

description: The food is amazing, the service is amazing, and the atmostphere is amazing.  I got to sit on a couch with pillows while I ate.
author: Cat J.

description: OMG!!!!!!!!!!!!! Words cannot describe how much I love Roti! I am truly obsessed with everything Roti....the food, the staff, the ambiance, and not to mention the overly generous owners who consistently go out of their way to say hello to use every time we come in and send us a delicious goat cheese naan, or a phenomenal ice cream dessert from Mitchells Ice Cream.  So Sweet! I have tried almost every dish that has ever been recommended to me by the incredibly knowledgable staff and have yet to have a bad dish!!! Everything about Roti, from the adorable hostess to the fabulous bus boys, to my favorite servers, and to the over compensating Chefs ( and if course my favorite Roti owners :-) ) makes Roti an experience to never forget. It's always packed in here because this experience is unforgettable and the food is so good that I often come up to three times a week. I love to see other familiar faces as I am not the only Roti obsessed customer. For those of you who write harsh words about the staff and the food, perhaps you didnt act in the appropriate Roti manner of kindness which is why you had such a negative experience. There are times when I feel bad for the employees of Roti as they are under-staffed, however, this is YOUR time to be a compassionate customer and cooperate with the situation at hand. The food may be a bit pricey due to the fact that ALL the food is organic, fresh, and made right before your eyes. NOTHING AT ROTI IS PRE-MADE, so for those of you who seem to think the sauces "cannot be prepared mild because they are all pre-made" you CLEARLY don't know anything about the food preparation at Roti. I've never had a bad dish, a bad experience, and I dont think I ever will. GO ROTI!!!!!
author: Bertha D.

description: Roti is an Indian "bistro" ... The fancy title also means fancy prices.  Don't get me wrong, the food is really good.  But when you can get really good Indian food in tons of other SF restaurants that are almost half the price, then this place loses some appeal.  That being said, the ambiance is good and the food -mainly specials - sometimes offer a new approach to Indian cooking, which is probably why I've been here more than once...
author: M M.

description: White washed indian food at it's best. Let's make the atmosphere all pretty and then throw tons of cream into our curry dishes and undercook our thin naan, voila horrible Indian food. There is nothing authentic about this place. There are no visibile spices in any of the curries. The chicken in the chicken tikka masala was completley white and had perfectly flat edges, just like rubber. The garbanzo beans were in a wattery like substance. And to top all off, the prices are absolutley outrageous, why, because you are in the oh so prestine west portal district! Never again will I be a sucker to this place.
author: Joanna W.

description: I have had too much Indian food to know which one is more like it. This place has pretty good food. The reason I gave 3 stars is the service, I had to wait 60 min with a 30 min hold time, then the guy who served us just came and kept the dishes, no hi, no smile, no names of dishes. The guy who came to take the pappad dish didnt even ask if we were done, just came and took our dishes. Sorry if I sound like complaining but if I am paying 20-30 for a meal then I think I paying a lot of it for the service rather than just the food.
author: Rags G.

description: I LOVE their curries, naans, everything. The waitress and host was accomidating. Their veggy options are nice too. Lamb popsicles were wonderful. My party of 3 had to fight over the last popsicle of lam. I had the bread basket and it just tasted so good.
author: bob k.

description: $4 for one piece of nann.... $5 for a small side of rice... $15 for chicken vindaloo.. = $tax..$26 for takeout for one.... Average food
author: patrick d.

description: This place is great, if you get a chance go to Roti. I havent had Indian food this good in a long time
author: noah f.

description: I have grown up in Delhi and Roti is like a good indian restaurant in india
author: sachin n.

description: Great job Roti!!!!  Costs me my bread and my cheese but....yeah it's worth it!
author: K.M. M.

description: We love Roti. In every way! It's gooood, delicious, clean, great quality food made by an awesome chef who takes pride in making awesome food. The super friendly owners take care of this place like their own home. The staff is always happy and attentive, and any food that you order you're guaranteed to get super fresh ingredients mixed up in a perfect way to create a dining experience you always want to come back for. My husband, family and friend have dined at Roti numerous times and we keep going back. And not once have we been disappointed with any food we've ordered. Have a feast!
author: M R.
